Wanting to increase my social media presence in the new year. For years I've been more of a consumer of social media than a poster. I'd like to turn that around and have been saving up tons of creative ideas for posting and promoting what I do. 

Most of my clients and patients are word of mouth, but as I'm gradually transitioning to the online space, I'd like to up my social media presence.

comments.text: I've seen a few videos from Michelle Cunningham called 5-minute video and I was thinking of taking a look at those as well. If anyone has used her information, I'd love to know!

I‚Äôm not an expert by any means but I‚Äôve heard 2 pieces of advice frequently that I‚Äôve found to be true:
1. The more you post, the easier it becomes so try to post often while you‚Äôre building the skill.
2. Don‚Äôt be a perfectionist, something is better than nothing.
Good luck! üçÄ

post_text:
To those providers that live in Florida, I am a cash only PT and need to know what are the laws concerning Wellness sessions? 

How is Wellness defined in Florida?

Do we need a physician to sign off on the POC after 30 days as we do with direct access? 

How many sessions are allowed? 

What ICD 10 codes are used?

Do we need short and long term goals?

Please add any other relevant information.

comments.text:
No physician sign off required, no POC required, no minimum days it's based on what you and your client want. No ICD 10 codes required.

We should be utilizing short and long-term goals. Even good personal trainers do that. I also write up an assessment. Even if you look at some of the assessments in the personal training space, they are quite thorough. I look at joint mobility, ROM, lumbopelvic stability, screen for pelvic health issues, and assess functional movements and balance. And I write it all up just like I would for a PT assessment. Well actually I dictate it using Google docs, it's pretty fast. 

For the regular sessions for most of my training clients, I use a spreadsheet on a clipboard. It also contains an area for the assessment and plan and anything they may have told me that session. Essentially a spreadsheet soap note format.

Wellness and cash based PT are 2 different things completely. 
If you are training someone (which is essentially wellness), it‚Äôs not function based and it‚Äôs not diagnosis based.  It‚Äôs instead generalized mobility and strengthening.  It‚Äôs not sit<>stand function, it‚Äôs ‚Äúsquats‚Äù, etc. 
It‚Äôs a mindset shift.  Notes are minimal and basically are non assessment check lists of the exercises performed.  

‚Ä¢No MD signatures. 
‚Ä¢No ICD codes 
‚Ä¢As many sessions as you want. 
‚Ä¢No goals needed unless you want some fitness threshold goals. 
‚Ä¢depends on ‚Äúclient‚Äù demographic too. 

Think I got a little  wordy/redundant, but hopefully some clarification in there somewhere üòÜ

post_text:
Has anyone worked with an SEO company?
If yes, what were the results?

comments.text: I work with Jordan at Behind the Practice - it has honestly been transformational for my business. I'm about a year into my practice and didn't have much of an online presence at all (was relying solely on word of mouth and local network). I tried working with a larger scale marketing/ad company over the summer and didn't see progress over the span of 4 months (a whole story), but switched to using Behind the Practice in October. He is a PT himself so he completely understands the ins and outs of my practice. I went from getting 0 to 1 leads per month to 5 in October, 10 in November, and already 14 in December. And most of those leads (~80%) convert to an evaluation and plan of care. Beyond happy with the progress and would recommend him to anyone.
Jenny Gill is an OT who is well versed in SEO.

post_text:
How many of you have used a digital marketing agency and are satisfied with the results?

Looking to get into the Meta/Google ads world, but no idea where to start. Hoping to find an affordable marketer who can manage and run the campaigns. I know there are a lot of them out there, and many are not good. What have been your experiences? If your super happy with yours, can you drop their contact info?

Thank you kindly!

comments.text:
Who are you trying to reach with Google/Meta ads? A local audience or a broader range of potential clients? 

My recommendation for Meta ads is Kwadwo. (Pronounced Quay-jo). I met him at a business conference and I really like his down-to-earth nature. I believe he would tell you if ads were going to be a waste of money or if it was the right move for your business. 

Here's his IG: 
https://www.instagram.com/quayjo/
He also had a podcast where you can get to know him more. Be sure to listen to the story of how he and his family were living in China but then got stuck in Mexico when Covid broke out - the wildest story ever!) 

I'm an OT and now run a marketing agency (focused on email marketing and sales funnels, plus a little LinkedIn ghostwriting). I've heard from way too many clinicians that the generic marketing agencies never really "got them", and the results were disappointing. It's a recurring theme in my discovery calls and it makes me so mad.

Most of the bigger agencies have someone who does the sales calls, and that person may understand... but then they subcontract it out to a cheap writer/designer who is just trying to get it done as fast as possible. They use ChatGPT to "understand" your specialty, but miss the mark with the messaging. 

I've also been targeted by a lot of PT clinic ads that are totally irrelevant to me since I don't live anywhere near them. So you're smart to find someone who can do ads well instead of "spray and pray"!
Speak with David Bayliff and Will Boyd. They will point you in the right direction

post_text: What do you say to an established patient who is scheduled for surgery and expects you to be available for them; the patient will be out for an unknown amount of time‚Ä¶but you have a waitlist and can‚Äôt hold their spot. (Not ready to hire yet)

comments.text: I'm a solo provider/therapist. I have found that all of my clients want me to take time off...unless it interferes with their care ü§£. I tend to straddle a weekend for my time off, so that I have spots for my post-surgical clients before and after my time off. I also prioritize returning clients over new referrals. I would love to hire someone to fill in for my time off, but we have a huge PT shortage in my rural community.

I hired someone to just fill in while I was out. Not a consistent employee. 
It was very helpful.

post_text:
Hey everyone!
I‚Äôve done mobile pelvic floor therapy as well as leased space as needed from a chiro office over the last 3 years. I‚Äôm ready to have my own space, especially as I can only see clients when the chiropractors are not in the office which is very limiting. 

After looking for the last couple of months (while turning away clients who wanted office visits when their schedules didn‚Äôt match my availability there), I have found a great option in my budget ($900 for 550 sq ft with waiting room, gym area and private treatment room, and bathroom, lease 2 yrs). This location is 5 min from my house which is amazing bc I have a 4mo old and 2 y/o.

The only catch: the space is on the second floor, no elevator. I‚Äôm currently only in network with BCBS, the rest of clients are cash pay. I was considering going in network with Medicare down the road but this would make that very challenging in the next 2 years in this space. I do home visits for newly postpartum moms. With my current population I don‚Äôt think this will be an issue, aside from moms who can‚Äôt bring their stroller in. I can always offer a home visit for anyone who is mobility impaired or postop, etc. I also don‚Äôt mind helping people carry anything up the stairs if needed.

Thoughts?? Thank you!!

comments.text: Second floor space with out an elevator would be a deal breaker for me. My first office space was on the second floor but it did have an elevator. I actually had a few that were fearful of the wk are and requested to take the stairs.  I decided with my second space I absolutely wanted to be on the main floor and I‚Äôve had so many people remark about how much better they like it.

Oof that‚Äôs tough because it seems perfect in every other way! This was a dealbreaker for me because I didn‚Äôt want moms to have to worry about carrying car seats or strollers up the stairs (I‚Äôm also pelvic).

post_text: I‚Äôve been connecting with a local DPC/concierge doc, and we want to formally collaborate. She‚Äôd like to be able to pipeline her patients to me, but include my service as part of the fee they‚Äôre already paying her (so not just a referral, and then they pay for my service). We are trying to figure out how to make this work so that I am also getting paid what I am due. Could this be as simple as the physician paying me out of petty cash from her practice when I see one of her clients, or do we need to go through credenting and billing as if a traditional clinic? Or something else?? Open to ideas ‚Ä¶ I have been totally solo an fully cash-based practice for several years, so this is new territory!!

comments.text:
I love that you‚Äôre thinking through this before you jump in, because the way you structure it now is what‚Äôs going to make this collaboration actually work long term.

There are a few clean ways to look at it.

First option: treat it like you‚Äôre getting free leads. If she wants to keep her pricing exactly the same and not rearrange anything, that can still work. The big thing is you cannot let people just show up at your door expecting free ongoing PT. You need a 15 minute phone call with them first so you can set expectations clearly‚Ä¶
‚ÄúHere‚Äôs what the eval normally costs, here‚Äôs what this first session looks like inside your DPC membership, and here‚Äôs what people with your issue typically need in terms of sessions.‚Äù
Basically give it the full discovery call feel so they understand where the free part ends and where your actual plan of care begins. That protects you and makes the whole thing way smoother.

Second option: if she‚Äôs planning to raise her prices, then your service can just be baked into that increase. It becomes a value add for her members and she stays whole financially. My guess is she‚Äôs probably not looking to raise prices, but it‚Äôs still worth mentioning because it‚Äôs the most straightforward version of the model.

Third option: she pays you directly per person she sends over. If you go this route, compare it to what you‚Äôd normally spend on acquiring a patient. If you‚Äôre running paid ads, depending on your city you might be paying anywhere from $80 to $150 just to get someone on a phone call. These aren‚Äôt cold traffic leads though. These are warm, already-sold referrals coming from someone they trust. That‚Äôs worth a lot. Your conversion rate on those will typically be double what you get from ads.

If you frame it that way, you can structure a win-win so every patient who needs PT goes straight to you as the default, not ‚Äúone of several options.‚Äù She sells it as part of the experience. You take it from the first call onward.

So you‚Äôve got a few models here. Just make sure whatever you choose sets expectations properly and positions you as the consistent PT solution for her people. That‚Äôs where this kind of relationship becomes genuinely fruitful instead of chaotic.

You have to be careful with these laws -the easiest way is to just accept referrals from the doc : 

Federal Anti-Kickback Statute (AKS): Prohibits knowingly offering, paying, soliciting, or receiving any remuneration (cash, gifts, discounts) to induce referrals for services paid by federal programs (Medicare/Medicaid).
Violations are felonies with severe penalties (prison, fines, exclusion from programs).
Stark Law (Physician Self-Referral Law): Prohibits physicians from referring patients for certain services (like lab work, PT, imaging) to entities they or their family have a financial relationship with (ownership or compensation), unless an exception applies.
State Laws: Many states (e.g., Texas) have independent anti-solicitation or anti-kickback laws that can be stricter.
Professional Ethics: The APA and other  organizations specify that payments should be for services rendered, not based on the referral.

Violations are felonies with severe penalties (prison, fines, exclusion from programs).
Stark Law (Physician Self-Referral Law): Prohibits physicians from referring patients for certain services (like lab work, PT, imaging) to entities they or their family have a financial relationship with (ownership or compensation), unless an exception applies.
State Laws: Many states (e.g., Texas) have independent anti-solicitation or anti-kickback laws that can be stricter.
Professional Ethics: The APA and other  organizations specify that payments should be for services rendered, not based on the referral.

post_text: Looking for some feedback on this situation: I've been subletting from a private gym for a while now and it's been great-- until another PT owner tried to plant themselves in the space too. The gym put them off for a few months, but now they are going back on their word to me and told the other business they could see a client there. Is this a "tough ish, that's business" situation? Is this the market now? While I understand it's not personal, it's business...I guess I had more faith in professionals respecting each other's spaces. Tell me I'm wrong and I will get over it ü§£

comments.text: I signed a lease and the lease has exclusivity rights to avoid competition. Not sure if theres a way you could talk to them and see if you could get something like that? But end of the day, it unfortunately is business. I would either leave or just make sure you have clear marketing and start establishing who your clear ideal client is.

My business mentor had a similar issue and ended up leaving due to the personal relationship falling apart. 

I‚Äôve worked out of 2 gyms and each time the expectation was that I was the ‚Äúexclusive‚Äù physical therapist at the space. I give preference to clients at the space with either financial discounts or priority scheduling. 
If you have already been doing that and this still happened, my recommendation is to see if the relationship really benefits you or if you‚Äôre just using the space. 

Do they refer to you regularly? Are they using your presence at the gym to market and generate revenue? Are you regularly working with the personal trainers in the space to ensure their clientele doesn‚Äôt fall off due to injury? 

If the space is benefiting more than you, I‚Äôd consider leaving. If not and it‚Äôs fairly even, try having a more direct conversation about the logistics of your business relationship and get things in writing. 

Good luck üëçüèª

post_text:
I'm winging it here and at a point where I don't really know what to do next. 
My dream job fell into my lap in May when my husband and I decided to move to Las Vegas. I was in a comfy hospital OP ortho job in Alaska, loved my coworkers, my patients, the structure, everything. He retired and we needed more for our family, so I left that behind. I met an ATC in Vegas who owns a beautiful gym in a very affluent area, and was looking to add a PT to his space. I always felt like being a cash based therapist in a gym setting was my ideal setting, but also wanted a few more years of practice under my belt first, since I just graduated in 2023. 

It felt very meant to be though to do this now, so over the last few months, I have been getting all licensing done, and building my business. 
Finally, I'm ready to start seeing patients. I've got word of mouth and several leads from the gym owner, I've set up a Facebook page and am posting in local groups, and I paid for Facebook ads. Messages I'm getting though are from people in Boston, Michigan... I'm not sure why, and I can't figure out how to target my ads better. I've also gotten a message from a Physician trying to get me to work at his local clinic one day a week to take insurance. 

Marketing is not my thing at all. I've tried and failed in the past. I can't give up now, I've invested a lot of money into this endeavor, but I just don't know where to go from here.

comments.text:
Came here to say, having some support will definitely help address some of those doubts, and would recommend the Uncaged Team! 

Good luck!

Highly recommend business coaching. If you don‚Äôt know how to market or about business (majority of us) learning those skills are key to success. I started 8 months into my business and it was game changer wish I would have started earlier

post_text: I‚Äôm 2 years into running my own mobile part B business and have kept busy schedule throughout this time, however the process of staying busy gets frustrating. I have 2 doctors offices, one social worker and a couple med A therapists who are main referral sources. It seems that unless I‚Äôm reaching out with a ‚Äúhey if you have any patients who are in need of PT, I have immediate availability‚Äù, they don‚Äôt refer. Feel like I constantly have to nudge and annoy these people, but it works so far. I‚Äôve shown my appreciation by ordering lunch on numerous occasions. They all say they have patients in need of home PT, but yet don‚Äôt reach out‚Ä¶ anyone else feel the same way/have the same struggles?

comments.text: You have to realize that those offices see dozens of people like you walk in and out of their offices with luncheons, brochures, etc.  Whether it's from pharm reps, radiology reps, or PTs.  You have to stand out to make sure they think of you first when referring a patient to home PT.  Otherwise it's just another one of many free lunches from a "rep".  Get to know the front desk personnel..those are the people that actually hand the list of PTs to the patients.  I went so far as to offer PT to one of these front desk personnel that needed PT.  Once they see how you stand out from otherwise, they will tell patients to go to you when patients ask, "which PT on this list is the best?"
Word of mouth has worked best for me. No md. People tell others

full_thread_text:
POST: I‚Äôm 2 years into running my own mobile part B business and have kept busy schedule throughout this time, however the process of staying busy gets frustrating. I have 2 doctors offices, one social worker and a couple med A therapists who are main referral sources. It seems that unless I‚Äôm reaching out with a ‚Äúhey if you have any patients who are in need of PT, I have immediate availability‚Äù, they don‚Äôt refer. Feel like I constantly have to nudge and annoy these people, but it works so far. I‚Äôve shown my appreciation by ordering lunch on numerous occasions. They all say they have patients in need of home PT, but yet don‚Äôt reach out‚Ä¶ anyone else feel the same way/have the same struggles?

COMMENT 1: You have to realize that those offices see dozens of people like you walk in and out of their offices with luncheons, brochures, etc.  Whether it's from pharm reps, radiology reps, or PTs.  You have to stand out to make sure they think of you first when referring a patient to home PT.  Otherwise it's just another one of many free lunches from a "rep".  Get to know the front desk personnel..those are the people that actually hand the list of PTs to the patients.  I went so far as to offer PT to one of these front desk personnel that needed PT.  Once they see how you stand out from otherwise, they will tell patients to go to you when patients ask, "which PT on this list is the best?"

COMMENT 2: Word of mouth has worked best for me. No md. People tell others

post_text: And ‚Ä¶. Let‚Äôs hear what this means to you in relation to the ‚Äúevolution‚Äù of PT over the last ‚Ä¶50 years‚Ä¶. And GO!

comments.text: That we (therapists) are no longer the ones who decide what a patient‚Äôs potential is and facilitate the realization of that potential. We now often give them treatment to address where they are and pass them to a different level of care. The result is that many patients don‚Äôt reach their full recovery potential. Bad for them. Bad for us.

Every new grad (and especially seasoned PTs who know better) who works for a ‚ÄúPT Mill‚Äù with unrealistic productivity demands is making it harder for all of us to push back against exploitation and protect the integrity of our profession.

Until we come together as a majority to refuse unreasonable conditions, nothing will change.

I left in network care years ago but it took years of building credibility and experience (and feeling the burnout) in network to make the leap.

post_text: Does anyone want to share what kind of discounts or free treatments you give for things like referrals, testimonials, etc. I mainly do dry needling and manual work. Something like if a person puts in a review I give them a discounted treatment, or a referral that completes ‚Äúx‚Äù amount of sessions gets a free electro dry needling treatment?

comments.text:
We send a handwritten thank you note and $50 Amazon gift card for word of mouth referrals (for non-healthcare providers - if it‚Äôs another professional we send them a handwritten note only, no gifts) and to patients who leave a Google Review we send a handwritten thank you card. 

We do offer a free session for client testimonial videos that we use on our YouTube channel (not Google Reviews) - we book the normal 60-min session and record the testimonial video at the beginning (takes 10-20 min, depending on how prepared they are or how much they want to share) and any leftover time the patient gets free care. They love it and it feels good to give them something for their time.

I don‚Äôt like to discount or give away free things for reviews. I just email them after the session and if they have a good experience they will leave a message. 
I do every once in a while host giveaways for a free session once in a blue moon on social media to drum up engagement

Hi üëãüèº need some advice on how to tell a patient you can‚Äôt see them anymore. He‚Äôs a real energy sucker, and I need to protect my mental health. He‚Äôs been through a lot and I gave him a contact of a local counselor in our area to work things out with. I‚Äôm seeing him for a total knee replacement since the local PT clinic doesn‚Äôt take his insurance. I am out of network with his insurance though and had to get pre-authorization to see him. 

He had his operation July 21st. Probably needs a manipulation (active range is about 90¬∞ flexion incredibly painful and he‚Äôs lacking 12¬∞ extension). I came into the picture about eight weeks postop.

I would tell him that you think you‚Äôve taken him as far as you can and refer him back to the Dr. something is not right and beyond your scope of service if he has not progressed past that, especially with the extension. post_text: I am a cash-pay mobile ortho PT.  My town has several affluent neighborhoods with their own magazines.  A couple have approached me lately to purchase long-term contracts to run ads monthly.  One has 4K homes, another with 550 (and growing).  Does anyone have experience/advice on this and the ROI?

comments.text: I agree with the short term contract. As well as considering other marketing. Do you have a significant list for past patients?  That‚Äôs the best people to market to. The main problem with marketing to people is you‚Äôre trying to get them to know like and trust you.  The people that are past patients already crossed this bridge.  They‚Äôve also crossed this bridge with their family and friends.  If you can get them to talk about you, that‚Äôs where the real magic happens.

Done it once and didnt even get a phone call.  It was in 8 different country club magazines.

I agree that Next door is best.   I respond to all posts asking for a local ortho,  rheumatologist, neurologist, etc and then add, if you need PT, I am....

It has worked great and cost nothing out of my pocket.

post_text: Hello, I just wanted to confirm for Georgia practice requirements‚Äîdo we need to have the plan of care signed by the referring doctor, or is it not required within the direct access period? It has been very time consuming with too much follow-up from the doctor‚Äôs office, so I wanted to be sure of the requirement. Thank you.

comments.text:
POC or referral?

If insurance based then some insurance require a referral regardless.

Direct access prior to needing a referral is 21 days and/or 8 visits. Which ever comes first.

A POC does not need to be signed during this time, but a referral is needed for continuation outside of this time frame. Depending on how the POC is written, it can count as a prescription/referral to continhe therapy when signed.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hello, I just wanted to confirm for Georgia practice requirements‚Äîdo we need to have the plan of care signed by the referring doctor, or is it not required within the direct access period? It has been very time consuming with too much follow-up from the doctor‚Äôs office, so I wanted to be sure of the requirement. Thank you.

COMMENT 1: POC or referral?

If insurance based then some insurance require a referral regardless.

Direct access prior to needing a referral is 21 days and/or 8 visits. Which ever comes first.

A POC does not need to be signed during this time, but a referral is needed for continuation outside of this time frame. Depending on how the POC is written, it can count as a prescription/referral to continhe therapy when signed.

post_text: For mobile therapists that went to brick and mortar did you notice patients taking you "more seriously"?

comments.text: I had the opposite! My one client took her physician's suggestion to try a "traditional physical therapy office" because they have more equipment blah blah blah.... well I encouraged her and said you know what give it a try, you never know. Well she called me last night saying she was paying a 40 copay for her to be passed around or being alone to do stupid exercises such as marching and standing side leg lifts...when she could have just stated with me to not waste time. She's angry with the physician and plans to tell her physician about how in home is fantastic because you have the sole providers full attention without distraction.

We had a strong following that went from renting out space in a gym and doing some private calls for $$$. Then covid happened and we went pure mobile.  Then got our own space   

Each time the business leveled up so to speak we saw a great deal of increased respect.  Especially from other providers.   

But when my wife and I had our first kid. Patients that previously would t pay for the cash services just changed over quickly.  ‚ÄúYou have little mouths to feed‚Ä¶ I will pay extra for extra quality ‚Äú   
Keep in mind these are patients that had known my wife and I 10 years from dating to engaged to married to married with children.

Adding nursing or companion services to my therapy company:
I am curious if anybody has ever added concierge nursing to their business model? My husband is an RN and we have discussed recently, adding him to my business, to provide private concierge nursing to some of my clients who need at times entire weekend coverage. Ôøº The clients in question, do not have any significant medical problems, other than dementia, so the clients Ôøºare not medically complex. This would essentially be a more highly skilled caregiver and companion. Would love to pick your brain if you have done this.

W2 vs 1099? Looking for the most tax beneficial and clean way to do this.

comments.text: Love the idea. Be sure you aren't running into a business practice that overlaps with licensure for a home health entity. Some states will say that if you provide nursing and therapy in the home, you would look like a home health entity. Even if it's private pay.
Not a nurse, but I thought about adding my girlfriend who is a family practice physician.

post_text:
***Stick with me here...***

What YOU can pull from the recent *Cracker Barrel* fiasco.

Cracker Barrel has been an iconic establishment since first opening its doors in Lebanon, TN in 1969.

One can drive along any highway and find a packed Cracker Barrel parking lot.

To so many, it has been a place of comfort food; reminding them of going to their grandmother's for Sunday lunch.

With the founder, "Uncle Herschel", now no longer with us, the company decided to hire a marketing firm to ensure its continued success.

This is where things went south for the company.

Again, *stick with me...*

There was a major uproar nation wide over the proposed changes.

The very loyal customer fan base let their displeasure be known, and in a very short amount of time, Cracker Barrel LOST $100M in revenue.

Yes, **$100 MILLION**.

What was really the culprit for the people who love Cracker Barrel to become disenfranchised with the company?   Cracker Barrel became disconnected with the people who willingly drove an extra few miles down the road to receive what they had to offer.

Deeper still, it was the fact that a marketing firm convinced the store to build something that they (the marketing firm) wanted to create.

Do you think said marketing firm understood Cracker Barrel's customers? Nope.

The result?  Unhappy customers feeling as though they had no where to go.

***How does this relate to you?***

If you are looking to build your own practice, *UNCAGED CLINICIAN* works with you to build the business YOU want. 

One that *YOUR* customers will want to come to.

We don't offer a cookie cutter plan, nor do we even attempt to convince someone of building something that *we* want them to build.

*It's your business serving your customers.*  

We not only like it that way; we want it that way.

If going from employee to practice owner to CEO is tugging strong at your heart, now is the time to take action.

We have created a whole new ***UNCAGED UNIVERSITY*** to help you as you build your dream.

Hi, I am just starting my practice on 1st September. 
Please share some ideas inform of some free workshops or pain assessment or what else I can offer to get visibility and people try the services? I am pelvic and ortho PT.

comments.text: Get onto local mom groups if you are a pelvic PT! They may not allow advertisements, but a lot of people ask questions that you can answer and start to familiarize your community with who you are. Build trust, exposure, and good will :)

Can also give a lecture at local community centers for the city. Our city does lectures all the time and they are grateful for volunteers who want to talk to the residents, especially if you are local to that town!

post_text:
Hello friends, I have a new patient tomorrow with BCBS who is coming without a referral. Based on Georgia direct access rules, I understand I can see the patient for up to 8 visits or 21 days (whichever comes first) without a physician referral. Please confirm if I‚Äôm correct, and advise if there‚Äôs anything specific I should be mindful of when submitting claims to insurance.

Thank you!

comments.text:
Understanding of direct access is correct.

Some insurances require a referral for reimbursement. 

If you are in network you might want to check. I believe a lot of BCBS plans are now requiring pre-auth

If you are out of network then I would still advise that the patient check to see. In my experience for GA with BCBS patients have been able to submit superbills for potential reimbursement prior to us receiving  a referral without any issues.

If you are out of network and submitting the claim yourself, check to make sure a referral isn't needed. If so, then you'll have to follow their process to ensure you'll get paid.
Correct

full_thread_text:

Please confirm if I‚Äôm correct, and advise if there‚Äôs anything specific I should be mindful of when submitting claims to insurance.

Thank you!

COMMENT 1: Understanding of direct access is correct.

Some insurances require a referral for reimbursement. 

If you are in network you might want to check. I believe a lot of BCBS plans are now requiring pre-auth

If you are out of network then I would still advise that the patient check to see. In my experience for GA with BCBS patients have been able to submit superbills for potential reimbursement prior to us receiving  a referral without any issues.

If you are out of network and submitting the claim yourself, check to make sure a referral isn't needed. If so, then you'll have to follow their process to ensure you'll get paid.

post_text: Having a hard time finding therapists to do per diem work. Any ideas on how to advertise besides Indeed and those kind of sites?

comments.text:
Get a licensure list from your state. You can then pair it down to the appropriate zip codes. Sometimes those lists have phones and email, sometimes just emails, depends on the state and you can reach out with a text or email and may get a response. 

Others have some good suggestions. On indeed you can (it may be a paid option you need) message people with resumes to apply to your job. 

Therapists need active recruiting to fill a position. Just posting a job and waiting for applicants is never enough unfortunately.

I always found my per diem jobs through the therapy-grapevine . 

If I were you, I‚Äôd network with therapists and have them ask their friends who may not be practicing full time or at all. 

I was basically under cover and wouldn‚Äôt have responded to any job postings because then the head hunters come after you. üò± 

I was also wary of anyone advertising because I assumed they were desperate and wouldn‚Äôt try to demolish my boundaries. (Others may not have this issue, but a few employers burned me so I was highly skeptical and wary.)

full_thread_text:
POST: Having a hard time finding therapists to do per diem work. Any ideas on how to advertise besides Indeed and those kind of sites?

COMMENT 1: Get a licensure list from your state. You can then pair it down to the appropriate zip codes. Sometimes those lists have phones and email, sometimes just emails, depends on the state and you can reach out with a text or email and may get a response. 

Others have some good suggestions. On indeed you can (it may be a paid option you need) message people with resumes to apply to your job. 

Therapists need active recruiting to fill a position. Just posting a job and waiting for applicants is never enough unfortunately.

COMMENT 2: I always found my per diem jobs through the therapy-grapevine . 

If I were you, I‚Äôd network with therapists and have them ask their friends who may not be practicing full time or at all. 

I was basically under cover and wouldn‚Äôt have responded to any job postings because then the head hunters come after you. üò± 

I was also wary of anyone advertising because I assumed they were desperate and wouldn‚Äôt try to demolish my boundaries. (Others may not have this issue, but a few employers burned me so I was highly skeptical and wary.)

post_text:
Hello All , I just opened my own practice last week. Did my first lunch meeting yesterday and booked 3-4 in next 2 weeks . 
Any other statigy would you guys recommend to get patients.
 Little disappointed

comments.text:
My goal when I started was to talk to 5 new people every day.  I would attend networking groups, meet other PTs or OTs that do home health, gym owners.   
Set up free info talks at libraries, gyms (wherever you feel like your audience is located).  
Attend and participate in local health fairs and talk to the everyone.  
You are on the right track so far if you already have 3-4.  Keep it going!

I think I have had a handful of patients from meetings with doctors in the past 5 years. The majority of my referrals came from word of mouth from other patients. I had many referrals from home care PTs who had to DC people that still needed care but couldn‚Äôt get to a clinic. Try reaching out to any friends who are Homecare therapists. I also talked to all of my friends and family about my business in the beginning and they referred people to me. Also it‚Äôs not always a popular option but my caseload doubled once I accepted Medicare.

post_text:
Haven't ever worked in ortho, but try to keep up my ortho knowledge best I can. My 80 year old dad who hikes everyday injured his back pulling out finished plants from the garden and now can't walk without a walker. Sent him to an ortho PT and was told If disc is ruptured he would need surgery. This is different from what I remember learning. 
So my question is: 1) Do you see pts who need surgery for a ruptured disc?
2) effective exercises when everything is painful?
SI joint correction brings mild relief that doesn't last. Unable to perform meaningful extension standing or prone due to pain. Flexion worse than extension. Feels best on back with legs raised or on side with a pillow under top leg. 
Went from a painful back to not walking in a week. I would have expected him to get better not worse over the week. 
Thanks for your responses.
Edited to add: Positioning, distraction, and NSAIDs minimally helpful,  but still helpful.  
Pain radiates down right leg to outside of ankle. Constant ache back of thigh,  top quarter.
Getting a Rx for imaging since he is a Medicare recipient and doctor referral required for imaging.

comments.text: I would definitely get imaging for compression fracture. With these patients, very gentle mfr around area, core stabilization (hip isos), gentle sh extension with bands and focusing on stabilization stabilization stabilization. No ROM until fracture cleared. Usually with that their pain goes down but need to clear fracture before doing ROM.

Thank you for all the responses.  Positioning, distraction and NSAIDs minimally helpful, but still helpful. Getting a Rx for imaging since he is a Medicare recipient and requires a physician rx. Truly appreciate the insights.

post_text: What do you think about this?

comments.text:
As a former LMT of 15 years before I become an OT I do have some concerns. 

1. My biggest concern is that stretching recommendations changed in 2015 and not a lot of massage therapists or other therapists are very well informed about it. Stretching too much can actually increase risk of injury. Massage therapists, personal trainers etc are not trained nor can prescribe stretching protocols. 
2. It has morphed into something much more than stretching. 
3. We should absolutely be lobbying some of these stretch labs especially ones that use resistance bands like the example provided in the link:

https://www.instagram.com/reel/CiAhDFEDpva/?igsh=MXJwZW45bjQ4eThwag==

Stretch Lab is a national franchise that hires PTAs, trainers and h to e like to do manual stretch sessions on people. Whole body 30-60 minutes basically for people who don‚Äôt want to do the work at home. I know PTAs who have switched bc no insurance, documentation or exercise prescription. Like the massage therapists of stretching. They stretch you and you go. Come again and see someone else whatever. 
PT does a terrible job of defining and protecting our scope

post_text: I was able to schedule a meeting with the owner of anytime fitness near me for a possible Physical therapy collab. For reference, I am a mobile physical therapist. What are some pros I can highlight to show the benefit of physical therapy üòä what is beneficial for them? This is my first time doing this so I am a bit nervous. And also how do I maximize my personal benefit of having a gym that I am able to work through? Thanks!

comments.text: Don't talk about you. Ask them what their problems are and solve those. When talking with gym owners, I tell them that I want to help their members stay healthy and fit so they can KEEP going to their gym which ultimately means less cancelled memberships for their gym.
Tell them you will increase memberships as you will help those that wouldn‚Äôt feel comfortable at the gym, stay at the gym once you discharge them. They want paying members!

post_text: I just met a realtor who partners with other businesses. She meets the owners or managers and asks if she can pay for something like a danish at a local coffee shop. Then, she puts their logo and free danish on the front of the card and her info on the back. Easy way to refer someone and for them to see you did it. She‚Äôs built relationships with several businesses this way. Last week, I met a concierge pharmacist. She has ‚Äúnatural‚Äù pain spray in her pharmacy that costs $10. She agreed for me to partner with her. I‚Äôm going to purchase a pain spray for my clients who want to stop by her pharmacy. This way, I send her people who are customem to paying cash and she can do the same for me!  Just wanted to share.

I am a cash based, mobile uncaged PT, and will be sitting down for a podcast episode with the president of the APTA. If you have any questions or topics of conversation that you think might be relevant or interesting to discuss, please let me know as I am starting to plan the episode. 

Keep in mind this podcast is not strictly structured, and more conversation based...

Thank you to this group!

comments.text:
What is being done to advance direct access in all states. If we're supposed to be primary care providers for msk issues we need full direct access. 

Definitely the choice for Medicare patients to choose who they see.

If these things arent being done, why be a member? I stopped renewing because it wasn't worth it.

Hey Noe hope you and Natalie are doing well 

1. Opting out of Medicare. But that‚Äôs been said once or twice. 

2. Ordering labs/bloodwork/ imaging/ across the board not just state by state. 

3. Increasing reimbursement but that will give you the normal political answer of not In my control‚Ä¶ 

4. What efforts are being made if any to create an Evaluation/management codes for us to use for maintaining health and longevity  ie cancer, ESRD, neuro conditions,  / or what efforts are being made for evaluating a patient referring to the appropriate provider of a different specialty?  Other providers get paid for this 

5. What efforts are being made for chart reviews of incoming complex patients? 

6. Does the US intent on ever moving towards the military model domestically and having DPTs prescribe, perform injections PRP etc like in so many other countries? 

7. What efforts are being done to stop insurance companies from ‚Äútreating patients‚Äù using algorithms without a single licensed clinician reviewing the cases?  Think HR 238 which is set to allow technology to prescribe and treat diseases without a physician.

Thoughts on doing my marketing on the social media of a gym I am going to be renting from? ü§îüí™üëç
The owner offered to add my name and services on their website at no charge. Any pros and cons? ü§©üí∞ü§ù
I can only think of that people may perceive me as an employee not a independent clinician. üßë‚Äçüíºü§îü§∑

comments.text:
Will you be only posting on their social media or can you mark it as a collaboration? 

My only issue is if you only post on their social media, you are not growing your brand if you move locations. It would be better to collaborate so you both will gain followers and access their followers and if you ever leave, the followers that like your content will still be with you. Hopefully that makes sense

I‚Äôm not sure what the cons if any are? Somebody willing to put your name, face, and company on their website, for free, in front of their clientele, who they have already established the know-like-trust factor, further vouching for you as a reputable service provider? Seems like a win to me.

post_text:
Anyone have success with facebook ads? I'm trying to run a really cheap add. It's for an upcoming course i'm teaching and was just trying to dabble with ads a bit. 

I'm really frustrated. 
My add says it's active but it's not showing any action or pulling from my billing.  

I then somehow turned off the add, turned it back on but the delivery section says off... 

I feel like it should be easier than this. haha

comments.text:
Whenever I hear people say their dashboard is not showing anything, it's because they forgot to update the date. I see that the latest date in the image is June 13, 2025, so select June 14 as the latest day of the calendar.

I found running FB ads with a really cheap budget will only bring in low-quality leads because there are so many people bidding and targeting the same type of audience so the budget of $30 lifetime won‚Äôt win high-quality traffic. 

Start with $30 per day if the course is mid ticket, if it‚Äôs high ticket, then start with $50-$100 per day depending on the price point.

full_thread_text:

I then somehow turned off the add, turned it back on but the delivery section says off... 

I feel like it should be easier than this. haha

COMMENT 1: Whenever I hear people say their dashboard is not showing anything, it's because they forgot to update the date. I see that the latest date in the image is June 13, 2025, so select June 14 as the latest day of the calendar.

I found running FB ads with a really cheap budget will only bring in low-quality leads because there are so many people bidding and targeting the same type of audience so the budget of $30 lifetime won‚Äôt win high-quality traffic. 

Start with $30 per day if the course is mid ticket, if it‚Äôs high ticket, then start with $50-$100 per day depending on the price point.

post_text:
Hi all,

I currently have a cash-based, mobile PT business for neuro rehab on Long Island, NY. Most of my clientele is older due to the nature of my work . I have an instagram page that I historically have not spent a ton of time and effort on, because most of my clients are word-of-mouth or Google search referrals.  I also know my target audience may not be super active on Instagram.

I am interested in trying to attract more telehealth patients, specifically for facial palsies, as I am trained in that/ have found it's a very suitable diagnosis for telehealth compared to other neuro diagnoses. From my clinical experience, that age demographic is more diverse, and might engage more on social media. I was looking into a social media manager for this goal specifically ( it would also be great to increase engagement, etc), and in addition to just offload the work that content creation poses. I have 2 young kids and my extra time is really valuable- I don't want to spend it making reels, haha! 

Does anyone have any input on if a social media manager has been worth the money for you, assuming it is within your budget? Especially if you are looking to target a specific audience/caseload?

Thank you :)

comments.text: Hi, I also have a mobile physical therapy practice on Long Island New York. I would love to connect! I offer a hybrid business model.

post_text:
Hi everyone! I started my mobile cash based pelvic floor PT practice about 2 months ago. After going to countless doctors, I'm realizing this is not the best way to market. However, I haven't been successful yet and was wondering what people did for marketing/battling the "if I have insurance why should I pay cash" ideology. 

I have posted on some moms groups in the area and made an Instagram account that I post in a couple times a week. 

Any insight would be super helpful! TIA!!!

comments.text:
Dont brand or sell yourself as PT to customers bc they may associate that with insurance

Just call yourself the Vagina Wizard or something and watch the clients roll in

Im half kidding half serious about the name, but you might get my gist

I have the same business model as well. I helped organize a local "women's health providers/fitness instructors" lunch meet up where we had doulas, midwives, Pilates instructors, personal trainers. stroller fitness teachers, etc. we have a great referral network with eachother . I also have a working relationship with the local OBs and pediatricians. Also- other concierge medicine providers are great referral sources. I also have a small instagram account I started just as my virtual business card and friended only local moms and local business owners instead of trying to market to the masses on social media (I rarely post but it's just so people can get some visuals)

post_text: Hi everyone! I live in a popular tourist town during the summer and I was wondering if anyone had ever reached out to AirBnB owners about marketing services to the people who rent out their properties? I primarily see active older adults and was wondering if this would even be a good strategy or if people wouldn‚Äôt really care

comments.text:
Ooh, interesting idea! 
I‚Äôm in a tourist town too. Lots of people come here with money to burn each summer. 

I think it would be worth a shot, especially if you were willing to do reciprocal marketing on your socials. 

Always think about how you can exchange value when you‚Äôre going to ask for something. If any of the rental house owners are already your clients, that would be an easy ask‚Ä¶ but otherwise, think of how it helps them. 

I wouldn‚Äôt hit every rental, but find the ones that also cater to your target audience, or homes that are in areas that may attract those people.
Airbnb offer experiences, I think even fitness recently

post_text: What do you use to run demographic information to determine your new clinic location? Is there a way to find out about percentage of Medicare patients?

comments.text:
Unless you are planning on opening a Costco size clinic I wouldn‚Äôt worry about those numbers too much. 

Are you looking at leasing an existing space or building a new space?

If leasing your options will be limited to what is available. 

When we opened new clinic locations we looked for ample parking near our front entrance, high visibility, easy exit from the parking lot, and we wanted the right neighbors. 

I liked opening in areas with hospital outpatient clinics or corporate clinics across the street or within view. We pick up a lot of new patients off their marketing and their waitlist. 

I would rather pay $1,000 more on rent and save $3,000 on ads because we are in a highly visible location.

Anthony Maritato brings up very good points.  Going into a "low traffic area" because MC clients are close by doesn't equate to them coming to you.  Use the benefit of other facilities being close by to help you!  That is why you see many clinics close to hospitals or even close to other clinics.  Gyms position themselves close to other gyms all the time, in part, for this reason.  Same with food chains

I would rather pay $1,000 more on rent and save $3,000 on ads because we are in a highly visible location.

post_text:
I treat a specialty with very few providers who are knowledgeable and available for me to use as referral sources. A good portion of my patients are also part of the lgbtq+ community. A patient recently brought to my attention that one of the few providers I have referred them to is on a website that is essentially Amazon for the far right. I don't feel like I can continue to refer patients part of the lgbtq+ community to this provider. So ethically
1) I don't think I'm going to refer to them at all anymore. Not any patients
2) I don't think I need to tell this provider why. I can just....stop. 
3) what do I do about patients already seeing him. I don't want to interrupt a relationship that is working. But some of these patients would definitely not be comfortable if they knew about this.

*there's no way theyre accidentally on there. You have to create an account and step by step click that you agree with the values in order to be posted on it. So this is something they sought out and did intentionally 

Just looking for....thought? Opinions? Guidance?

comments.text:
This is America. Do what you want but expect reciprocity. You start to alienate your referrals sources d/t political ideologies then you‚Äôre going to lose business. As healthcare providers we treat regardless of personal beliefs and should be judgement free. If someone has a different political alignment than myself, big whoop. Avoid the topic and treat to the best of your ability. Let your patients make their own decisions on who they want or don‚Äôt want to see. 

I would also assume you are showing professionalism by not bad mouthing another healthcare provider to patients.
A therapist selling items on Public Square will cause you to stop sending them patients? Even if they have delivered great care to your clients?

What is the easiest way to create an Amazon link that lists all of the products I recommend to patients, just to streamline things?  

Right now I look up whatever they need and send them the Amazon link during the visit.  Because I also do personal training I am recommending more and more equipment, and sometimes might recommend multiple items, since most of these clients work out at home. 

I am looking into the Amazon Associate program, but thought that they changed their rules a while back allowing you to send the link out via text and email, and not just from your website? 

Otherwise I'll just make a Google doc with links to all of the items and call it a day. 

Always striving to be more efficient so if you have any knowledge on this I would appreciate it, thanks!

comments.text: Just got setup as amazon associate and using link tree, pretty painless! Associate, affiliate, and influencer are all different things so that was the hardest part of getting setup was figuring out what to go with or what i was approved for

Generally, you can create a wish list and add products to it to keep them all organized in one spot. But if you want to earn commissions on the items, apply for the affiliate program and then you would create an ‚Äúidea list‚Äù and add products to that and put a link to that list on your FB/insta business pages or website and you could direct people to those places to click the link to your recommended products. You can share your affiliate link on each individual item with clients but there was a rule that you couldn‚Äôt send the affiliate link directly through text. It might have changed to allow that now, not sure. The client had to go to your business page and go through the link from there.
You have to disclose that you earn commissions as an affiliate. You can check mine out on my business FB if you want. Stretch PT and Wellness ATL

post_text:
Hi everyone
I‚Äôm checking UHC insurance benefits and I always get confused when it says no referral required and no visit limits. Does it mean I can see patient without a doctor‚Äôs referral , no signed POC and however long the patient needs? Insurance also says do not charge $35 co-pay. She‚Äôs a neuro patient . Please advise, I am not trying to beat the system, I just need guidance because I‚Äôm new to this. Thank you

comments.text: Typically then you'd follow your state practice act. Always follow the strictest rule

Q: Checking insurance benefits and I always get confused when it says no referral required, and no visit limits. 
Can I see the patient without a doctor‚Äôs referral, no signed POC and however long the patient needs? 

No referral means it's not an HMO plan that would need a referral. 
Check your state direct access laws, we have 20 days or 10 visits whichever is sooner without a script, and a script from a doctor is needed to have the insurance pick it up. And also charts need a doctor's signed POC/eval and re-evals.
You have to be able to show progress, and it be a skilled therapy needed and not maintenance care. Otherwise if there's a plateau (after one re-eval already having a flare up) they may try their HEP on their own a bit, because insurance may reject payment and the bill may fall to the patient.
Also unlimited visits may also have a money cap if it's Medicare, which is about 30 visits before the chart would be audited and modifiers need to be added each time. 
Was told some neuro can be tough because can be auto immune dx e.g. M.S. where it does not always steadily improve. But working in Ortho, I don't have all the insurance and outs.

Please advise, I am not trying to beat the system, I just need guidance because I‚Äôm new to this. Thank you

COMMENT 1: Typically then you'd follow your state practice act. Always follow the strictest rule

COMMENT 2: Q: Checking insurance benefits and I always get confused when it says no referral required, and no visit limits. 
Can I see the patient without a doctor‚Äôs referral, no signed POC and however long the patient needs?

Check your state direct access laws, we have 20 days or 10 visits whichever is sooner without a script, and a script from a doctor is needed to have the insurance pick it up. And also charts need a doctor's signed POC/eval and re-evals.
You have to be able to show progress, and it be a skilled therapy needed and not maintenance care. Otherwise if there's a plateau (after one re-eval already having a flare up) they may try their HEP on their own a bit, because insurance may reject payment and the bill may fall to the patient.
Also unlimited visits may also have a money cap if it's Medicare, which is about 30 visits before the chart would be audited and modifiers need to be added each time. 
Was told some neuro can be tough because can be auto immune dx e.g. M.S. where it does not always steadily improve. But working in Ortho, I don't have all the insurance and outs.

post_text:
I got a patient (and husband) who both come once a month. One cash, one BCBS (but has 14k deductible so kind of cash).

I have a wait area, a gym area, and a private room (where most of my sessions are). They usually book first or second schedule. I usually have a 15 min break in between sessions to set up my room, go to the bathroom, breath. If first session, I arrive 10 min early to do same (I usually am exhausted by end of day and tend not to fully clean before I go home. Prefer to do it next mornings). 

They have the most annoying habit of arriving early and barging into my room vs waiting in the waitroom. I have started locking the wait area access to gym, but they will knock it and go to the glass door to the gym (and emergency door out, not usually open) and knock‚Ä¶ because I don‚Äôt have a receptionist and they are ‚Äúafraid I am not there‚Äù. üôÑ. I even added a sign: please be seated, your therapist will be with you. 

Any suggestions? 

Ps: they are snarky with other things (like asking why I did not clean on the day before if they are first ones, or whining other PT never charged copay even when she did not meet deductible, and other little silly things.

comments.text: Let them knock. Don't reward their inappropriate behavior. If it's a glass door, give them the "one second" finger gesture, and leave them alone until you are ready.

Establish boundaries. 
Tell them you appreciate their promptness but their sessions starts at (stated time). 
I also agree with the statement above that this might not be your client. You have a choice just like they do for services. Stand up for yourself and let the pieces fall where they may. 

Good luck!

When you receive a subpoena for records, do you notify the client as a courtesy?  Or just send the info? 

Some details (that I don‚Äôt think are particularly relevant but just in case):

Yes, we are ‚Äúcompetitors,‚Äù however I have given and received referrals from all of them bc we each know our specialties and all want our populations to be served as best as possible (even when it‚Äôs with another clinician).

post_text: Dear group, looking for a little advice here.  I've been in private practice PT for over 20 years in my area.  Our local hospital is purchasing many of the independent PCP offices and establishing satellite clinics all throughout our surrounding area.  I was speaking with one of their physician's regarding referrals.  He informed me if any of the provider's use an "outside" (PT) referral they will usually get a phone call from someone within the hospital system asking them why they chose to use an outside source.  In other words, the provider's are strongly 'encouraged' to refer in-house.  This has to be illegal!!  Any advice on how best to address this?  Thank you.   Please feel free to DM if needed.

comments.text: Have the patient ask for a physical copy of the referral. They have every legal right to that and in the end it doesn‚Äôt matter where the referral is written to for physical therapy just that it exist and the patient can produce it for the PT clinic. Ôøº
These hospitals are buying up all competition and getting reimbursed more for their services by insurance companies than outpatient clinics. Greed is taking over the healthcare space

full_thread_text:
POST: Dear group, looking for a little advice here.  I've been in private practice PT for over 20 years in my area.  Our local hospital is purchasing many of the independent PCP offices and establishing satellite clinics all throughout our surrounding area.  I was speaking with one of their physician's regarding referrals.  He informed me if any of the provider's use an "outside" (PT) referral they will usually get a phone call from someone within the hospital system asking them why they chose to use an outside source.  In other words, the provider's are strongly 'encouraged' to refer in-house.  This has to be illegal!!  Any advice on how best to address this?  Thank you.   Please feel free to DM if needed.

COMMENT 1: Have the patient ask for a physical copy of the referral. They have every legal right to that and in the end it doesn‚Äôt matter where the referral is written to for physical therapy just that it exist and the patient can produce it for the PT clinic. Ôøº

COMMENT 2: These hospitals are buying up all competition and getting reimbursed more for their services by insurance companies than outpatient clinics. Greed is taking over the healthcare space

post_text:
SEO anyone?

I have had my brick and mortar practice for 4 years, and have been thriving for this long on word of mouth and direct referrals. I hired on another PT and now have to fill their schedule. I have a website, but never went down the rabbit hole of SEO and really worrying about my online presence. Where do I start? Do I hire someone, do an online program? I dont know anything about making my website get in front of the people who need to see it.

comments.text:
Hire Jenny Gill or Corey Hiben for a consult or a project. 

Do not hire some rando who doesn‚Äôt really care about therapists. The results are dismal. 

If you want to learn SEO, you can. Therapists are plenty smart to learn it‚Ä¶ but I‚Äôd consider if you want to spend your time/energy or spend money. 

I understand and help people with SEO occasionally, but it‚Äôs not my specialty, so I‚Äôm throwing Jenny & Corey‚Äôs names in as far better options. üòÜ 

ChatGPT is only as good as the person promoting it, so there‚Äôs no guarantee what you‚Äôll get. It‚Äôs like asking it for an ACL rehab program - you‚Äôll get something, and it may not be half bad, but if you don‚Äôt know what the output is supposed to be you won‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs good or bad. 

Congrats on your biz growth!! ü•≥

post_text:
So I have an opportunity to go from being a woman show to working in a gym with personal trainers and lots of modalities such as hyperbaric chamber, red light therapy, cold plunge, and saunas. I would be providing PT services along with wellness such as dry needling and cupping. Has anyone gone down this route and is there anything I am missing? TIA 

Pros: we both benefit from each other's clients. I have more access to gym equipment, modalities and space. 

Cons: I would be working for them, further drive from my client population. 

I am so torn

comments.text: I agree not to work for them. U work for yourself.  Maybe agree to collaborate at their gym space 1or  2x a wk. Then u can stay avail to your local already established clients. You could buy a ref light laser for your own mobile practice use and charge for it

I would ask to rent the space with a short term initially to test the waters. 
We rented space from a gym and it went really well.
We did eventually open a space with those modalities and that‚Äôs the only reason we left. We now rent out our extra rooms to a DPC and masseuse. 
We do still have people from that gym come see us.

post_text: So looking again with frustration at all the other practices that encroach no matter how inappropriate. Maybe not taught kinesiology, physiology for a reason. Where is APTA protecting us. Other than dry needling. I can do more with less restrictions as a trainer or massage therapist. Sorry but frustrated.

comments.text: My frustration is more about the restrictions placed on PT and not other disciplines providing the same service. If it's safe for them without restrictions then why not us. As a PT, I can not take cash from a Medicare recipient but as a massage therapist or trainer I can. Ridiculous. I applauded anyone who takes the time to expand their toolbox, and provide great care, but as a PT, I expand mine and then limited as to what I can do, how I bill, who I have to report to. Just frustrating.

This is going to be an unpopular opinion but anyone with a brain and a desire can learn to do any of this online these days and can be highly effective and impactful to their clients. I think this mostly makes us upset as PTs because we went through the system, spent a crap ton of time and money and now seemingly have to compete with non PTs for the same clients. Personally, besides the foundational knowledge which is actually part of all healthcare curriculum, everything I learned that‚Äôs applicable and used on a daily basis came after school. This ad attracts me- this person admits their education was lacking, has intimate knowledge of the feel of structures and went above and beyond to educate themselves properly regarding strengthening. Kudos to them.

post_text: What tips do y‚Äôall have for establishing connections with other professionals and businesses in the area (as far as for genertainf referral sources)? I‚Äôm a mobile cash based practice is justt getting started. Thinking it would be good to get the ball rolling with reaching out to nearby physician offices, chiros, dieticians‚Ä¶ others? And ways to appeal to them in receiving referrals?

comments.text: Figure out what your niche is. Where does this niche hang out at? Speak directly to them i.e. workshops or just leading with value. When connecting with other businesses get to know their business first. Build a long term relationship where you see congruence with your business. Keep pounding the pavement weekly. Make a list of your possible dream top 100 referral partners. Then cut it down to top 20 and go after them first.
This is all really helpful! Thank you

post_text:
I have created a policy for my clinic that, when a law firm reaches out for client records, I contact the client, and then email them the records, telling them they are welcome to forward/share as they see appropriate.  
I tell the law firm (without confirming who is and isn't a client) that all clients have access to their records and can share with them if they would like to.  

(all of our clients do have access to their records anytime via the online portal, but I send them all in 1 PDF for ease and as a courtesy.)

I just had a large law firm tell me that this is unheard of and be very frusterated during the hour that it took for the client to forward them their records.

Am I missing something?  Does anyone else just provide the records directly to clients?

comments.text: Usually the records come with something signed by the patient allowing them to request them and for you to send. However- I invoice the law firm and will not send until they pay us for them.

ÔøºYou are the custodian of those records, legally. Simply sending a copy of records to a patient does not relinquish your custodial responsibility of protected health information.

If a third-party Ôøºentity has a record request with a signed patient consent form we have a legal requirement to send those records, but like some have referenced already, in certain situations we can invoice and withhold record delivery until that invoice is paid. Ôøº this tends to vary depending on area jurisdiction. Ôøº

A clinic policy like you have described does not supersede or replace Ôøºcustodial responsibility. There is a very specific process you have to go through to transfer that custodial responsibility. Ôøº

full_thread_text:
POST: I have created a policy for my clinic that, when a law firm reaches out for client records, I contact the client, and then email them the records, telling them they are welcome to forward/share as they see appropriate.  
I tell the law firm (without confirming who is and isn't a client) that all clients have access to their records and can share with them if they would like to.  

(all of our clients do have access to their records anytime via the online portal, but I send them all in 1 PDF for ease and as a courtesy.)

I just had a large law firm tell me that this is unheard of and be very frusterated during the hour that it took for the client to forward them their records.

Am I missing something?  Does anyone else just provide the records directly to clients?

COMMENT 1: Usually the records come with something signed by the patient allowing them to request them and for you to send. However- I invoice the law firm and will not send until they pay us for them.

COMMENT 2: ÔøºYou are the custodian of those records, legally. Simply sending a copy of records to a patient does not relinquish your custodial responsibility of protected health information.

If a third-party Ôøºentity has a record request with a signed patient consent form we have a legal requirement to send those records, but like some have referenced already, in certain situations we can invoice and withhold record delivery until that invoice is paid. Ôøº this tends to vary depending on area jurisdiction. Ôøº

A clinic policy like you have described does not supersede or replace Ôøºcustodial responsibility. There is a very specific process you have to go through to transfer that custodial responsibility. Ôøº

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt need those steps‚Äù

‚Äúthat‚Äôs not going to help me, I know better‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve done this work before, just tell me how to market and get more clients.‚Äù

post_text: Hi all! Looking for some guidance. I'm struggling on how I may want to move forward in my career, and I'm considering pursuing a certification in order to better market myself. I have experience in outpatient ortho as well as acute care. I'm hoping to get into an outpatient position at some point, but I'm not feeling drawn specifically to any specialty. Of the three below options, which would you feel would look best to a referring physician? For those who have pursued these specialties, do you feel they have been work it? Thanks!

comments.text:
Who cares what a referring physician thinks?

Who are you excited to work with? What population / subgroup would you treat for free and can't believe you get paid to work with?

If you're just looking to make the most $$, physical therapy is NOT the place!  Pay is questionable at best, documentation requirements are terrible (if you're in-network).  

BUT... I got to see an old woman's face light up today.  She stood up for the first time since July (& gave me the credit... despite her being the one dealing with the pain and crippling fear of fallin again).
You‚Äôd have to do market research to know which one would be most valuable in your community.

post_text:
I'm a physical therapist looking to connect with others who have partnered with gyms. I'm interested in learning more about how these relationships work, especially in regards to using gym equipment and bringing in non-member clients.

Questions:

How do you typically structure your partnership with the gym?
Are you allowed to bring in clients who are not members? If so, are there any restrictions or limitations?
Do you have to prioritize the gym's members over your own clients?
What are the benefits and challenges of partnering with a gym?

comments.text:
I do not have a private practice but have been researching here and there for a few years. These are great questions, but unfortunately, the answer is not one-size-fits-all. In terms of amenities and business practices, things may differ between gyms, so it‚Äôs essential to know what you want for both your patients and your business.

Not allowing non-members would be a major red flag. Everything else can and should be negotiated.

If they want member priority, this could be harmful for growth, but you can counter with offering designated member-only times, discounted member rates, asking for lower rent, or requesting marketing support.

There is so much ambiguity in this aspect that it will be beneficial to know where you will excel and where you may struggle, so that you ensure the partnership is mutually beneficial and unlikely to lead to future tension.

Protect your brand and your values (this is your motivation and drive), ensure a contract is formed (with plenty of reflection and revision), have an exit strategy in writing, and build in a re-negotiation date at a certain checkpoint.

As for structure, the most common that you will see are flat rate rent, percentage of revenue, or a hybrid. If you expect very fast growth, then a flat rate may be optimal. If you expect slow growth, a percentage of revenue may be better. A hybrid offers them a guarantee while giving you protection if growth is slow.

You could offer a revenue cap where you pay a percentage of revenue up to a certain threshold, followed by a reduction in percentage ‚Äî possibly even to zero. Another option is a tiered split, where the percentage decreases as your revenue increases.

Depends on your agreement/contract with gym. I like percent per visit (can be anywhere 10-30% depending on how everything is set up) rather than flat fee, this gives the gym incentive to send people your way.

post_text:
Planning to be mobile/online based. What do y'all use for your business email? I'd like it to be ***@businessname.com, but not sure how that all works! 
And is a business phone number necessary with the practice model I'll have?

comments.text:
Great questions! Here‚Äôs how to tackle both:

Business Email

To get an email like *@businessname.com, you‚Äôll need:

1. Domain Name: Purchase your domain from a provider like Google Domains (currently transitioning to Squarespace), GoDaddy, or Namecheap.

2. Email Hosting: Use a service like Google Workspace (formerly G Suite) or Microsoft 365. Both allow you to link your domain and create professional business emails. For example, Google Workspace costs around $6/month per user and comes with Gmail, Drive, and other tools.

Once your domain is set up, these platforms guide you through connecting it to your email hosting.

Business Phone Number

For a mobile or online-based practice, having a business phone number helps separate personal and business communications and builds professionalism.
Options:

Google Voice: Free for basic use, or $10+/month for advanced features.

RingCentral or Grasshopper: Paid options that provide more tools like call forwarding, texting, and voicemail.

VoIP Apps: Services like OpenPhone or Sideline are affordable and integrate seamlessly with mobile devices.

A business phone number isn‚Äôt mandatory but is helpful if you‚Äôll be communicating regularly with clients, insurance companies, or referrals. Plus, it ensures your personal line stays private.

Mike Chua's ChatDPT . üòÅüòÅüòÅ

post_text:
Could use some insight into potential for kickback law violations??

Here's what's going on: 

I have been networking with local businesses and got connected with a small gym in the area. We did a service trade experience where I went in and did their initial consult process at the gym, and the owner's wife came to my clinic and I gave her a free eval (I'm in women's pelvic health). We basically got familiar with how we each approach things and we have very similar views on health and wellness. We both feel like working together would be a good fit and are trying to find ways to work together and support each other. They've tried workshops in the past but they feel like they fall short with their clientele so they aren't super keen on that idea.

They then proposed the idea to me that if I sent people their way, they would pay me the equivalent of that person's first month membership.

I've been digging into kickback laws and it seems pretty black and white that if they were another medical provider, it would be a violation. But when it's not another medical provider it seems like a gray area? It's my first time running into this and I want to make sure I'm solid on this. Not sure if this is common practice in other industries to compensate for referrals? If so I'd also like to have a better response if it ever comes up again.

Any insight is greatly appreciated üôè

comments.text: This is 100% lawyer territory. I wouldn‚Äôt trust any Facebook group on this because the repercussions of a wrong choice could be severe and expensive.

Not an attorney obviously but I think in general receiving compensation for referrals is a bad idea. 

That being said, I don‚Äôt think this would be much different from being an affiliate for a product that you promote to patients where you get a cut of sales. Always a good idea to disclose your interest to the patient up front but I wouldn‚Äôt think you‚Äôre out of bounds legally.

post_text: I just got my new NPI2 number and when I put in a google search for my business a website called HippaSpace pops up with my NPI2 number along with all my personal information including address and phone number. I'm mobile so I don't have a physical space. It shows as my mailing address. How can I protect my personal information? I have a registered agent but don't use that as my mailing address.

comments.text: I have a po box is helped

In most cases you really can‚Äôt. 

If you have an NPI it is part of the public record. Then cross reference that with property tax records and other public directories and your info is pretty much everywhere. 

You can pay for cyber security services to monitor suspicious activity, but you really can‚Äôt stay private and be in business.
