Hello

For those of you who use DBA for your practice:

I created an entity (lets call it ABC Physical Therapy PLLC) and realized that there is another ABC Physical Therapy and Acupuncture PLLC in my city (I feel so embarrassed for not doing enough research on a name but I needed to create the PLLC quickly)! I did not realize that there was another practice with such similar name (only difference is they provide acupuncture services). 

I do NOT want to be associated with the other practice because they seem to run as a chain/mill. I filed for a DBA for the entity (lets call it 123 Physiotherapy) so I can use the DBA instead of the original name. 

Question:
1. For billing/superbill purposes - what do I write as the name of my practice? My NPI and EIN are associated with ABC Physical Therapy PLLC
2. How do I advertise? I would much rather everyone know my business as "123 Physiotherapy"
3. Is there anything that I should know about if I want to use my DBA instead of my original PLLC name? Is a DBA still considered a PLLC?

Thank you for all of your insight and help!

comments.text: In WA, I think the only time I ever see the actual business name for a different clinic I work at is on my quickbooks time sheet. Otherwise, everything is the dba. I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôll get other answers here more thorough than mine re: billing, but all of your branding should be your dba definitely. Don‚Äôt advertise anything as the original biz title.
In Florida, everything can be done under the DBA

post_text:
Illinois PT Practice Act/Direct Access Question 

This has come up a couple of times in the last few months, and I just want to make sure I'm correct. 

It's my understanding of the Practice Act that I have 5 business days to notify a ‚Äútreating healthcare professional‚Äù, chosen by the patient, that we have started PT without a referral. 

Twice, I've had prospective patients state that they've seen a PT via direct access without notifying a ‚Äútreating healthcare professional‚Äù. This doesn't seem correct based on my reading of the Practice Act. 

Any feedback from the group would be really helpful.

https://www.ipta.org/news/651241/New-Changes-Adopted-in-the-Rules-for-Administration-of-the-IL-PT-Act.htm

https://www.ilga.gov/commission/jcar/admincode/068/068013400000850R.html

comments.text: The text confuses me more a little. For the patient that doesn't not have a physician, is this saying that you just need to offer to notify? And what do you do if they do not have a physician, many with a PPO plan do not
In Illinois that just means you have to fax the plan of care to a physician.  If they don't have a current physician we just ask them who the last physician was that they saw and we send it to them.

full_thread_text:
POST: Illinois PT Practice Act/Direct Access Question 

This has come up a couple of times in the last few months, and I just want to make sure I'm correct. 

It's my understanding of the Practice Act that I have 5 business days to notify a ‚Äútreating healthcare professional‚Äù, chosen by the patient, that we have started PT without a referral. 

Twice, I've had prospective patients state that they've seen a PT via direct access without notifying a ‚Äútreating healthcare professional‚Äù. This doesn't seem correct based on my reading of the Practice Act. 

Any feedback from the group would be really helpful.

https://www.ipta.org/news/651241/New-Changes-Adopted-in-the-Rules-for-Administration-of-the-IL-PT-Act.htm

https://www.ilga.gov/commission/jcar/admincode/068/068013400000850R.html

COMMENT 1: The text confuses me more a little. For the patient that doesn't not have a physician, is this saying that you just need to offer to notify? And what do you do if they do not have a physician, many with a PPO plan do not

COMMENT 2: In Illinois that just means you have to fax the plan of care to a physician.  If they don't have a current physician we just ask them who the last physician was that they saw and we send it to them.

post_text: SLP here, how often do we need to get a physician's signature for Medicare B patients? I received the signature for the initial POC, when do I need to get another one or do I even need to? Thank you.

comments.text: When the POC expires or 90 days, whichever is sooner. You need a progress note every 10 visits but that doesn't need the doctor signature

full_thread_text:
POST: SLP here, how often do we need to get a physician's signature for Medicare B patients? I received the signature for the initial POC, when do I need to get another one or do I even need to? Thank you.

COMMENT 1: When the POC expires or 90 days, whichever is sooner. You need a progress note every 10 visits but that doesn't need the doctor signature

post_text:
I despise marketing emails.  I hate getting them... they immediately get trashed.  But "everyone" says to build your email list and send out the emails routinely.  I read in a book recently that you should expect about a 1% conversion on emails if you're making an offer.  So, despite hating the very thing that I was advised to do, I created a flyer and sent out an email with an offer of 20% off multi-visit packages through the end of the year.

You guys.

I sent the email out FOUR days ago to about 180 people, and I've sold SEVEN packages since then - about half of those are routine clients who would've purchased packages anyway, but at least one person is someone who had been a client earlier in the year and the email kickstarted him to come back.

Moral of the story: send the email, make the offer!

Topic: SEOs / Google Search 

I just moved to a new state and launched my website, so I don‚Äôt get much visits (yet! ü§û), but I make sure every web page on the site has all the necessary keywords: biz name, our services, specialties, locations, contact info, and even my name. 

I can get my business‚Äô name on the top of the first page on Google when people search it. The dilemma is when I search physical therapy + our city. The business doesn‚Äôt even show up in ANY of the pages (even as far back as page 5+). My area is pretty small and there‚Äôs no other provider within 25 mi from me, but the top hits are practices outside of my radius.

I‚Äôve spoken to local businesses owners and none of them have paid for ads or search engine page boosts. I‚Äôm sure there‚Äôs a way then to be a top (non-sponsored) hit organically, that won‚Äôt take decades to achieve. 

So for those of you who have had success in this, how are you doing it? Any advice is appreciated! ü´∂

comments.text: Just like you expect someone to pay you for your expert services, pay someone that is an expert in SEO...it's worth the ROI

Is your Google Business profile updated? 

Did you update title tags and meta descriptions too? 

Jenny Gill is an OT and copywriter who is great with SEO. 

If there aren‚Äôt other providers in the area, I would t pay someone to keep changing your SEO. You should be able to rank. 

How long have you had the website listed in the new location? 

Is your business address still an old location in some other paperwork or something? Or maybe even in your privacy policy/terms & conditions page? 

Also, have you submitted your website to get re-crawled?

post_text: Wondering if anyone has started their business as a side hustle while also working for a company in a smiliar setting and what your experience was. I am currently at a large corporation working in an outpatient setting. I am also up for a promotion to manager at this clinic. I am currently renting space at my CrossFit gym to do the occasional cupping/scraping sessions for members, but have always had dreams to turn it into an LLC structure and market out to the community for full cash based performance Physical Therapy. I really don‚Äôt want to step on any toes as I live in a very small town and would hate for my name to be ruined here. My outpatient setting is part of a hospital system so we see probably 75-80% Medicare/geriatrics and my ideal clients are the younger, active population. Would this be completely frowned upon or should I just go for it?

comments.text: I rented space out of a CrossFit gym for almost 3yr and started a LLC while working as an OP PT. I was upfront with my boss when I took the position. Now I have just recently transitioned full time to a brick and mortar location. It was a great, low risk opportunity to build a clientele up and get my feet wet!

Just check if your hospital system makes you sign a conflict of interest form or something. I just had to fill one out but nothing came of it and they might just tell you not to poach clients directly. But if you haven‚Äôt signed a non compete then you should be fine. I think being transparent to your bosses isn‚Äôt a bad idea so it doesn‚Äôt come across the wrong way, or if somehow a coworker found out and then told your bosses behind your back before you got the chance. I had a coworker try and get me trouble actually.

post_text: Today I saw a patient for s/p lumbar fusion 9 days post op. I‚Äôve seen dozens or patients with this. comments.text: Very disrespectful. You could send her to another clinician or have family members sit out in the waiting area to provide some space to work with the client. The only time I allow family members to be in the session is if I‚Äôm doing family training.

post_text: Are there any mobile ortho PTs in the group that have successfully become a "preferred provider" for orthopedic surgery group(s) in their area?  I really feel like this is an important group for us to market to, but there's a delicate line because they often have preferred PTs in their community (clinic based) that they want to feed referrals to for one reason or another.  IMO, offering 1-2 weeks at home for early post-op would be a sweet spot, then refer them to the standard clinic (if the referrer and/or patient wants to) for the remainder of rehab...?  I am thinking of the smaller ortho procedures (knee 'scope, RC repair, ACLR,) which aren't likely to qualify for home health, but need early PT.

comments.text: Interesting idea. Would you do this as a cash based service for non-Medicare folks or through insurance?
I have a mobile PT solo practice, and about 70% of my patients are first 2 weeks post-op total knees. Then the docs send them out to whatever clinic they want. I really enjoy it!

If you have a CRM, what are you using it for? I currently use Go High Level, but feel I don't really get the best use out of it. Its the user not GHL LOL.

I currently have my phone/messaging, website, contacts and referral sources on the CRM. I love it for my referral sources as its so much easier to track my conversations with providers/local business vs a spreadsheet.
While I hear it so useful, I wonder what else I can use it for? At times it feels just like another system to have in addition to my EMR?

Looking for ideas on how to use it to its full capacity to see if its truly worth the money. If anyone else has other ways to track and manage their referral system, I'd love to hear as a spreadsheet just got to cumbersome.

post_text: What can I legally/ethically offer to incentivize my neighbors to use my mobile therapy services? I figure I can cut down my in between client time significantly if they're in my zip code.  I know offering a discount is frowned upon, but legally/ethically speaking can I? Do you have other ideas of how to incentivize?  I took my first client out of my desired range because I was excited and it took me 40+ minutes each way. This is just not practical long term.

comments.text: It's really the same thing. You can either charge a travel fee for far away clients or provide a discount for nearby clients.  As you get further into this though I would definitely try to shrink your area as much as possible. Word of mouth is huge and that's usually what gets me a lot of clients in my area

Why is a discount frowned upon? If they are cash then you dictate the price. Unless they are federal payer. - different rules. Everyone starts somewhere. You incentive with everything that sets you apart from others. I have neighbors post about me in the Facebook page. Word spreads fast.

full_thread_text:
POST: What can I legally/ethically offer to incentivize my neighbors to use my mobile therapy services? I figure I can cut down my in between client time significantly if they're in my zip code.  I know offering a discount is frowned upon, but legally/ethically speaking can I? Do you have other ideas of how to incentivize?  I took my first client out of my desired range because I was excited and it took me 40+ minutes each way. This is just not practical long term.

COMMENT 1: It's really the same thing. You can either charge a travel fee for far away clients or provide a discount for nearby clients.  As you get further into this though I would definitely try to shrink your area as much as possible. Word of mouth is huge and that's usually what gets me a lot of clients in my area

COMMENT 2: Why is a discount frowned upon? If they are cash then you dictate the price. Unless they are federal payer. - different rules. Everyone starts somewhere. You incentive with everything that sets you apart from others. I have neighbors post about me in the Facebook page. Word spreads fast.

post_text:
Hi all, I'm a PT in California new to the private practice world, and I have some questions about direct access in a cash pay setting. My understanding per California law is that I need to do all of the following: 
- notify the patients that they can be seen for 12 sessions or 45 days, whichever comes first, after which we need a signed plan of care
- notify the treating physician that the patient is receiving care (requiring the signed written consent from the patient to reach out to their physician)
- and, if beyond the 45 day / 12 visit limit, get a signed and dated plan of care 

As a one-man show the prospect of having to track down PCPs to sign plans of care for patients seems like it's going to add a lot of admin time. 

Here are my questions:
* Do all practices really do this - specifically the notices? I've been to a PT before myself and I don't recall getting notified of this, though I'm sure there was stuff on the back end I didn't see
* What qualifies as "wellness"? Because wellness visits don't seem to fall under this requirement, what differentiates a wellness visit from normal PT?
* I know a lot of folks don't have established PCPs. Is there any way around this requirement for a signed plan of care if the patient doesn't have an MD etc available to evaluate them?

Thanks for any advice

post_text:
Had a patient ask if I could do a sports physical for his child. I knew right off the bat that PTs cannot, but it made me actually pause and ask why not? 
"Qualified Practitioners: The annual physical evaluation must be administered either by a licensed physician, a licensed osteopathic physician, a licensed chiropractic physician, a licensed physician assistant, or a certified advanced registered nurse practitioner."
If chiropractors were not on this list, I wouldn't have thought twice about it, but food for thought I guess?

comments.text: I honestly think it should be done by someone that is qualified to listen to heart and lungs and determine if there is abnormalities.  I further think every kids should be having an EKG and echo, but that's an argument for a different place...

In our school district, it must be a physician, NP or PA, not a nurse or chiropractor. I would not want to be responsible for clearing a student and they die on the field from heart problems or an asthma attack.

post_text:
PSA....  Phishing scam alert: 
I have had 2 in the last few months. This morning I got an email supposedly from my independent contractor who I pay direct deposit through quickbooks. Posed as her saying that she had changed her deposit bank account and needed to know how to update that for all future payments. It was obviously not her email and the wording was very generic.
A few months ago I received one from a "French PT" who had a client visiting the area for the summer and wanted to know if I could see their patient for back pain a few times/week. This would not be super unusual because I am in a resort area. They even took a bunch of descriptors from my website and included them to sound legit. I pointed them to my online booking site and then they replied asking if I would take a check from the person's manager and refund whatever funds I did not need.
I am a super small business and am frankly surprised that they found me and are putting energy into it. If they are finding me - they can find you (if you have a business website). Stay alert.

Best decision and investment I made!

I did Launchpad back in January or February and now I‚Äôm in the Pathway program (started around April)

My background: I worked for a larger private practice in my county (CA) and was clinic director of one of their offices for the last 2 years. I always knew I wanted to do something on my own. I had the dream and game plan. But didn‚Äôt have the final drive. Most likely from fear of ‚Äúnot making it‚Äù and making it hard on my wife and kids. At the same time, I was getting burnt out with the ‚Äúcaged‚Äù clinic I was at.

I was blessed to talk to David Bayliff, who gave me the inspiration and answered many of my business related questions before I joined.

I had a minor in Business Admin in college and have learned more about business (with a true emphasis on clinicians) through Launchpad and Pathway than any of my college courses. They motivate you, educate you, keep you accountable, provide you resources, and celebrate you.

I officially became Uncaged at the end of April. I‚Äôm a hybrid mobile (mostly)  PT seeing cash and Medicare. I have made 2 contracts with 2 gyms in the county where I see clients (mostly their clients) in their gyms. I‚Äôm getting pretty close to making as much as I was at my previous job (if you take into account the different expenses my business now pays for). I‚Äôm starting to prepare on hiring another PT (my goal is the end of the year).

I wouldn‚Äôt have made the jump without Uncaged. Wouldn‚Äôt have built a solid networking group without Uncaged. Wouldn‚Äôt have had a solid foundation without Uncaged. Wouldn‚Äôt have thought about contracting with any gyms without Uncaged. Lucky to have Uncaged as I plan to grow.

Feel free to message me if you have any questions!
The best advice is to hop on a call and see if we fit what you‚Äôre looking for. If you don‚Äôt trust the program or coaches you work with no program will work so find who you align with

post_text:
For Medicare clients can missed visits be made up the following week? 
I.e if POC is for 1x a week can you see client 2x next week if client had to cancel or is going out of town, etc

comments.text: Please refer to CMS transmittal 88. It clearly addresses this situation. I don‚Äôt think any amendments have been made to it since it was issued that I am aware. The short answer is: Medicare B does allow for variation from the weekly frequency as long as the total visits on the certification period remains the same based on that source document. Documentation for the reason of the variation is expected per the document.
I was last employed by a company that only saw Medicare pts. My supervisors said it was fine to do this as long as you document why (illness, vacation, family emergency etc).

full_thread_text:
POST: For Medicare clients can missed visits be made up the following week? 
I.e if POC is for 1x a week can you see client 2x next week if client had to cancel or is going out of town, etc

COMMENT 1: Please refer to CMS transmittal 88. It clearly addresses this situation. I don‚Äôt think any amendments have been made to it since it was issued that I am aware. The short answer is: Medicare B does allow for variation from the weekly frequency as long as the total visits on the certification period remains the same based on that source document. Documentation for the reason of the variation is expected per the document.

COMMENT 2: I was last employed by a company that only saw Medicare pts. My supervisors said it was fine to do this as long as you document why (illness, vacation, family emergency etc).

post_text: This seems so basic, but how do you actually drop off marketing materials to referring clinicians/mds?

comments.text:
Something off beat or off the wall like a shock and awe package.
Having written a book on your expertise works well, because it takes up physical space on their desk or shelf, but stays subconsciously in the mind. 
Mail a package of peanuts directly to the doctor with a flyer saying ‚ÄúYou‚Äôd be nuts not to work with us‚Äù
A rubber foot saying ‚ÄúI‚Äôve done the hard work for you and got my foot in the door‚Ä¶now here‚Äôs how we can work with each other to benefit our patients‚Äù
If you have a local podcast, getting them on as a guest then opening the 2 way street is a good one.

Here's my process (I'll probably get a million comments saying I'm doing it wrong but....). When I go in, I only bring one form of marketing materials, letter, brochure, card, so I have excuses to come back and drop off more. When I go in, I ask the front desk person their name and if I can drop off materials for the doctor (s). Always respect their level of busy-ness. If they have time for small chitter-chatter while I get out the materials, then that's fine. As soon as I leave the office, I write down the name of the front desk person and any little details they said (going on vacation soon, only work in the mornings, etc). I then put in my calendar when I'll be coming back to drop off more info. On the return visit, I say hello to the front desk person by name and say something about our last conversation (how was your vacation? I came in the morning because I knew you'd be here....) While dropping off different marketing materials from the last time, I try to get some Intel from the front desk (would I be able to schedule a meeting with the doc? How does your office handle PT referrals? Etc). It's a snowball process of getting the trust of the front desk, the gatekeepers. So you can get in to see the MDs face to face.

full_thread_text:

COMMENT 1: Something off beat or off the wall like a shock and awe package.
Having written a book on your expertise works well, because it takes up physical space on their desk or shelf, but stays subconsciously in the mind. 
Mail a package of peanuts directly to the doctor with a flyer saying ‚ÄúYou‚Äôd be nuts not to work with us‚Äù
A rubber foot saying ‚ÄúI‚Äôve done the hard work for you and got my foot in the door‚Ä¶now here‚Äôs how we can work with each other to benefit our patients‚Äù
If you have a local podcast, getting them on as a guest then opening the 2 way street is a good one.

COMMENT 2: Here's my process (I'll probably get a million comments saying I'm doing it wrong but....). When I go in, I only bring one form of marketing materials, letter, brochure, card, so I have excuses to come back and drop off more. When I go in, I ask the front desk person their name and if I can drop off materials for the doctor (s). Always respect their level of busy-ness. If they have time for small chitter-chatter while I get out the materials, then that's fine. As soon as I leave the office, I write down the name of the front desk person and any little details they said (going on vacation soon, only work in the mornings, etc). I then put in my calendar when I'll be coming back to drop off more info. On the return visit, I say hello to the front desk person by name and say something about our last conversation (how was your vacation? I came in the morning because I knew you'd be here....) While dropping off different marketing materials from the last time, I try to get some Intel from the front desk (would I be able to schedule a meeting with the doc? How does your office handle PT referrals? Etc). It's a snowball process of getting the trust of the front desk, the gatekeepers. So you can get in to see the MDs face to face.

What characteristics or actions do you see in common with your most successful students?

comments.text:
1) Belief. When we don‚Äôt have to spend time building belief that this will work, and belief in themselves that they can do this, then success comes more quickly.

Question(s) about a cash-based gym opportunity. This would be my first foray into such a practice model so I‚Äôm really relying on others‚Äô experience with this.

There is a new gym opening in my area. They are offering 10x12 clinic rooms as contracted space. They will provide a scheduling and payment platform/EMR, supplies (including table, needles, IASTM tools, cups, etc). Referrals would likely be easy, because it‚Äôll be gym members and their personal training clients. I would still operate under my own LLC and liability insurance. $37.50 per half hour, $75 per hour isn‚Äôt bad if you aren‚Äôt paying rent, you aren‚Äôt paying for supplies, and you aren‚Äôt paying for marketing.

It will only show the missed spam calls I get. But if I get a call from a person looking for my business it doesn‚Äôt ring, it doesn‚Äôt even show on my call history. I will only know to call them back if they leave a message. Which is super frustrating and results in more phone tag than necessary. post_text: I finally pulled the trigger and got an LLC for my mobile/gym based cash PT clinic in Gainesville, Florida.  This is definitely just a side source of income and nothing full time as I also have to juggle a lot of family demands. I want to make sure I have all the administrative steps checked before I start seeing patients.  Does anyone know if I need to register with the Florida Physical Therapy Board and the City of Gainesville?  My online search is not yielding any answers, so I am assuming no.

comments.text: I'm in Orlando Florida and I had to register my business with the county and get a local business tax receipt. I'm not sure if that applies to where you are but I would double check. Also for the state of  Florida you register as a clinic with a health care clinic exemption

Hi! I‚Äôm an OT who specializes in Barnes Myofascial Release and Pelvic Health. I have a solo practice called Zest Myofascial Release in Jacksonville Beach. I have a couple clients who drive from Gainesville to see me. I‚Äôd love to connect with you, as I don‚Äôt have a gym & focus more on somatics/mind-body treatment than exercise, but would love know someone I can refer to for this in Gainesville.

Definitely register your LLC with Sunbiz (the Florida State division of corporations) as well as your city.

full_thread_text:
POST: I finally pulled the trigger and got an LLC for my mobile/gym based cash PT clinic in Gainesville, Florida.  This is definitely just a side source of income and nothing full time as I also have to juggle a lot of family demands. Does anyone know if I need to register with the Florida Physical Therapy Board and the City of Gainesville?  My online search is not yielding any answers, so I am assuming no.

COMMENT 1: I'm in Orlando Florida and I had to register my business with the county and get a local business tax receipt. I'm not sure if that applies to where you are but I would double check. Also for the state of  Florida you register as a clinic with a health care clinic exemption

I have a couple clients who drive from Gainesville to see me. I‚Äôd love to connect with you, as I don‚Äôt have a gym & focus more on somatics/mind-body treatment than exercise, but would love know someone I can refer to for this in Gainesville.

Definitely register your LLC with Sunbiz (the Florida State division of corporations) as well as your city.

post_text:
does anyone use Google ads ? 
have they helped?

comments.text:
Google Ads can be a massive help, but results vary based on clinic type, your market, your website and ad budget.

Are you cash or insurance? Hybrid? What patient population are your targeting?

For instance, I've seen a TON of ad spend wasted on a small Google Ads budget in an area with little search volume. Targeting cash pay patients with a limited Google ads budget is difficult because a small budget means limited keywords to bid on, which means you're only targeting the highest buyer intent keywords and the vast majority of those keyword searches are coming form people who were referred to physical therapy and want to use their insurance and already have their minds made up.

If you need a quick and more predictable turn around personally I've found Facebook ads to be the fastest because you're reaching a much larger bucket of prospects because it doesn't require them to make a search before starting the conversation. $500 budget won't get you very far though.

If all I had was $500/mo to spend, I'd spend it on building and nurturing local relationships, and invest in ads when I'm ready to view it as an investment I want to scale vs a static number that I'm willing to light on fire every month.

full_thread_text:
POST: does anyone use Google ads ? 
have they helped?

COMMENT 1: Google Ads can be a massive help, but results vary based on clinic type, your market, your website and ad budget.

Are you cash or insurance? Hybrid? What patient population are your targeting?

For instance, I've seen a TON of ad spend wasted on a small Google Ads budget in an area with little search volume. Targeting cash pay patients with a limited Google ads budget is difficult because a small budget means limited keywords to bid on, which means you're only targeting the highest buyer intent keywords and the vast majority of those keyword searches are coming form people who were referred to physical therapy and want to use their insurance and already have their minds made up.

If you need a quick and more predictable turn around personally I've found Facebook ads to be the fastest because you're reaching a much larger bucket of prospects because it doesn't require them to make a search before starting the conversation. $500 budget won't get you very far though.

If all I had was $500/mo to spend, I'd spend it on building and nurturing local relationships, and invest in ads when I'm ready to view it as an investment I want to scale vs a static number that I'm willing to light on fire every month.

post_text: Does anyone have suggestions on reaching out to an ortho surgeon to tell them of your role in a patient's progress? Without going into great detail, I've dropped info & progress report with a previous patient. But current patient I didn't have a referral from this doctor. But the doctor is very pleased with their progress. I like to believe is in part to the services I provided the patient. I'd like it to get past front desk. A personal letter mailed introducing myself & the care provided to 2 mutual patients? Kind of name dropping, but attempting to figure out how to move beyond front desk & the standard referral to their physician owned clinic. Also not sure I can do this if they weren't a referring provider. ü§î

comments.text: I email them directly

Ask your patient to champion you and your services.  Talk to them about how a patient expressing to their doctor that they had a great experience, having the patient encourage the doctor to refer more to you, and have them reiterate this every time they go.  A patient going above and beyond to sing your praises is going to sway your doctor much more than anything you say.  Coach your patient on these conversations before each follow up visit with ortho.

post_text:
Question about rebranding (or starting a secondary brand).

Over the last 4 years or so my practice has been focused on dancers and performing arts. It's all we've seen thus far. 

Recently took on some non-dance clients that were referred us, which I've had great success with and apparently some word has gotten out (which is great!). I do not want to reject this population as of course it could be another source of income for us (and honestly, perhaps more steady). 

Since I am in a niche population of dance, I understand that our branding doesn't necessarily speak to the general population. 

Our clinic brand is recognizable in the dance community so I'm not changing that. 

To attract a different population is it worth it to rebrand? Do I start a "new" clinic? A DBA? 

Just need to hear some thoughts so any insight is appreciated. Has anyone run into similar situations? 

Thank you!

comments.text: I‚Äôd def discuss with your accountant‚Äîbut my guess would be DBA
I feel like Dinah Hampton of Pivot Dance & Pivot Sport in Canada could be a great person to chat with!

post_text:
Question: 
I‚Äôm a LPTA, Certified Comprehensive Pilates Instructor and Myofascial Release Practitioner Certification. I have been an employee at my current PT clinic for 15 years. I have developed Pilates programs including pilates group classes patients can join, private and semi-private lessons on various pilates apparatuses. I also see people for Myofascial release sessions for 60-90 minutes (they are first seen by PT on Evaluations). 

Anyways I‚Äôm planning on starting my own pilates and wellness center by September 2024. I‚Äôm sure I will have some clients follow me to my new business. Can my current employer sue me if clients follow me? I‚Äôm going to be getting a business lawyer to help me with my start up but wanted to hear feedback from you all too. Ôøº

Thank you kindly for your input, 
Colleen

comments.text:
I mean... Anyone CAN sue someone else. But it would be a shoddy case. Customers have the right to go wherever they please.

I'm a PT and a couple of my patients followed me when I left my clinic. I was upfront with my clinic director and my team. I chose not to "advertise" myself beyond letting patients know I would be leaving. I made it clear that it would be perfectly fine if they stayed at the clinic. If they wanted more info, I gave it to them.

Also, congrats on prepping for your own thing. üíõ

I don‚Äôt have a legal answer. I am a PTA. However if you mention your new start up in a casual conversation during treatment once you have a website and social media platform is one thing.  I would suggest that handing out  a flyer/business card with your all pertinent information  could be construed as a dirty move which could cause at the least  serious Tension. Lmao . .  Pilates + MFR with your PTA background sounds like an awesome combo for wellness!!!!!  Your going to do great!!!

I'm a PT and a couple of my patients followed me when I left my clinic. I was upfront with my clinic director and my team. I chose not to "advertise" myself beyond letting patients know I would be leaving. I made it clear that it would be perfectly fine if they stayed at the clinic. post_text:
This is the message I got from my patient today after going to her ortho follow up with her. I‚Äôve heard Anthony Maritato talk about going to MD appts with patients several times. David Bayliff and I have been talking about how to network too! 

Since starting my mobile business I want to do things differently than I‚Äôve done in the past and try to add as much value as I can. 

She is my first patient. She is seeing a local ortho doc that I have met a few times and grew up with a ton of people I grew up with. 

She had a distal humerus fracture and wore her sling 4 weeks longer than she should have. She couldn‚Äôt get PT here because she had out of state BCBS. A friend of a friend gave her my number. 

When I first saw her, she was in tears after her ortho postop visit. They told her to do PT 4x/wk, get dynasplint and she would need about 4 months of PT to even hope of getting her range back. She‚Äôs 35 c 3 kids and was scared to death. 

I gave her my rate and we decided on once a week if she would do exactly what she was supposed to do. 

After week 3 we decided on the dynasplint. Yesterday was week 6 of PT at once a week and week 3 of the dynasplint. She maxed out the extension component of the brace. 

We went into the visit missing about 5 degrees of ext and of flex. When she started she was stuck about 5-10 from 80 both ways. 

Also her bone wasn‚Äôt healing when she went last time. 

She is still not completely healed, but they released her back to work and scheduled her for 3 months out. 

I was nervous about going, because I didn‚Äôt want it to be about what I was doing there, but wanted to see if this actually made a difference in her outcome and her perceived value. I think her text and her Google review shows the value. 

Please make time to do this. I also got to talk to the ortho doc and PA. I had never met the PA. I got to share a funny story with them about texting someone who I thought was the doc (they will remember that because they all made fun of the doc afterwards in good fun). I spent about 5 minutes with the ortho MD who have me his cell number and asked how he could send more people to me. 

My plan is to focus more on the direct primary care and concierge docs in town, but I want to spend time with anyone I can to show the value I‚Äôm providing. 

This is purposely long to show how much personal value i got from this and how much my patient felt honored and cared for with this experience. 

Just do it!!!

comments.text: I love this!!
THAT‚ÄôS WHAT I‚ÄôM TALKIN‚ÄôBOUT!!

post_text:
This post is for those who are nervous about networking with local businesses. I met with six different businesses over the last two weeks - two small gyms, a running shoe store, a massage therapist, and two Pilates studios. Of those six businesses and WITHOUT ME ASKING: 

- three offered to host a pop-up for me 
- one offered to host a workshop ‚Äúbecause I have so many clients I know will benefit from this‚Äù
- the shoe store wants me at local runs they organize as medical coverage ‚Äúand so you can get free advertising‚Äù
- one offered to rent me a room should I want a home base 
- two offered to feature my business as part of their monthly newsletters with their email lists
- one Pilates studio walked me down the street to introduce me to a local acupuncturist ‚Äúbecause they need to know about your business‚Äù 

Will all of these pan out perfectly? No. But people are far more encouraging than I anticipated. All I did was:

1. Tell these businesses that I want to know where to send my clients (so their biz will benefit from meeting with me)
2. Speak about how I want to fill a need in my community that other PT clinics don‚Äôt
3. I was honest in telling these businesses that I just started advertising my services and hope to make it a full time venture. 

I‚Äôve reached out to about 20 businesses so far and I anticipate many won‚Äôt return my messages or be interested in meeting - and that‚Äôs okay! 

So many of you have been encouraging and I really appreciate this community ‚ù§Ô∏è I hope this can be a boost for others like me who dislike networking or have been intimidated by reaching out to local businesses.

post_text:
Hi everyone,

So I know we can't offer financial incentives for referrals due to kickback laws. 

I know some people who "get around" this by donating to charity. ie. "I can't offer direct financial compensation for referrals but I'd be happy to donate $50 to a charity of your choice for each referral"
 
What're people's thoughts? Genius or straight up illegal?

comments.text: Straight curious: If you're outside insurance (and especially CMS stuff) do the anti-kickbacks even apply? Those are federal regs for federal programs, right? I've never seen a state practice act address anything like this.

Eric Schneider David Bayliff

Hey I understand the sentiment guys and the value of building relationships. But I don't see why you couldn't employ both if it is legal? They aren't mutually exclusive tactics. 

For example, massage therapists offer referral discounts all the time, since they aren't subject to healthcare kickbacks. They see a client for X number of sessions. After they've built trust with the client they ask them to recommend their services to people they know and say "I offer a $20 gift voucher for any referrals that come in" This happens in gyms and other wellness businesses too. 

It happens even more often in non health/wellness businesses. Does that mean building relationships isn't important in their industries just because they use financial incentives? I would argue no. 

Regardless, I just thought it was an interesting idea. I'm not going to employ it as of yet but I don't want to completely discredit it either. I definitely don't want to if it isn't legal. Can anyone comment on legality?

Question for mobile PTs: Do you provide clients with free resistance bands? 

I would of course bring some good quality bands with me to use during treatments, but supplying them with a piece cut off of a theraband roll just doesn‚Äôt seem like enough (resistance is too light for most of my clients anyways). 

I was thinking a ‚Äúwelcome gift‚Äù of a nice set of loop bands might be a nice touch, but I‚Äôm also just starting out & trying to keep overhead costs low.

comments.text: I provide mini bands.

If a patient needs theraband for their HEP, I do give it to them. As a mobile/telehealth practice, I have found if I tell the patients to get the band themselves, they‚Äôll never do it. It‚Äôs an easy thing to provide for them and they get better quicker. Ôøº

post_text:
To those renting space in a gym:
1. Are there things you need posted to legally run your business out of the gym (labor laws, license, etc). If so, and you don‚Äôt have a separate room from the gym, how do you get around this. I‚Äôm in MA. 
2. If you‚Äôre in a gym space without your own locked room and you do mobile visits, do you need to keep your charts and paperwork that may be on paper in a locked space? Any advice on this would be greatly appreciated!

comments.text:
The Security Rule requires "covered entities to maintain reasonable and appropriate administrative, technical, and physical safeguards for protecting e-PHI."

Most everyone I know uses the double lock rule (not technically required, but good data management) - keeping physical records in a locked file cabinet or similar. For my e-PHI I keep it in a 2nd passworded/encrypted folder for anything stored locally in the event of equipment theft since I'm mobile.
Just have a good ehr

full_thread_text:
POST: To those renting space in a gym:
1. Are there things you need posted to legally run your business out of the gym (labor laws, license, etc). If so, and you don‚Äôt have a separate room from the gym, how do you get around this. I‚Äôm in MA. 
2. If you‚Äôre in a gym space without your own locked room and you do mobile visits, do you need to keep your charts and paperwork that may be on paper in a locked space? Any advice on this would be greatly appreciated!

COMMENT 1: The Security Rule requires "covered entities to maintain reasonable and appropriate administrative, technical, and physical safeguards for protecting e-PHI."

Most everyone I know uses the double lock rule (not technically required, but good data management) - keeping physical records in a locked file cabinet or similar. For my e-PHI I keep it in a 2nd passworded/encrypted folder for anything stored locally in the event of equipment theft since I'm mobile.

COMMENT 2: Just have a good ehr

Google voice users:
I currently receive my personal and business numbers through my cell. I recently brought on  a receptionist and we are trying to figure out how to use her own phone to handle calls I can forward incoming calls to her, but she has to use my phone to make calls or view texts. Is there a way to use the same number through both phones without setting her up for an additional number?  Which would defeat the purpose. 
Ideally, we'd like to set up a phone dedicated to the clinic, but this is the current situation.

Can forward the phone to ring where you want, outgoing calls/texts all from the work line + the calls are time/date stamped & can be recorded for review.
You have to be in the same Google account as her.

post_text: Simple Practice EMR users - How are you getting physician signatures on your POC documents?

comments.text: We just fax them. Unfortunately other EMRs that are much more expensive have issues with their system faxes as well. We were paying so much before and really the only part we could use was the incoming fax box it wouldn‚Äôt notify you if fax did not go through so that was a wasted feature and a huge frustration.

For doctors who have hippa compliant emails and are willing to e-sign, there is a very easy way to send the POC for signature right from the patient profile. But for the 90% of practices that want things faxed for signature... I couldn't find a good way. And their support staff were less than helpful... I ended up making a custom POC template with a signature/certification area and then I use a third party e-fax service. Less than ideal. If anybody knows a better way I'd love to hear it!

full_thread_text:
POST: Simple Practice EMR users - How are you getting physician signatures on your POC documents?

COMMENT 1: We just fax them. Unfortunately other EMRs that are much more expensive have issues with their system faxes as well. We were paying so much before and really the only part we could use was the incoming fax box it wouldn‚Äôt notify you if fax did not go through so that was a wasted feature and a huge frustration.

COMMENT 2: For doctors who have hippa compliant emails and are willing to e-sign, there is a very easy way to send the POC for signature right from the patient profile. But for the 90% of practices that want things faxed for signature... I couldn't find a good way. And their support staff were less than helpful... I ended up making a custom POC template with a signature/certification area and then I use a third party e-fax service. Less than ideal. If anybody knows a better way I'd love to hear it!

post_text:
Hey y'all, mobile PT here trying to get myself established in my community. I'm reaching out to all the local gyms to introduce myself, say hello, and ask if they're cool with me coming in and working with people who may happen to have memberships at their gyms already. Do you offer to help gym owners/employees with treatment for themselves? 
What else do you recommend asking gyms when meeting with them? This is all new to me and I feel like I'm horrible at selling myself, but I know I need to put in the work and get out in the community. Any advice is greatly appreciated! I'm meeting with two tomorrow!

comments.text: You should be trying to fill a need that the gym has (people pausing memberships, canceling, etc due to injury). You're selling a solution to a problem they have. Try to find out what their problems are and go from there. Partnership goes both ways.

I had a few gym owners ask me to look at a client or their own pain as sort of a test to make sure I was good.  One uses me if she has clients in my area, the other I actually have a revenue share agreement with so I can hold classes and see patients using his equipment.  Other gym owners just brushed me off (one of those just asked if I could work with her gym now lol).  It‚Äôs been helpful for me starting out because they have the clients and I don‚Äôt.  Once I get a following then I‚Äôll re evaluate, but never count on more than 30% of business coming from a gym you work with.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hey y'all, mobile PT here trying to get myself established in my community. I'm reaching out to all the local gyms to introduce myself, say hello, and ask if they're cool with me coming in and working with people who may happen to have memberships at their gyms already. Do you offer to help gym owners/employees with treatment for themselves? 
What else do you recommend asking gyms when meeting with them? This is all new to me and I feel like I'm horrible at selling myself, but I know I need to put in the work and get out in the community. Any advice is greatly appreciated! I'm meeting with two tomorrow!

COMMENT 1: You should be trying to fill a need that the gym has (people pausing memberships, canceling, etc due to injury). You're selling a solution to a problem they have. Try to find out what their problems are and go from there. Partnership goes both ways.

COMMENT 2: I had a few gym owners ask me to look at a client or their own pain as sort of a test to make sure I was good.  One uses me if she has clients in my area, the other I actually have a revenue share agreement with so I can hold classes and see patients using his equipment.  Other gym owners just brushed me off (one of those just asked if I could work with her gym now lol).  It‚Äôs been helpful for me starting out because they have the clients and I don‚Äôt.  Once I get a following then I‚Äôll re evaluate, but never count on more than 30% of business coming from a gym you work with.

post_text:
Hey there,
If allowed, I‚Äôd like to understand more about OTs in private practice. 

I am a PT in private practice and over the past year I‚Äôve been able to get a pretty steady case load of clients.  (Mostly all Medicare) I‚Äôd like to bring on an OT so that my clinic would better serve the population that I personally like to treat (more neuro/less orthopedic). 

I have thought about two options of 
1) hiring an OT (not sure I can afford) 
2) inviting an OT to build their own business and basically just rent space from me - I have a whole private room available and all equipment available and could add them to my current EMR, etc.  in my mind this is an extremely turnkey option for an OT to get ‚Äúuncaged‚Äù. (I win because having both disciplines seems more marketable and also from receiving rent) 

However the only OT I‚Äôve actually talked to about this was just so negative about the idea that OTs could build a caseload and how much easier it is for PTs.  

Can any uncaged OTs comment on if you were able to build a business as OT in a brick and mortar space? 

Thanks!

comments.text: That‚Äôs too bad they were negative about a great opportunity.  Some things to consider: Have you been collecting data on how many of your patients would benefit from OT?  Or how many calls and referrals you‚Äôve have for OT and had to turn away?  What are the other OT clinics doing in the area?  WHO are their clients?

I‚Äôm an OT who‚Äôs owned an OON clinic for 4 years and have a PT & OT on my staff. I honestly have realized that clients don‚Äôt care what the letters are behind the name of the person treating them, as long as they can get the help they need and they connect well with the providers. I do think PT has done much better in the marketing sector in what PTs actually do (even in acute care environments, so many assume we‚Äôre PTs), but overall, it‚Äôs not more difficult from a business standpoint!

For those of you who are fully mobile and having issues with google business profile requiring verification..... Make sure you are setup as servicing an area instead of an address and then chat with them to let them know you don't have an office to video. 
I've been through this twice with clients in the past 2 weeks and it takes them about a week or so, but they sort it out. They usually call you and chat for a bit asking questions and may ask you to send pictures of marketing materials to verify your business is real. 
If you have trouble finding where to chat, the link is below... they are quite helpful with any issues actually.

post_text:
For those doing mobile outpatient PT, how do you screen for your own self safety when starting a new patient? 

Patients will come from word of mouth referral or from a MD referral and I would use observation and general safety awareness tactics, but I‚Äôm curious what others are doing.  
I am in a large metropolitan area.

comments.text:
Pre-screen with phone calls (infections, general PMHx, patient support, animals, access to home?), know your local area (ex. Downtown SD has low income areas with very common infestation of bugs), set firm professional boundaries, know when to limit supplies that need to go in the home, and pre-assess for cognitive issues/psychiatric illness. 

I can do all this with a quick chart review and phone call screening.
Ensuring someone else knows where you are is important. Someone else who knows your schedule and where you‚Äôre supposed to be and when you‚Äôre supposed to be done.

Downtown SD has low income areas with very common infestation of bugs), set firm professional boundaries, know when to limit supplies that need to go in the home, and pre-assess for cognitive issues/psychiatric illness.

post_text: Anyone have advice on what to charge for a 2-3 hour educational course for a small group (3 personal trainers). I had a community personal trainer reach out to me asking if I could do some sort of presentation on safe lifting techniques and mechanics after coming back from an injury. Not sure what a fair price would be. Thank you!!

comments.text: Might be an unpopular opinion, but do it for free. Working alongside personal trainers can be a great source for generating referrals. I see it as a 1 time charge for the course, versus a long term relationship with the trainers. The revenue generated from one client referred to you by a personal trainer from will likely exceed the amount you‚Äôd charge for the course. Work the angle of how you can benefit their clients if they experience pain and/or restrictions in their lifting technique, and share clients this way. Food for thought üëç

It seems like ‚Äúcoaching‚Äù is completely unregulated. Why should I continue to fight insurance companies on reimbursement for CPT codes and to network for referrals from MD‚Äôs who don‚Äôt really value what I do? I‚Äôm in one of the 3 states with no direct access for a PT. Why not just become a ‚Äúcoach‚Äù and ‚Äútrain‚Äù people with a rehab/therapy mindset? Essentially be strictly Wellness. Surely I can find a masseuse to work with to offer manual/soft tissue services.

I‚Äôm obviously not in a professional crisis AT ALL‚Ä¶

comments.text: It‚Äôs a tricky! I‚Äôm an OT in same place. I‚Äôm doing educational consulting/coaching for families but very low key. I want to expand but am worried

If I remember correctly there were some PTs in Texas that tried this. They were punished because they were held to the "limitations of their highest license". Essentially they were PTs with personal trainer Certs "training" people. They were in violation of direct access laws because the grey area was deemed to lean towards therapy and not wellness. So be careful with all your notes and wording you use. I'm not the extent of the punishment, but it was mentioned on a Jarod Carter podcast.

post_text:
I'm sure this group will relate, but I recently realized I am not providing the quality patient care I would like to because of all the flaming hoops insurance has put up. I am going to make the jump to cash based and have a question for the group. 

I am in a pretty small town so I will likely need a side job as I get started. I am a physical therapist with over 15 years of outpatient experience in orthopedics and pelvic health. I am fairly certain my current employer will not be willing to let me gradually transition out. I am not picky, it doesn't have to be PT related or even in the medical/fitness field. Any suggestions?

comments.text: It‚Äôs a little different animal going cash based and I‚Äôve found the expectations are more like a trainer (I want this, this and this) than in insurance world because they are putting their own money up.  If you can fill in the gaps getting some fitness world exposure that would be helpful because for a lot of patients that is the choice they are making with their dollar (trainer vs. PT)

Small isolated town could work in your favor. Word of mouth will be a strong potential for referral. But if socioeconomics are not appropriate you will have more difficulty. Explaining difference between insurance based and private access is critical. Let patients know in many cases they are already paying for the bulk of the cost. Explain as private pay you time with them is devoted to them not paperwork for insurance company. Explain the process of reimbursement and authorizations and how that limits outpatient therapists ability to treat within full scope and autonomy. Not everyone will be interested but those that are will be. Need to show what the benefits will be to them. IE faster appointment scheduling, coming to their home or place of work, potentially fewer sessions needed, no waiting for authorizations, referrals, additional visits. Building a whole body wellness mindset starting with a relationship with a provider who can screen and make recommendations how they can feel better, be healthier‚Ä¶Your business model will reflect what those benefits are to the patients.

I am fairly certain my current employer will not be willing to let me gradually transition out. I am not picky, it doesn't have to be PT related or even in the medical/fitness field. Any suggestions?

COMMENT 1: It‚Äôs a little different animal going cash based and I‚Äôve found the expectations are more like a trainer (I want this, this and this) than in insurance world because they are putting their own money up.  If you can fill in the gaps getting some fitness world exposure that would be helpful because for a lot of patients that is the choice they are making with their dollar (trainer vs. PT)

COMMENT 2: Small isolated town could work in your favor. Word of mouth will be a strong potential for referral. But if socioeconomics are not appropriate you will have more difficulty. Explaining difference between insurance based and private access is critical. Let patients know in many cases they are already paying for the bulk of the cost. Explain as private pay you time with them is devoted to them not paperwork for insurance company. Explain the process of reimbursement and authorizations and how that limits outpatient therapists ability to treat within full scope and autonomy. Not everyone will be interested but those that are will be. Need to show what the benefits will be to them. IE faster appointment scheduling, coming to their home or place of work, potentially fewer sessions needed, no waiting for authorizations, referrals, additional visits. Building a whole body wellness mindset starting with a relationship with a provider who can screen and make recommendations how they can feel better, be healthier‚Ä¶Your business model will reflect what those benefits are to the patients.

post_text:
Pediatric COTA here with a BA in psych and extensive training in Executive functioning 

Looking to work remotely doing parent coaching , executive functioning coaching & looking to get into being an educational advocate 

Where / how do you market especially for remote work

comments.text:
Are you looking to start your own business or you want someone to hire you for those tasks? 

If you‚Äôre running your own business you can create a website and at least static social media pages (rather than worrying about posting all the time) 

Create an opt-in so people can join your email list, then a welcome/nurture/sales sequence that sends out after they join your list. 

Then you have to get traffic/get noticed. 

You can use SEO, paid ads, active social media accounts, podcasts, YouTube, etc. But you have to get in front of your ideal clients, have a solution to their problem, and establish that you‚Äôre *the* place they need to come for solutions. 

It‚Äôs a lot of groundwork to get started, but doable! 

You can‚Äôt sell ‚Äúexecutive function coaching‚Äù or ‚Äúparent coaching‚Äù though‚Ä¶ you have to sell a transformation and the solution to the problem. The coaching is just the vehicle that gets them there. 

Like selling a trip to Hawaii. You‚Äôre not selling the airplane, you‚Äôre selling the destination. üòâ 

Screen Time Clinic was helping people get started with parent/family coaching around digital wellness at one point. I‚Äôm not sure if they still are, but you could contact them. I think they were doing a monthly fee for a certification and being listed on their website/getting marketing materials and support from them. But you‚Äôd still be running your own business and getting clients.

post_text:
Anyone have any suggestions on marketing ideas? I'm supposed to open a prenatal/postpartum group fitness and physical therapy studio Evolution Mom NJ  in January and I've gotten a decent amount of traffic to my website but no bites yet, that is just with local doc visits (haven't gotten past the front desk)using social media and a local daycare email list. I've been doing what I can to boost my Google ranking but it's hard since I'm not technically open yet! 

I'm wondering if it's just bc I'm not open till Jan but was hoping to have had some inquiries/class registrations...

also not sure how to grow the local social media following? 

Any ideas!? 

Thanks in advance! This group has been so helpful in getting to this point!

comments.text:
One idea could be doing a workshop at a local library or other venue to give people a chance to get to know you and the specific problems you solve. 

Maybe even a free class at the end of the workshop to let people experience the services you offer.

Congrats! I def agree with the above, find some mom groups online and offline, offer a free workshop or class, and get to know your local midwives and doulas. 
For the website, which is beautiful btw, you may want to change a few things on your site structure. It's difficult to tell that you need to register or purchase classes on site from the homepage and from the schedule page. Also, instead of registering for a class it just adds it to the cart which can be confusing for people if not explained. Try updating that and adding more calls to action on the homepage so people have more direction. You can break up the longer paragraphs so only 1-2 sentences are together so it reads easier. 
As far as SEO, the site is missing important meta data, image alt text, the H1-H4 headers aren't appropriate, and try optimizing for local keywords. That should help your local search a lot, although Google can take up to 6 mo to show a site in search, you can manually submit the sitemap to speed that up.
Don't forget you need a popup for cookie approval to be compliant and a website privacy policy (you have HIPAA but you need a website one also or you can combine the two on one page). Just pick one social to concentrate on, you can always share the same things across tt, fb, and insta too.

post_text: Does anyone have recommendations/advice on how to do better marketing? Specifically via social media/Instagram to gain folllowers?  I now have online fitness programs up on Everfit app and trying to find ideas on how to better market the programs and gain clients.  Marketing to my womens mountain bike club of 3,500+ ladies hasn‚Äôt been enough so far.  üòí

comments.text: Be consistent, pool your audience to know what they want to know, create content around what they want to know and not what you think they want to know, be consistent and post daily.

Don‚Äôt overcomplicate it. Just provide value. Post simple videos or text posts answering a common question or issue your clients run into. Do NOT get caught into the trap of trying over explain yourself in your caption (we all do it). Because then it will take you like 45 minutes to make 1 post. Keep things as simple as you can and try to make each post just 1 main thing you are trying to get across. Don‚Äôt worry about editing posts or anything. Just post. Show your personality (people work with people they like). See what works and what doesn‚Äôt. Go from there. 

Why would somebody want your program? What are they going to get out of it? And I don‚Äôt mean ‚Äúget stronger, more fit, etc etc‚Äù because every program ever says that. What actual problem will your program help solve for mountain bikers? What are the things people complain about most often? Stay on the bike longer? No longer need long rest breaks once you get to the top? 

Don‚Äôt try to just post stuff on the mountain biking group to market, just be in there a lot and answer questions and show them you are knowledgeable and eventually people will reach out to you. 

Think of social media marketing as farming. Just keep planting seeds, and then eventually you‚Äôll be able to harvest them.

post_text:
Advice appreciated cause I don‚Äôt know who to ask! This group is an absolute blessing.‚Ä¶ 

Background info first:
I‚Äôm a DPT, CSCS with an LLC. 
Main gig is independent contractor at an ortho clinic and then I see private clients/athletes under my LLC with home visits. 

I also work for a gym 0-10 hours/week. Clients see me for personal training, recovery sessions, and physical therapy. The gym pays me as their highest level trainer. I do not operate out of the gym as my business, they pay me W2. Clients pay the gym, gym pays me as employee. So this is where all my questions come from with this setup. 

Most important question:
- I offer my home visit LLC clients a superbill obviously since that is my business but a gym client is asking, I said no since she pays the gym and not me (my personal info & medical credentials is not on her bills, she pays for a level X trainer). Is this the right assumption? Is there a better explanation to give her? I said, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think so but I‚Äôll do some research.‚Äù They then asked/suggested if I could write a letter with my info, medical reasons they are being seen and attach a gym bill‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm not sure how to proceed     üôè any advice?üôè 

Two other questions if anyone has read this far: 
- Trainers want me to assess their Medicare age clients for minor injuries, HEP, and program advice/modifications. The goals are for in the gym & wellness is not covered by Medicare. Even so do I need to have them sign something strictly because they are consulting with a PT and no cash PT with Medicare eligible? Or should i just be extra clear in my personal documenting?

Consent form:
- I assume I‚Äôm covered by the gym since I‚Äôm hired as a trainer but they don‚Äôt have anything to help regarding my license (I‚Äôm assuming). Because of this should I have those seeing me because I‚Äôm a PT sign a consent from my LLC? I have liability insurance under my LLC with the gyms name in the policy. Would a form even be valid in case something happened since the client never paid the LLC but only the gym?

In order to be a business you must act like a business but this pay setup makes that quite confusing ü´†. This is my fun job that I‚Äôm using to learn from, it‚Äôs not permanent but I‚Äôd rather not give it up because having a PT license is over complicating it lol

comments.text: I would not provide the gym client a superbill. You are seeing her as a trainer, not a PT. Though you are held to your highest license, if you start providing superbills at the gym you are essentially saying you are performing PT services which is not the intended job there and could get very muddy. If she wants to see you for reimbursable services she would have to see you through your LLC, in my opinion. Please note that all of this is just how I would operate things and is not intended as legal advice. Hope that helps.

If a gym client wants Physical Therapy give her option of home based or office based treatments not at the gym. Jumping back and forth as a trainer the a PT doing injury assessments and education is creating confusion for you so imagine how confused clients and patients will be. As far as liability in the event something happens and a law suit is filed typically Everyone gets pulled into the suit. Who ever pays the premium is the sole responsibility of that insurance company. Always protect yourself with your own policies even if employers has a policy with your name on it also.

I do not operate out of the gym as my business, they pay me W2. Clients pay the gym, gym pays me as employee. So this is where all my questions come from with this setup. 

Most important question:
- I offer my home visit LLC clients a superbill obviously since that is my business but a gym client is asking, I said no since she pays the gym and not me (my personal info & medical credentials is not on her bills, she pays for a level X trainer). Is this the right assumption? Is there a better explanation to give her? I said, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think so but I‚Äôll do some research.‚Äù They then asked/suggested if I could write a letter with my info, medical reasons they are being seen and attach a gym bill‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm not sure how to proceed     üôè any advice?üôè 

Two other questions if anyone has read this far: 
- Trainers want me to assess their Medicare age clients for minor injuries, HEP, and program advice/modifications. The goals are for in the gym & wellness is not covered by Medicare. Even so do I need to have them sign something strictly because they are consulting with a PT and no cash PT with Medicare eligible? Or should i just be extra clear in my personal documenting?

Consent form:
- I assume I‚Äôm covered by the gym since I‚Äôm hired as a trainer but they don‚Äôt have anything to help regarding my license (I‚Äôm assuming). Because of this should I have those seeing me because I‚Äôm a PT sign a consent from my LLC? I have liability insurance under my LLC with the gyms name in the policy. Would a form even be valid in case something happened since the client never paid the LLC but only the gym?

In order to be a business you must act like a business but this pay setup makes that quite confusing ü´†. This is my fun job that I‚Äôm using to learn from, it‚Äôs not permanent but I‚Äôd rather not give it up because having a PT license is over complicating it lol

COMMENT 1: I would not provide the gym client a superbill. You are seeing her as a trainer, not a PT. Though you are held to your highest license, if you start providing superbills at the gym you are essentially saying you are performing PT services which is not the intended job there and could get very muddy. If she wants to see you for reimbursable services she would have to see you through your LLC, in my opinion. Please note that all of this is just how I would operate things and is not intended as legal advice. Hope that helps.

COMMENT 2: If a gym client wants Physical Therapy give her option of home based or office based treatments not at the gym. Jumping back and forth as a trainer the a PT doing injury assessments and education is creating confusion for you so imagine how confused clients and patients will be. As far as liability in the event something happens and a law suit is filed typically Everyone gets pulled into the suit. Who ever pays the premium is the sole responsibility of that insurance company. Always protect yourself with your own policies even if employers has a policy with your name on it also.

post_text:
I rent space out of a gym currently for my PT practice and specialize in working with athletes. Referrals from in house have been steady, but not enough to keep my schedule full. (It‚Äôs a small private gym.) 

No surprise that while other gyms and fitness facilities don‚Äôt offer PT in house, referring clients to me because I am located in a gym is a barrier. 

Any advice on how to best approach outside trainers or gym facilities in this situation?

comments.text:
Gyms are territorial. 
It's easiest when they've been your patients and "get it" or get the type of client you are looking for.
Like anything these relationships take time to nurture, and knowing how much energy to put into the "right" relationships. It's like dating, they won't say yes on the first date. Keep showing up if you think it's worth the energy.

I was located in a CrossFit gym, and got referrals from all the other CrossFit gyms. For me it came down to knowing the individual trainers/coaches at the gyms, not the owners. Owners will be overprotective of their business (which is probably hurting them). The trainers and coaches will just do whatever they need to, to help their clients. 

If you have contact with the owners, you just need to make sure they know that your goal is to get their members healthy and back into their own gyms as quickly as you can so they don‚Äôt cancel their memberships or feel like they are wasting them.

full_thread_text:

No surprise that while other gyms and fitness facilities don‚Äôt offer PT in house, referring clients to me because I am located in a gym is a barrier. 

Any advice on how to best approach outside trainers or gym facilities in this situation?

COMMENT 1: Gyms are territorial. 
It's easiest when they've been your patients and "get it" or get the type of client you are looking for.
Like anything these relationships take time to nurture, and knowing how much energy to put into the "right" relationships. It's like dating, they won't say yes on the first date. Keep showing up if you think it's worth the energy.

COMMENT 2: I was located in a CrossFit gym, and got referrals from all the other CrossFit gyms. For me it came down to knowing the individual trainers/coaches at the gyms, not the owners. Owners will be overprotective of their business (which is probably hurting them). The trainers and coaches will just do whatever they need to, to help their clients. 

If you have contact with the owners, you just need to make sure they know that your goal is to get their members healthy and back into their own gyms as quickly as you can so they don‚Äôt cancel their memberships or feel like they are wasting them.

comments.text: Medicare doesn't really care about scripts. But direct access or not, a claim must have a referring provider. This is who will sign the POC. Some clinics require a script to ensure this doctor will sign. But if audited, Medicare wants to see a signed POC. Not a script.

Hi folks, looking for some advice on how to market effectively and establish a larger footprint. 
I have a part time cash pay practice in CA with a niche focus (circus, pole dance) but am also very comfortable with martial arts, weight lifting, and rock climbing. Though I want to establish myself in this niche community, as I'm starting out I want to prioritize reaching more people so that I can scale. That is to say, I don't want my website to only highlight the niche audience if that will reduce the likelihood of getting other types of athletes, but I also recognize that including too many areas of specialty can dilute the sense of expertise in the area I want to establish myself in.

post_text: Question for all of you Uncaged PT clinic owners. We are contemplating offering Annual Physical Therapy Evaluations for our geriatric population. The question is, if the physician request and recommends the annual exam be completed for a client to establish baseline measures and identify risk factors for future injury, are we able to submit that visit to Medicare and Medicare advantage plans for reimbursement. We are in a direct access state so we technically don‚Äôt need a physician referral to evaluate, if that matters. The annual exam would be conducted essentially as an initial evaluation as it is anticipated that nearly all of our prospective clients would have deficits and areas of concern that at the very least would warrant a HEP. Our thoughts would be to address the concerns of the client through the evaluation and bill Medicare for the evaluation. If not medically necessary to treat additionally it would be an eval only and if warranted a plan of care would be developed and physician signature would be requested before treatment began. Thoughts?
