post_text:
I‚Äôve searched the group and am piecing info together, but would love some direct advice. I am a PT, but left hospital based outpatient care a few years back and am functioning now as a mobile personal trainer. I have my own LLC. Over the years, I have had many clients and gyms who have reached out to me asking to provide physical therapy services. I‚Äôve had to refer out or turn them down. Recently a gym offered me the option of leasing space from them, but in hopes I would be able to offer PT. I can figure out the logistics- I have the LLC. This would continue to be a cash based business. I would have the space to treat. Obviously consider costs of leasing. I already have liability insurance that covers me for PT and wellness. I would have a network for referrals. I can piece together the other legal aspects, forms, etc. But what other or big things am I not considering??

(And yes, I am interested in offering PT as part of my business. I have turned down enough opportunities over the years. This particular gym and owner align really with my business model.)

comments.text: As Tom Conlon pointed out, you will need to check with both State and City to see if they require a "business license/permit".  This can vary state to state and city to city.  Yes, you will need to be able to provide people with superbills if they wish to submit OON for reimbursement.  Know this: Anyone who feels that you are their best option, and they decide that they want to pay for what they feel is the best option for them, has the right to do so

You will only be able to provide services for individuals who do not have Medicare, or become credentialed with Medicare. If people want to submit as OON, you will need to provide documentation for them to submit to their insurance

full_thread_text:
POST: I‚Äôve searched the group and am piecing info together, but would love some direct advice. I am a PT, but left hospital based outpatient care a few years back and am functioning now as a mobile personal trainer. I have my own LLC. Over the years, I have had many clients and gyms who have reached out to me asking to provide physical therapy services. I‚Äôve had to refer out or turn them down. Recently a gym offered me the option of leasing space from them, but in hopes I would be able to offer PT. I can figure out the logistics- I have the LLC. This would continue to be a cash based business. I would have the space to treat. Obviously consider costs of leasing. I already have liability insurance that covers me for PT and wellness. I would have a network for referrals. I can piece together the other legal aspects, forms, etc. But what other or big things am I not considering??

(And yes, I am interested in offering PT as part of my business. I have turned down enough opportunities over the years. This particular gym and owner align really with my business model.)

COMMENT 1: As Tom Conlon pointed out, you will need to check with both State and City to see if they require a "business license/permit".  This can vary state to state and city to city.  Yes, you will need to be able to provide people with superbills if they wish to submit OON for reimbursement.  Know this: Anyone who feels that you are their best option, and they decide that they want to pay for what they feel is the best option for them, has the right to do so

COMMENT 2: You will only be able to provide services for individuals who do not have Medicare, or become credentialed with Medicare. If people want to submit as OON, you will need to provide documentation for them to submit to their insurance

post_text: Hi everyone! I started my own business so that one day I can eventually do my own thing but ended up coming into contact with a solo practitioner whose values align with mine- I love what he is doing with his business. It‚Äôs an orthopedic practice, cash based. He hired me on as a contractor as he is in need for a therapist due to good growth! I started with him about 6 months ago but have been struggling to get patients onto my schedule. They know him as the face of the company and I understand it‚Äôll take time for people to know whÔøºo I am. I‚Äôve been doing injury screens and plan to run a workshop myself, as well as meeting more people in the community/networking. But can‚Äôt seem to get patients! And he keeps taking on new evals/has a waitlist. He‚Äôs told me to be patient but starting to wonder what I should be doing differently or if I need to take on PRN work until he can start to fill my schedule. I would love to market more but finding it hard as I‚Äôm not making much as is! And need to start contributing more to my finances with my family. Has anyone hired on their first PT as contract and had the same issue with filling schedule? Any advice is appreciated! Thank you!

comments.text:
I have so many questions. First of all, is he paying you to do marketing and workshops? If he hired you to help him, why is he continuing on put new patients on his personal waitlist and not on your schedule? That makes no sense. It‚Äôs his responsibility to get patients on your schedule otherwise what‚Äôs the point in him having you if he‚Äôs just going to keep making his wait list longer. Seems silly to me. 

Secondly, if you are putting in the time and effort to market and network, do workshops‚Ä¶just start your own business. That‚Äôs a lot of work to essentially be promoting someone else‚Äôs company‚Äîgo promote your business!

Had sort if this same problem at our clinic when we hired.  And the solutuon we used would require his help.  Try observing a patient of his. (I would volunteer this hour of your time)  get to know the patient and then co treat a little.  Then have follow ups scheduled with you.  What i do to this very day when i am trying to get a patient on another PT's schedule is to tell the patient that "jane doe" has avilability and can get you in right away. "She treats me" (which is 100% true)  that line works EVERY time.

post_text:
Would anyone here rent a room out of a private outpatient therapy clinic? You are responsible for getting your own patients, you have access to the front desk person (which you may get patients from as well), but ultimately you are responsible for your own people. Have access to the common area gym and have your own private office. 5 private offices total and you have one. Does that sound appealing? You have to do your own billing but you can utilize the front desk to call anyone if you are busy. And they base their monthly fee off a full schedule so when I did the math it‚Äôs taking roughly 30% of each person. (Figuring about $100 per session). Does that sound like a good deal? I‚Äôm a solo therapist but would be nice to have a space and not be committed to being on the lease and all that. 
What‚Äôs a good monthly amount to pay? It‚Äôs Florida

comments.text: Sounds like a lot of $. Access to equipment? Do you need front desk staff? Do they really work for you? Or, will you be an add on to their to do list? How would referrals work? If a person is referred to you and walks in the door will you be contacted or will that be countered as a general walk in client? Paying a flat for an office that is yours to use as you wish and when you wish would be better. Do not let someone make up your productivity level and take a percentage of each potential patient.

Maybe check out office suite rentals. I am in centra Florida and found one in an apartment building. I have access to their gym(it‚Äôs super big and nice) the pool and waiting area. $750 including electric and wi fi.  I‚Äôm OON so no billing. I do my own calls.

POST: Would anyone here rent a room out of a private outpatient therapy clinic? You are responsible for getting your own patients, you have access to the front desk person (which you may get patients from as well), but ultimately you are responsible for your own people. Have access to the common area gym and have your own private office. 5 private offices total and you have one. Does that sound appealing? You have to do your own billing but you can utilize the front desk to call anyone if you are busy. And they base their monthly fee off a full schedule so when I did the math it‚Äôs taking roughly 30% of each person. (Figuring about $100 per session). Does that sound like a good deal? I‚Äôm a solo therapist but would be nice to have a space and not be committed to being on the lease and all that. 
What‚Äôs a good monthly amount to pay? It‚Äôs Florida

COMMENT 1: Sounds like a lot of $. Access to equipment? Do you need front desk staff? Do they really work for you? Or, will you be an add on to their to do list? How would referrals work? If a person is referred to you and walks in the door will you be contacted or will that be countered as a general walk in client? Paying a flat for an office that is yours to use as you wish and when you wish would be better. Do not let someone make up your productivity level and take a percentage of each potential patient.

COMMENT 2: Maybe check out office suite rentals. I am in centra Florida and found one in an apartment building. I have access to their gym(it‚Äôs super big and nice) the pool and waiting area. $750 including electric and wi fi.  I‚Äôm OON so no billing. I do my own calls.

post_text: Can you explain the process of when a client comes to see you as a wellness client verses for traditional physical therapy services? Is the paperwork the same? What is the criteria for someone qualifying for wellness vs. PT, is billing different etc?

comments.text: Ditto to what Jessica said. A lot of our rehab patients end up continuing services with us as wellness clients to continue to work on strength training, health coaching, whatever they want. I've had wellness clients stay on 2-5x a wk for over a year after discharge from therapy. They love it and they often end up spreading the word about the business to their friends and family.

I have them sign a general waiver that also states that services are not PT or medical treatment (I had an attorney draft this up). There are no notes so paperwork is minimal. I do an intake similar to a trainer to see problem areas and know if there are any issues I need to be aware of. My billing is a flat price per visit and visits are as needed. Many clients are post PT or wanting to prevent issues etc 

Main differential is I‚Äôm NOT offering PT so not evaluating or diagnosing

How do you go about contacting patient‚Äôs PCP/MDs who come directly to you without a referral and need a POC/rerferral sent to continue care? Do you call their offices and speak with their front desk and ask them to fax you and BCBS a referral?   And when documenting, do you put their MD/surgeon as the ‚ÄòReferring provider‚Äô even though the patient came straight to you but assuming referral will be the surgeon?

comments.text: is this due to an HMO?  most of what your asking about isn't needed, depending on your state practice act.

Do the evaluation. Document Referral: Self via direct access/provider name you will be faxing to. (Assuming your state has at least partial DA) Send completed POC to MD office for signature within 30 days. All you need is a signed POC. You don‚Äôt need an order in addition to that.

post_text:
Hello! Looking to start my own practice within the next 5-6 months and have the option to rent a space at a local CrossFit gym. Curious what pros/cons you have experienced when having an office at a gym! I searched the group and didn‚Äôt find exactly what I was looking for. 

We discussed paying a lower monthly rent with an additional fee based on hourly gym equipment usage. Approximately 400 sq ft. 
Thanks!

comments.text: I‚Äôve built my entire business out of CrossFit gyms. Depends on the population you want to treat. My ideal client is a CrossFitter, so nobody has minded the music or noise. I‚Äôve had a lot non-CrossFit clients go on to join the gym afterwards even. I just pay hourly with a cap. Use of equipment is included. I‚Äôve never had an issue with CrossFit gyms not wanting their members to go to other gyms for rehab. I get sent people from most of the gyms in the area without any issue. They want their members healthy and back in class.

I know many people including myself that have started and grown very successful practices inside of CrossFit gyms. 

A sliding scale initially is a great idea if they are up to it. 

Basically assume the ‚Äúfull time‚Äù price and work backwards form there

If I was working here full time it would be this price then adjust for 30 hrs or 20 hrs or 10 hrs etc.

post_text: Hello, thank u for letting me join. Thinking of pursuing  pediatric mobile PT. Do u still have to maintain notes on prvt/ cash clients?

comments.text: Maintaining your own notes is important for your protection and to keep track of how you progress your clients.  Plus ,you never know if your client will need some type of surgery/medical tx down the road and the MD may request it.  I had a client fall on her icey back steps and she continued to come to see me, decided to follow up w/MD, had a MRI and decided to have surgery.  The MD AND  the insurance company requested all of her notes.  Be careful, CYA.
Yes, legally I would always maintain notes, for your protection.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hello, thank u for letting me join. Thinking of pursuing  pediatric mobile PT. Do u still have to maintain notes on prvt/ cash clients?

COMMENT 1: Maintaining your own notes is important for your protection and to keep track of how you progress your clients.  Plus ,you never know if your client will need some type of surgery/medical tx down the road and the MD may request it.  I had a client fall on her icey back steps and she continued to come to see me, decided to follow up w/MD, had a MRI and decided to have surgery.  The MD AND  the insurance company requested all of her notes.  Be careful, CYA.

COMMENT 2: Yes, legally I would always maintain notes, for your protection.

post_text: Mobile Therapists: How are you guys dealing with the anxiety of going to people‚Äôs homes? So I‚Äôve been doing home health for a while and haven‚Äôt had trouble with it, but the referral always comes from a hospital or physician, etc. As a private practice, if I get a direct access, private paying patient, anyone could call me with any motive. Has anyone had a safety issue?

comments.text:
I have been mobile for two years without issue. My practice is all word of mouth so there is always a connection to someone I know. 
Also just because someone is in the hospital being referred doesn‚Äôt always mean it‚Äôs safe. You still never know what you‚Äôre walking in to.

Search for past discussion on this. Word of mouth referrals kept me safe. I also screen everyone on the phone first, usually at least a 15 min phone call. If I‚Äôm going into a new situation, I‚Äôll put pepper spray in my pocket/bag. 

In home health some of our nurses carried tazers. 

There‚Äôs a great book called The Gift of Fear.

post_text: Love this!!  I‚Äôve been saying pretty much the same thing about the PT industry for years.

comments.text: Eh. You can grow your own food too, but‚Ä¶I‚Äôm all for anything that makes it easier for people to move. Indoors, outdoors, cheap, expensive. I don‚Äôt care. Just be healthier. I‚Äôll meet you where you‚Äôre at without all the judgement.

yes, its not always neccessary. AND this article is very ablelist. 
because not everyone can get down and do pushups. people who use wheelchairs can be super strong with machines and not be able to do much body weight wise. 
people with balance issues benefit from machines. 
cities have vastly changed since 20 years ago, not as much running space and capacity as there used tobe. not to mention that the streets arent neccesarily safe for women jogging outside. and black males running outside would be arrested much more often....
Yes, I am giving extreme examples just to point out that this isnt black and white. and that not thinking of psychosocial factors invoved with gyms and machines can be racist and misogynist.

and also gym culture can be good for the mental health as well. 

Story time: i went to the gym today (cuz im one of those that like the iron culture) and a women saw me doing super set of hamstring curl and pushups. yes i can do pushups at home but thats not as motivating. she says "impressive" and then said that she watched me do hip extension ex on the assisted chinup machine and she wanted to copy me. but then she said "i fractured my ankle really bad. like its destroyed. so im not sure if i will be able to do it well" . so the physio in me said, hmm, are you doing rehab. and thankfully she is. so i said ask your physio to go over step ups with you. its easier, its functional and you dont have to worry about the weight. 
so yes, she can do that at home. and doesnt need expensive machine.
but me doing it at home, wont cut it ;)

post_text: We have a lot of patients that just want us to continue to do manual with them after they feel better, but not come for full visit. Does anyone have a creative way to make this a wellness cash visit vs skilled PT? Our PTA is even offering to get massage license to help offer just massage, but trying to see if anyone has creative ideas on offering it as cash service with the licenses we currently have. Thanks!

comments.text: When my clients were "done," I offered up a Continuity Program where they came in 1x/month to make sure things were good and if anything else could have shown up.  I was in a CrossFit gym.  I offered this at a reduced price as long as they signed up for at least 6 mos and if they needed any additional therapy over that 1x/mo visit, I charged my regular fee.
If they really want a massage, then hire a massage therapist as an independent contractor, and refer those people to them. Cash basis, no referral needed.

full_thread_text:

COMMENT 1: When my clients were "done," I offered up a Continuity Program where they came in 1x/month to make sure things were good and if anything else could have shown up.  I was in a CrossFit gym.  I offered this at a reduced price as long as they signed up for at least 6 mos and if they needed any additional therapy over that 1x/mo visit, I charged my regular fee.

COMMENT 2: If they really want a massage, then hire a massage therapist as an independent contractor, and refer those people to them. Cash basis, no referral needed.

post_text:
Pt referred to PT with order 2-3x/wk x 12 wks‚Ä¶..

Pt discharged less than 4 wks ago after couple months tx with max potential reached‚Ä¶‚Ä¶

PT eval concludes no skilled tx needed as no functional decline noted . (obviously pt is upset about it as they think PT is personal trainer from insurance) 

Now,
Question 1: does this make physician upset as well? 
Question 2: did PT do anything wrong? 
Question 3: how would you explain this to the pt as physician order specified the frequency and duration already?

All input appreciated.

comments.text: PT determines frequency and duration, not the physician based on medical necessity. If the PT decides 1x/wk for 4 wks before DC or 3x/wk on 1st follower by 2x/wk on 2nd wk. It is up to the evaluating therapist. The physician will not protect you if insurance or Medicare determines that you are over utilizing or abuse of the services.

PT determines the frequency. It's their professional judgement and treatment plan. Writing frequency on a referral is old school. If the patient's goals are met, they are done. Good opportunity to educate the physician if they are upset about it. I would guess it's just built into their EMR and they don't even care how many visit happen as long as the patient is better.

post_text:
Hi! Apologize in advance for how simple this question may be...not very tech savvy. 

I‚Äôm trying to write an initial evaluation report in Word. Do I take my practice logo and add it to the header? Where should my contact information go then? I googled but I think I‚Äôm using the wrong terminology maybe? Google sent me down a rabbit hole. Looking for any resources to help me figure this out!

I use simple practice but like the idea of generating reports in word and uploading them that way. 

TIA for any guidance this group can provide!

comments.text: From a graphic design perspective, I would place your logo in the headed and your contact information along the bottom in the footer

if you have all relevant info and contact on the top (header) then your logo can be on the top or bottom;  whoever is reading it will be able to know who wrote this immediately; the signature can have your name typed and then signed and dated; the bottom edge can have more info or repeated (website, email, social media handles, etc). i also have tried to create a watermark of my logo so it shows up very lightly behind the type;

post_text: Need ideas for office phone.  I currently use Google Voice on my personal phone as my business line, but I want a separate phone for my admin to answer.  What are others using that is affordable?

comments.text:
I use google
Voice business account. My admin downloaded the voice app on her phone and were logged into the same account. When the phone rings, it rings on both our lines but during her work hours, she picks up. I like seeing the calls
Coming in. Texts and voicemails are accessible to us both.
Ring central. Voice over IP. I have it as an app on my personal phone. So they ring separately. I can silence my work number. I have a work line and fax line

full_thread_text:
POST: Need ideas for office phone.  I currently use Google Voice on my personal phone as my business line, but I want a separate phone for my admin to answer.  What are others using that is affordable?

COMMENT 1: I use google
Voice business account. My admin downloaded the voice app on her phone and were logged into the same account. When the phone rings, it rings on both our lines but during her work hours, she picks up. I like seeing the calls
Coming in. Texts and voicemails are accessible to us both.

COMMENT 2: Ring central. Voice over IP. I have it as an app on my personal phone. So they ring separately. I can silence my work number. I have a work line and fax line

post_text:
Not sure of the best place to ask this, but lets start here! I'm working on starting my own business MADE NEW Physical Therapy and Wellness, but found out I'm pregnant with TWINS. This has delayed my capacity to work on the business as I am still full time at my current op Ortho job and DEAD by the end of the day. 

Wondering if there are any virtual positions I could apply for to give me time with the twins at home and some flexibility to continue seeing my Made New patients. Not really looking for a clinical reviewer position which I know are out there.

Thanks!

comments.text:
I‚Äôm due in august and plan to explore virtual services as I gradually return to work.  I wish I had started virtual sooner as being pregnant has made it a little harder to market and grow my in-person business, I‚Äôve basically only been treating maintenance clients the past month üò¨ 
I think virtual and in-person will be a good blend when I return

Depending on your financial and healthcare benefits needs through this period, you could grow your biz with virtual services. If you plan to accept insurance in the future or need to develop billing, marketing, sales, or admin skills in order to learn and train your future staff, you could accept a VA position with another PT clinic in addition. Pay will be less per hour but you‚Äôll be ready to rock and roll with those skills for your own biz when you are ready to start accepting more volume and see clients in person.

post_text:
Hi there guys. I was hoping you could give me some guidance here. 
So my current business plan is mobile PT for Medicare and cash with a niche in Geriatrics and eventually with fitness athletes. My cash rate would be $175/visit. 

However, I have a friend engaged to a dentist, and the dentist knows a concierge doctor, an internist, in a very affluent area about an hour away from me. 
It sounds like that concierge doctor would be interested in having a mobile PT for some of his patients. 

So, if this opportunity becomes a reality, I would be driving an hour to see some pretty wealthy people. I'm told that this doctor charges $150k a year just to be your doctor, labs and tests cost extra. 

I have not talked to the doctor yet about this, but I met him briefly several months ago at a birthday party. The dentist texted him last night to see if he would be interested and the doc responded "sure."

How would you approach this? What questions would you have?  Would you charge a higher rate (obviously would need to just for the commute)?  Would you offer a true "concierge" service where they pay monthly or yearly for say 1 or 2 visits a week, or just take referrals as they come for a specific plan of care? 

Any thoughts would be greatly appreciated. 
Thanks!

comments.text: I would hire a therapist in that area as I don't want to drive 2 hrs round trip

I would not want to go Concierge for a fee and be obligated to them for service. Life happens and if for some reason you can't continue treatment then what? Also do you have special skills for TMJ or anything of that nature that the dentist would find advantageous to his practice? Have you studied and trained in cranial sacral therapy?

post_text:
Non-compete question! 

I‚Äôm looking at working PRN at a home health company while I work toward becoming independent with my mobile services - the non compete they want me to sign is making me question doing this! Both of our services are in the home and I was hoping to have clients from HH transition to my cash services when HH services were completed if able, but it states I can‚Äôt see past, current, or future clients from 9 months from my termination‚Ä¶help!

comments.text: So let me make a distinction. There is a difference between opening your own practice (non compete), and taking their company‚Äôs resources (non solicitation). They can absolutely come after you for solicitation of their clients while an employee of their company. Clients are the $$ of a company. Each valued at approximately $150 per referral in marketing costs. Taking clients would be considered stealing proprietary information and they could win a monetary amount for whatever their ROI is for that client.

I would double check with them on this. Because it could be a win-win. You could refer patients to your company after Home health once they have been discharged. And it's two separate services home health and outpatient, which don't necessarily compete with each other.

COMMENT 1: So let me make a distinction. There is a difference between opening your own practice (non compete), and taking their company‚Äôs resources (non solicitation). They can absolutely come after you for solicitation of their clients while an employee of their company. Clients are the $$ of a company. Each valued at approximately $150 per referral in marketing costs. Taking clients would be considered stealing proprietary information and they could win a monetary amount for whatever their ROI is for that client.

COMMENT 2: I would double check with them on this. Because it could be a win-win. You could refer patients to your company after Home health once they have been discharged. And it's two separate services home health and outpatient, which don't necessarily compete with each other.

post_text:
Hey everyone! Quick question- if I am a direct access state and cash pay business ( accepting no insurance) do I need a doctors signature on a super bill for the dx code? 

Total newbie here and deciding whether or not to take the plunge in providing patients with a super bill! 

Thanks All!

comments.text:
No, superbills aren't related to direct access. They are simply a statement provided to the patient to be potentially reimbursed by insurance or to have it potentially count towards their deductible. 

Direct access based upon your state dictates if and how long you can see the patient before a referral/prescription for therapy is needed. 

I hope this helps! 

And congrats & good luck üòÄ

check your state licensure laws.  if u are providing skilled services, it doesnt matter to your state board if u r cash or accept ins.    u still need to follow the law.  unskilled is a different story.

post_text:
Cash-pay clinicians practicing in states with restricted direct access- how do you overcome the barrier of a referral being required to work with patients? Do you do wellness sessions? Do you require patients to get a PT prescription in order to work with you? 

I've gotten mixed replies to this - do you even need a prescription if you're cash pay? 

I have not been practicing long enough to have a direct access license and am hoping to start a cash pay side gig in PA. Any advice is appreciated! Thank you!

comments.text:
Always refer to your state practice act‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt know PA but insurance alone wouldn‚Äôt be a reason to determine allowance for direct access. It is always tied back to the practice act‚Ä¶ 

The only time insurance plays a part is if they require a referral for coverage (or signed plan of care-Medicare).

If I can‚Äôt get a referral from the patient‚Äôs PCP, I used a telehealth platform where I know I can get one.
Direct access should only matter if you're working with insurance. Is your only accepting cash who cares if they have a referral...?

post_text:
HELP! I need some advice! I‚Äôm currently in a crossfit gym and they are most likely going to close down. I have the opportunity to move in a 2000 sq foot office however cost for that space ranges from 2600-2750 per month. In my area, 2000 sq ft goes for 4K a month. I had a great month of March but things have been slowing down the last two months. I don‚Äôt know if I should take the leap and get the space. 

I did get an offer from another crossfit gym in another town to lease out 850 sq ft for $800. However, that is only making a lateral move not a progressive one. 

Curious if anyone would take the leap despite things being slow or going for a cheaper and safer bet and moving into another crossfit gym in another town??

Any advice would be appreciated. üôèüèªüôèüèª

comments.text: How does the 2000‚Äô space fit into your long term plan? Do you plan to hire and grow? How many therapists/ visits per month could that space accommodate and does that align with your goals?

This is my perspective coming as someone who does CrossFit and is a fan of it. 

CrossFit seems somewhat shaky as leadership continues to change and they don‚Äôt provide adequate or the best support to affiliate owners (this may be localized to where I‚Äôm located, but I see it a lot on comments on their online platforms as well). More gyms are starting to close. 

Taking that into consideration, you really need to evaluate the new CrossFit gym you are looking at if that‚Äôs really the move you want. How are they marketing? Are they attracting the clientele you want to treat? How many new members are joining on average monthly? All of that considering if you are trying to use them as a referral source.

post_text:
Seeking advice on what to wear as a female, mobile PT.

I am a mobile PT.  I wear a logo'd t-shirt, jogger (poly/spandex blend / not sweat) pants, and clean/nice tennis shoes when I see clients and when I go to networking events.  I feel like it is my "uniform."  My husband thinks I look unprofessional.  He thinks I should wear a polo shirt (or a button up shirt) --especially for networking events and definitely if I meet a doctor.  I hate polo shirts.  I don't want to wear polo shirts and khakis.  I think they look/feel corporate.  I do not feel like that is me.  I, personally, feel stuffy in them.  I don't want to be stuffy.  I want to feel like me.  He thinks a stranger deciding between a PT wearing a polo shirt ("professional") or me wearing my logo'd t-shirt and jogger pants ("sloppy"), the stranger would go with the polo shirt PT because of 1st impressions. I said that is a stupid reason to choose a PT, but he says people think like that.  

I don't have much of a caseload right now, which I don't think is because of my clothes.  I think it's because it is hard to build a mobile practice when you don't have a head start of referral sources or prior patients to seek you out.  He thinks I need to wear a polo so people take me more seriously.  We, seriously, have had multiple arguments about this.  (Btw, he works in the civil engineering world where sometimes he meets public figures - I told him our work worlds are different, but he still disagrees.)   

What do you think?  Do I need to suck it up and get some freaking polo shirts?  I am especially interested in hearing what other female, mobile PTs wear to patient (older adults) homes and to networking events/meetings with doctors.  Thanks, in advance, for being a neutral 3rd party, lol.

comments.text: If I‚Äôm going to someone‚Äôs home odds are I‚Äôm doing heavy transfers or dealing with catheter bags, etc so I wear scrubs. If I‚Äôm seeing patients in my space it leggings with pockets ( athleta makes thick nice ones that give great compression) with a professional top and flats. I definitely have gone to talk to doctors in this outfit too.
Know your audience.....

I feel like it is my "uniform."  My husband thinks I look unprofessional.  He thinks I should wear a polo shirt (or a button up shirt) --especially for networking events and definitely if I meet a doctor.  I hate polo shirts.  I don't want to wear polo shirts and khakis.  I think they look/feel corporate.  I do not feel like that is me.  I, personally, feel stuffy in them.  I don't want to be stuffy.  I want to feel like me.  He thinks a stranger deciding between a PT wearing a polo shirt ("professional") or me wearing my logo'd t-shirt and jogger pants ("sloppy"), the stranger would go with the polo shirt PT because of 1st impressions. I said that is a stupid reason to choose a PT, but he says people think like that.  

I don't have much of a caseload right now, which I don't think is because of my clothes.  I think it's because it is hard to build a mobile practice when you don't have a head start of referral sources or prior patients to seek you out.  He thinks I need to wear a polo so people take me more seriously.  We, seriously, have had multiple arguments about this.  (Btw, he works in the civil engineering world where sometimes he meets public figures - I told him our work worlds are different, but he still disagrees.)   

What do you think?  Do I need to suck it up and get some freaking polo shirts?  I am especially interested in hearing what other female, mobile PTs wear to patient (older adults) homes and to networking events/meetings with doctors.  Thanks, in advance, for being a neutral 3rd party, lol.

post_text: For mobile therapists, are we allowed to see Medicare B pts in their ALF?  Or is there a rule by Medicare that they only be seen by inhouse therapists?  Thank you!

comments.text: People have the right to choose their providers. That is their home- I would argue that they can have anyone come to their home to provide therapy. I haven't gotten clients yet, but I've had 2 marketing people from ALFs admit that to me.  Now they may not want to promote you since it conflicts with their in house therapists.
YES you can see clients in an ALF even if there are onsite  providers. It is the persons home and they can choose who they want for a provider.

I had a referring provider ask me for my encrypted email address in order to send referrals (since I don't have a fax number - never got one since most of my patients come direct access, very few MD referrals). Does anyone know whether Google business with BAA is enough HIPAA protection for receiving referrals, or there is another layer of encryption that can be set up?

comments.text: I thought that was sufficient enough and never had anyone question it‚Ä¶ regardless if you want a cheap fax service you could use faxage ($7/month) if some providers you use are being a little extra cautious
I use paubox with my gmail it will encrypt your emails and is hippa compliant. Srfax is a cheap fax service as well

post_text: I‚Äôm getting things ready to start my own practice. What should I use to build a website? I would like the ability to purchase sessions online since I do virtual sessions as well as in person and might make courses and such. I‚Äôm hoping to do this myself. I was thinking Wordpress‚Ä¶ thoughts?

comments.text:
I‚Äôve literally used them all and have feedback here but‚Ä¶ 

If you‚Äôre just starting, trust me, this is not your first step or where you want to put alll your attention. I did that and it was a mistake. 

Just create a simple landing page on any landing page biulder with a booking form for clients to work with you and focus on other things, you will have a beautiful website in the future üôÇ 

I personally settled on Kajabi but wouldn‚Äôt recommend it for most people. 

I‚Äôd use something like GoHighLevel (all inclusive with your email) or a simple platform with just landing pages like Wix. 

Honestly you can start with just a Convert Kit opt in landing page that says ‚Äúcoming soon contact me here‚Äù and call it a day for now. 

WordPress is not simple, if you‚Äôre set on it or have some tech background, use the thrive themes plug ins. That wasent super challenging at all and you can grow with the plug in options over time. 

Yes, it‚Äôs the best because it‚Äôs yours when you biuld it. But becoming a website designer is just not a great use of time.

I really like GoDaddy and it's easy to use. I linked it to my Hushmail account pretty easily. I partner with a massage therapist who uses AcuitySchedule through their website to schedule and take payments.

full_thread_text:
POST: I‚Äôm getting things ready to start my own practice. What should I use to build a website? I would like the ability to purchase sessions online since I do virtual sessions as well as in person and might make courses and such. I‚Äôm hoping to do this myself. I was thinking Wordpress‚Ä¶ thoughts?

COMMENT 1: I‚Äôve literally used them all and have feedback here but‚Ä¶ 

If you‚Äôre just starting, trust me, this is not your first step or where you want to put alll your attention. I did that and it was a mistake. 

Just create a simple landing page on any landing page biulder with a booking form for clients to work with you and focus on other things, you will have a beautiful website in the future üôÇ 

I personally settled on Kajabi but wouldn‚Äôt recommend it for most people. 

I‚Äôd use something like GoHighLevel (all inclusive with your email) or a simple platform with just landing pages like Wix. 

Honestly you can start with just a Convert Kit opt in landing page that says ‚Äúcoming soon contact me here‚Äù and call it a day for now. 

WordPress is not simple, if you‚Äôre set on it or have some tech background, use the thrive themes plug ins. That wasent super challenging at all and you can grow with the plug in options over time. 

Yes, it‚Äôs the best because it‚Äôs yours when you biuld it. But becoming a website designer is just not a great use of time.

COMMENT 2: I really like GoDaddy and it's easy to use. I linked it to my Hushmail account pretty easily. I partner with a massage therapist who uses AcuitySchedule through their website to schedule and take payments.

post_text:
"$500k/year" 

That's what someone just told me they had sitting there unbilled or clients that are being turned away because they can't find qualified therapists.  

First- it's amazing what our clients are accomplishing in their practices that this is what's waiting in referrals and being turned away. 

But more importantly than that, it gave me an opportunity to talk about something I've been noticing a lot recently. 

Many people and potential clients of Uncaged only want to talk about how to grow a business and how to make $$$$ in a practice. They LOVE talking about the ENGINE of a business but very rarely talk about the BRAKES of a business. 

Are brakes sexy? no. It's way cooler to talk about how many horsepower a car has 

But one of the quickest way to derail your practice/business is to sacrifice the quality of care, delivery, and boundaries. 

Don't build a business that is all horsepower and no stopping power.

comments.text: Amen! I‚Äôve found my business really flourishes when I say no to the opportunities that don‚Äôt feel right but have $$$ potential and yes to the opportunities that resonate with how I want to practice as a clinician. Takes guts and faith to trust the process.

Turning business away is hard. Often we hold on to it too closely and when we tell people "no" we feel that we're letting them down. 

I still have to untangle from this in a non-clinical role... and I was REALLY wound up in it while working clinically. (Mostly because if I said no, they had to drive for hours to find another OT... which sucks.) 

But you're SO RIGHT that when we focus on our areas of strength and pass on the opportunities that are outside of our zone -- we do more good and impact more lives in the long run. 

I've been leaning into this more this year and every time I say "I need to pass this project to someone else" I cringe, but it allows me to stay in my zone and find the best fit clients. üôÇ

post_text:
I am an OT and I am interested in starting a cash-based wellness business for adults (mostly 50+ based on demographics where I am). Not interested in dealing with insurance at all - so strictly focusing on wellness. Several years ago I had my own, small private mobile OT business and I am having trouble shifting my mindset! ü§Ø

üí° Would love to hear about other wellness based businesses - what services/programs do you offer? 
üìö How do you highlight your OT/PT skills and knowledge while clearly indicating that you are not providing that skilled therapy? 

Example I encountered just in conversation about starting to see clients privately -  someone who is about 3 months post-stroke w lingering hemiparesis, living home independently.   This person would certainly benefit from skilled services  (postural alignment, quality of movement, strength)- how to you draw the line and what would make your services ‚Äúwellness‚Äù vs OT/PT. 
‚Ä¶ I can 100% agree with an argument that a very knowledgeable personal trainer could provide appropriate exercise for this patient. BUT - as a licensed OT, would I be crossing a line?

comments.text:
This is basically what my business is. I‚Äôm a PT, and my take on wellness is a) if someone could learn what I‚Äôm teaching in a weekend, it‚Äôs not skilled and therefore not PT, and b) if there‚Äôs no specific diagnosis that I‚Äôm working on it‚Äôs not PT. 

I like to say I‚Äôm doing personal training with a PTs eyes.

Think of recreation vs necessity. Medicare doesn't care if people can golf, play pickleball, etc for example. They want function: just get to the toilet, don't fall, etc. Your client wants to do more than basic function, so make it clear that in your practice that= wellness. Also clearly state on your website that you do not take insurance and that your "wellness" work is  to make the enjoyment of life better. Hope that helps. I struggled here too, but now am good with thinking wellness is anything over basic function. Good luck in the new practice.

post_text: Question re: Part A services. If a client is getting Part A for PT, does that prohibit Part B for OT? My understanding is yes because the PT is claiming that the client is home-bound to require these services. Is this correct?

comments.text: You are correct.

The patient has to be completely discharged from all part A services in order to begin part B. This includes wound care and any other medical or home health aide. And I would even wait another 24 hours after the date on the discharge in order to resume services through part B. Don‚Äôt overlap!Ôøº

full_thread_text:
POST: Question re: Part A services. If a client is getting Part A for PT, does that prohibit Part B for OT? My understanding is yes because the PT is claiming that the client is home-bound to require these services. Is this correct?

COMMENT 1: You are correct.

COMMENT 2: The patient has to be completely discharged from all part A services in order to begin part B. This includes wound care and any other medical or home health aide. And I would even wait another 24 hours after the date on the discharge in order to resume services through part B. Don‚Äôt overlap!Ôøº

post_text:
Hey everyone!  3 questions

I am starting my own ortho/sport practice and partnering with a small gym/training center that tailors to golfers. I will be working more into that community but, I'd like to bring in outside sources too because it's fun to switch up what you treat üôÇ

-Starting out, what were your most productive forms of generating leads?

-For those who did tabling events/ortho screens what marketing materials and pt equipment did you bring to your setup? 

-For reaching out to MDs for referrals, what have you found is the best approach? 

Thank you all for any advice! Its a scary but fun time starting out

comments.text:
Just remember when you‚Äôre starting out the easiest way to generate leads is doing a great job with each client and ‚Äúword of mouth‚Äù spreads! With each proof of concept client in the early part of your practice, your confidence grows and so do your referrals. üòâ 

I‚Äôm 7 years in and still haven‚Äôt looked back. It‚Äôs hard work, but very rewarding.

Hi Lindsey‚Äì Congrats on starting! We started a running-focussed practice in the past.

What worked pretty well is becoming part of several niche athletic communities, schools and providing value there sporadically (advice, prevention, etc)‚Äì For example offer free injury screens at events or training sessions. 

And also listing on Google maps with a physical location! That's where people look for  when they are looking for a PT. They Google 'Physical Therapy in XYZ', or 'PT Near Me'.

post_text: I need some real sound business advice. I treat patients at a gym that I partner with. This gym will have summer camp soon and will host 300-400 students during the summer. They have a trainer that does agility, strength, speed, etc with them. I need some ideas that I can market to these middle school and high school students that will bring some serious value. Any ideas?

comments.text: Reflex performance reset. It‚Äôs mind blowing and totally suited for athletes.

Agility, strength, speed are unfortunately the big things these athletes need to be worrying about. Max lifts, 40 speed, triple hop distance, long jump, vertical, cone drill, etc. Maybe find some objective test like those that the personal trainer isn‚Äôt doing and fill in the gaps. Or perhaps focus on mobility. Most high level athletes tend to have at least above average mobility.

full_thread_text:
POST: I need some real sound business advice. I treat patients at a gym that I partner with. This gym will have summer camp soon and will host 300-400 students during the summer. They have a trainer that does agility, strength, speed, etc with them. I need some ideas that I can market to these middle school and high school students that will bring some serious value. Any ideas?

COMMENT 1: Reflex performance reset. It‚Äôs mind blowing and totally suited for athletes.

COMMENT 2: Agility, strength, speed are unfortunately the big things these athletes need to be worrying about. Max lifts, 40 speed, triple hop distance, long jump, vertical, cone drill, etc. Maybe find some objective test like those that the personal trainer isn‚Äôt doing and fill in the gaps. Or perhaps focus on mobility. Most high level athletes tend to have at least above average mobility.

post_text:
Looking for opinions: 

I have been treating a patient post MVA. The daughter of the patient was unfortunately recently involved in a separate car accident. The daughter wanted an ortho recommendation, so I provided the name of a local ortho who I met with a few months back in hopes of starting a referral relationship. After her initial visit, they put the patient in touch with a chiropractor. Feeling a bit slighted here and want to reach out to them but want to respect their clinical judgement.

Thoughts????

comments.text:
100% follow up with patient and follow up with ortho. Would tell them how you referred said patient over and that this is not how you would like a biz relationship to be. I would hands down ask them if they have any patients that may be a good fit for your practice

Also you might get patient back. This happened to me one time

What Joey said plus,do you have a referral process in place? Did you send to doc with a written referral from you? Call to let them know to look out for a patient you had referred? Call and set up the appointment from your office? Educated the patient that you would like them to return to you once seen by the doc? Scheduled the patient on your books and sent over the initial POC for signature if necessary and appropriate?  If not, you may want to formalize this process. Educate your patients so that they become your advocate. You want patients telling their doc that you sent them there and they want to go back to you when it's time for rehab.

Scheduled the patient on your books and sent over the initial POC for signature if necessary and appropriate?  If not, you may want to formalize this process. post_text: When you guys started out on your own side gigs, did you have your own website?  How did you avoid alerting attention to your current employer?

comments.text: got my website 2 full years after starting to see patients privately in their homes and making my PLLC. i didn't do or say anything to my employers. maybe it's less of an issue because the hospitals i work at are quite a distance away from where i live/see private patients ü§∑üèº i feel like little ol me coming to your house to give you PT for cash is a totally different thing than hospital based outpatient PT that accepts all kinds of insurance, medicaid, etc. it's not really a competition.

Nope no website. It was word of mouth. And my employer back then knew I was doing home visits, I was not able to solicit my services when I was working for their clinic.

But check with the contract you signed because some times there‚Äôs a ridiculous non-compete clause.

post_text:
Hi all.  I'm doing my first vendor event in late April.  It is a street festival, and most of the vendors will be selling food or crafts.

I am a sports/ortho PT (cash-based, no Medicare) and would like to focus on the role of PT in wellness and injury prevention.  My first thought had been to do an injury risk screen, similar to one that I offer once a month at my practice.  I use a self screen, but with the space I have for the event 10x10) can probably only do 2 at a time.

So questions to those who have done outdoor vendor events:

1. What ideas have you used that worked well in getting people to stop at your tent/table?

2. What ideas do you have to turn these leads into clients, preferably ways to collect emails or phone numbers for marketing?  Some thoughts I had were ebook sign-ups, raffle for free session.

3. Is it worth it to have giveaway items, and if so, what did you use?

Thanks in advance.

comments.text: I have events planned for late fall; a 5k and a gravel bike ride.  I plan on doing IASTM and cupping on a portable treatment table while advertising running analysis and bike fitting.  I might try to hand out some chocolate milk for the runners.
what about giving away 15-minute personal screens for people to come see you. Usually a screen will land you some patients. And, if they don't take advantage of it, it didn't really cost you much.

post_text:
Post approved by @David Bayliff 

Hope this inspires all of you to promote your business and your work in the world and stop playing small. 

Be brave and allow your amazing self to BE SEEN! ‚ù§Ô∏è

Story time: ü§ì

I was looking to grow my social media followers for my physical therapy business. 

So I decided to send a message to all my friends and relatives asking them to follow my account and share with their circle to follow it. 

I was transparent about wanting more followers. (Because authenticity and transparency are my core values. We all live by our core values. Most people just have no awareness of what their core values are.) 

I woke up to more than 30 new followers from across the world (USA, India, Canada, UK, Africa etc) in less than 24 hours. 

And I know the list of followers is going to grow because my business information has been passed on so many times by my loved ones and well wishers. 

I was surprised (shocked actually üò±) to see who all didn‚Äôt follow me until now including my immediate family members and a few extremely close friends who I assumed were following me. üòÉü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è The moral of the story: ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è

Be Brave. 

You have to ask for what you want.

You have to ask for what you need. 

Don‚Äôt assume people will know what to do just because they love you or are family. 

You have to be clear on your expectations and communicate them clearly. 

You can‚Äôt get upset with people for not reading your mind. 

You have to get out of your own way. 

Stop overthinking and just go get what you need. 

People are more open and understanding than you give them credit for. 

Stop allowing your biases to limit your growth. 

Much love,
Tulsi ‚ù§Ô∏è 

PS: 

If you have been thinking about working with me one day, don‚Äôt sit on the fence forever overthinking everything. Send me a message üì±and let‚Äôs get the conversation started. 

I will be honest and transparent in my suggestions for you. 

PSS: 

I am asking all of you to follow my business pages as well. (Why not? üòâ) 

Here are the links: 

Active Body Active Life

Tulsi Desai

https://instagram.com/activebodyactivelife?igshid=YmMyMTA2M2Y=

https://instagram.com/tulsidesai1?igshid=YmMyMTA2M2Y= 

https://www.tiktok.com/@tulsides1?_t=8aVGshnlrhr&_r=1

I will greatly appreciate your like and follow üëç to all of the above accounts. 

And please share with your loved ones. I promise to share fun, valuable and beneficial information for all my followers. ü§ó‚ù§Ô∏è

comments.text:

This is how to go about growing an audience.  
It‚Äôs exactly how (The Mobile PT LEAGUE, now UNCAGED CLINICIAN) was grown. 
This will serve (you) much better than spamming people.

post_text: For those who are mobile, can you treat Medicare patient at a different location (e.g. a gym) but still bill code 12 - Home?

comments.text: This is an ongoing topic but to me 11 is office.... This mobile . 12 is home... Thus for home health PT ( not mobile). I have only  billed 11 and see clients where ever they want

12 is for mobile outpatient providers. 11 is for your office registered with your MAC. Medicare doesn't cover therapy provided in community settings like a library or gym but if you have a lease with the gym and it's your office you'd use 11. If you see clients in their home at an ALF it's still 12.

full_thread_text:
POST: For those who are mobile, can you treat Medicare patient at a different location (e.g. a gym) but still bill code 12 - Home?

COMMENT 1: This is an ongoing topic but to me 11 is office.... This mobile . 12 is home... Thus for home health PT ( not mobile). I have only  billed 11 and see clients where ever they want

COMMENT 2: 12 is for mobile outpatient providers. 11 is for your office registered with your MAC. Medicare doesn't cover therapy provided in community settings like a library or gym but if you have a lease with the gym and it's your office you'd use 11. If you see clients in their home at an ALF it's still 12.

post_text:
Big question for ones who are practice with a gym and is hybrid:

A new gym opened, offering a PT room to solely just one PT.  They‚Äôre charging a rate of $2,000/mo and do not take any percentages and have only on PT on site for the gym.

Still being a new practice and currently mobile, the gym itself is an ideal set-up, but I‚Äôm still trying to build clientele. I believe the gym is 18,000sq ft and trainers would refer their clients to me. 

I‚Äôm just anxious of having that big of a monthly payment with low clientele. Wanting to build it up first. 

Thoughts?

comments.text: I have this exact set up. But in my opinion $2000 is way too high. I would try to negotiate a lesser amount. $1200 max. Or try to negotiate a cost per visit so the gym is incentivized to send you clients.

Maybe explain your concerns and negotiate an ‚Äúon ramp‚Äù period where you might pay like $1000 the 1st month, then $1500 the 2nd month, then the full amount to give your time to build up your clientele and income?

Thoughts?

COMMENT 2: Maybe explain your concerns and negotiate an ‚Äúon ramp‚Äù period where you might pay like $1000 the 1st month, then $1500 the 2nd month, then the full amount to give your time to build up your clientele and income?

post_text: How are you getting your referrals? Marketing ideas? i‚Äôve gone to different Primary MDs, Home Health agencies? Maybe i‚Äôm missing something because we‚Äôre struggling with getting referrals. I have a hybrid business model offering PT and OT with specialty for wound care and lymphedema. We take cash, Medicare, and BCBS. Located in Chicago.

comments.text: Think outside your typical referral sources. Go straight to the consumers. Offer free workshops with support groups, libraries, gyms, etc. Teach basic anatomy and give them a taste of why they would want to work with you. Just ask for name and email to start your own distribution list.

I tried marketing to the same for awhile my 1st year in practice and got no where. But keep at it. Within the last 6 months I've had 2 doctors start referring to me regularly. It helped that the patients I saw from them gave me raving reviews during their followups, so they started sending more to me. My business coach also says it takes 12+ 'touches' to make someone interested and purchase from you, so just have to keep consistent with it. Most of my referrals come from word of mouth, previous patients, friends and family. Just starting to get some more from Google and my website.

full_thread_text:
POST: How are you getting your referrals? Marketing ideas? i‚Äôve gone to different Primary MDs, Home Health agencies? Maybe i‚Äôm missing something because we‚Äôre struggling with getting referrals. I have a hybrid business model offering PT and OT with specialty for wound care and lymphedema. We take cash, Medicare, and BCBS. Located in Chicago.

COMMENT 1: Think outside your typical referral sources. Go straight to the consumers. Offer free workshops with support groups, libraries, gyms, etc. Teach basic anatomy and give them a taste of why they would want to work with you. Just ask for name and email to start your own distribution list.

COMMENT 2: I tried marketing to the same for awhile my 1st year in practice and got no where. But keep at it. Within the last 6 months I've had 2 doctors start referring to me regularly. It helped that the patients I saw from them gave me raving reviews during their followups, so they started sending more to me. My business coach also says it takes 12+ 'touches' to make someone interested and purchase from you, so just have to keep consistent with it. Most of my referrals come from word of mouth, previous patients, friends and family. Just starting to get some more from Google and my website.

post_text:
Just for fun I thought I'd ask ChatGPT to come up with a sales pitch and a marketing plan for cash services. These are the results I got:

"Invest in your health today and experience the benefits of physical therapy with cash payment. By paying with cash, you save time and money as there's no need to go through insurance claim processes. This means you can get started on your physical therapy journey right away without any delays. Moreover, cash payment gives you more control over your physical therapy sessions as you can choose the frequency and length of each session. So, why wait? Invest in your well-being and make the most of your physical therapy experience by paying with cash."

Marketing Plan for Cash-Pay Physical Therapy Services

Target Market: Our target market is individuals who are seeking physical therapy services and have the financial resources to pay out of pocket. This could include individuals who do not have insurance, have high deductibles or out of pocket maximums, or do not want to go through the hassle of insurance claim submissions and pre-authorizations.

Unique Selling Proposition: Our unique selling proposition is that by paying cash, clients will have access to more personalized and comprehensive physical therapy services without the restrictions and limitations imposed by insurance. This includes a personalized treatment plan, longer appointment times, and a more hands-on approach to treatment.

Marketing Channel: Our marketing channels will include social media platforms, email marketing, and direct mail. We will also reach out to local gyms and fitness studios to build partnerships and offer promotions for their members.

Social Media Marketing: We will utilize social media platforms such as Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter to reach our target market and showcase our physical therapy services. We will post informative articles and videos about physical therapy, share testimonials from satisfied clients, and offer promotions for cash-pay services.

Email Marketing: We will create an email marketing campaign to reach out to past and current clients who have expressed interest in our physical therapy services. The email will highlight the benefits of cash-pay services, including personalized treatment plans, longer appointment times, and a more hands-on approach to treatment.

Direct Mail: We will create a direct mail campaign that targets individuals who live in the area and have recently been diagnosed with a condition that would benefit from physical therapy. The direct mail will highlight the benefits of cash-pay services and offer a special promotion for new clients.

Partnership with Local Gyms and Fitness Studios: We will reach out to local gyms and fitness studios to build partnerships and offer promotions for their members. We will provide informational flyers and posters to be displayed in the gym or studio, and offer a discount on cash-pay services for members who sign up.

Promotion: We will offer a special promotion for new clients who choose cash-pay services. This could include a discount on their first appointment or a complimentary consultation.

Measuring Success: We will measure the success of our marketing plan by tracking the number of new cash-pay clients, the growth of our email marketing list, and the number of social media followers. We will also track the success of our partnerships with local gyms and fitness studios by tracking the number of members who take advantage of our promotions.

Adjustments: Based on the results of our marketing plan, we will make adjustments as needed to ensure the success of our cash-pay physical therapy services. This could include adjusting our marketing channels, refining our promotions, or expanding our partnerships with local gyms and fitness studios.

Can we talk social media?  Have you found social media presence to be a big boost to your business, and if so, which platform has worked best for you?

I'm toying with the idea of really increasing my presence on Instagram. Honestly I love the platform so it would be more for fun, with minimal expectation, more as a hobby, and to learn.   But I know it's a time consuming venture so was curious if over time you had true benefits to your business doing this?  Or did you find it to be a total time suck?

comments.text: This is such a great conversation because I recently hired a virtual assistant/marketing firm to help me grow (and serve) my presence on social media. ÔøºAt the end of the day it‚Äôs the last thing I gave energy to do. We see geriatrics, PD, vestibular a post op primarily. It‚Äôs been helpful for clients and their families two see us in action and get a little bit of community. ÔøºWe‚Äôve had no direct client growth but have ‚Äúsecured‚Äù clients as they reported ‚Äúwe saw your legit.‚Äù üòä

I think it would depend on your demographic. My patients are mostly older and I get most referrals from word of mouth and home care therapists. The only patients I received from social media were family members of friends who saw I had started a business. If you are treating younger people I would think it might be helpful. Personally I prefer making connections in real life especially being mobile and going into peoples homes.

post_text:
What are ways have you partnered your mobile PT practice with local gyms ? 

I‚Äôm meeting w an owner and practicing my sales pitch. I want to find his pain points and see how I can fit in. How can I add value by improving their customer retention and new client conversion ? Ultimately another goal is get my practice name into the community so I can get more word of mouth referrals. 

Unfortunately I am not comfortable marketing myself on social media, I‚Äôm better w one to one promotion. 

My ideas:
‚Äî Offering onsite 15 min PT screens to existing clients
‚ÄîOffer post or pre work out manual work and stretching
‚Äî Give individual HEPs to their clients who have a history of injury, and have been discharged from PT
‚ÄîDesign different combinations of post workout stretches that could pair up with their small group training programming. 

Say he agrees, and I do these things‚Äî how can I measure if my services are helping his bottom line and to prove my worth ? How do I come up with a fair value to be paid for the time I‚Äôm spending doing these things? 

Or what other ideas do you have üí° Do I offer discounts on my mobile PT services to their clients ? Do I just ask them to refer injured clients to me? 

TIA. Pls ask any questions for clarification. I love the expertise of this group and I‚Äôm admittedly all over-the- place.

comments.text: My practice is inside a performance gym and it‚Äôs wayyyyy simpler to just pay rent. If you‚Äôre friendly with the coaches and owners, they‚Äôll refer you people naturally so I definitely wouldn‚Äôt mix their bottom line and yours.

You should pay monthly rent and not give them any piece of your ideas. Just keep in mind, the gym may have competition within such as massage, chiro, trainers, etc. if this is the case, they have no incentive to refer to you bc they are collecting from you regardless and yet can filter the income onto their own resources. So it depends ok the situation

post_text:
I have an interesting case that I want some input on from you all. 

Client complains of pain around the R eye/forehead that happens when he does any type of physical activity or standing up from sitting that lasts 15-45 seconds intensity of 6-9/10 and then goes away to a 0/10. Symptoms are reproduced with resisted left cervical rotation and deep palpation to right upper trap and SCM. He had a nerve block to occipital nerve which seemed to improve his symptoms. MRI of brain negative. Tested for temporal arteritis was negative. Tested BP seated vs standing and all WNL. 

Dry needling to R UT and SCM reproduced his symptoms and then improved after being in for 2-15 min. I haven‚Äôt DN suboccipital region. But any type of cervical exertion causes the headaches. 

Any ideas from anyone?

comments.text: How long has he had pain for?
If the occipital nerve block temporarily relieved his symptoms consider nerve entrapment.  If therapy can‚Äôt fix him I recommend Tim Tollestrup MD peripheral nerve surgeon.

MRI of brain negative. Tested for temporal arteritis was negative. Tested BP seated vs standing and all WNL. 

Dry needling to R UT and SCM reproduced his symptoms and then improved after being in for 2-15 min. I haven‚Äôt DN suboccipital region. But any type of cervical exertion causes the headaches. 

Any ideas from anyone?

COMMENT 1: How long has he had pain for?

COMMENT 2: If the occipital nerve block temporarily relieved his symptoms consider nerve entrapment.  If therapy can‚Äôt fix him I recommend Tim Tollestrup MD peripheral nerve surgeon.

post_text:
I‚Äôm curious what your thoughts would be if you learned of a chiropractor in your area basically performing physical therapy in their clinic. Today I learned of a relatively new chiropractic clinic near me who advertises their services as ‚Äúchiropractic adjustments, dry needling, functional rehabilitation, Gaston/IASTM, FAKTR, and cupping.‚Äù She also advertises pregnancy and postpartum care including stretching and exercises. I‚Äôm not exactly sure what all chiropractors are trained in, but it seems like this practice is blurring the line between chiropractic and PT. The name of the clinic doesn‚Äôt even have chiropractic in it. I‚Äôm on the fence about reaching out to this chiropractor as a potential referral source (her to me and me to her). I‚Äôm also trying to have the mindset of ‚Äúthere‚Äôs enough to go around‚Äù and not see her as competition, but it‚Äôs hard not to.

Update: I called and spoke to the chiropractor yesterday. She hasn‚Äôt even opened her doors yet but does next week. I‚Äôm meeting with her next Friday morning. She sounds really nice and was excited to hear from me. üòä

comments.text: A good chiro and a good PT should practice pretty similarly

Chiropractors can bill 97110 and 97112, so what they are advertising is perfectly fine.  They just can‚Äôt call it physical therapy. 
I market myself on social media performing grade V manipulations of the spine, but I call it manipulations and not adjustments or chiro care.  We are very similar professions, so there is a lot of crossover.

post_text:
So what is the absolute minimum you need to start to see patients on your own mobility or in home? 
My husband and I are planning to start our own cash side gig and hopefully grow it to a full time thing. 

Also how important is a social media presence because I am not a fan of posting things. Our kids are heavily involved in the community through church, sports, ect and we've coached a lot of teams and plan to market through our social networks of people we know in these areas and start there.

comments.text:
Liability and malpractice insurance are musts as well. 
I had treatment table
EmR 
Cleaning supplies (wipes, purel)
Fascia free 
Resistance bands
Balance pad
And the most important is your brain and how your evaluate and educate patients. 

My business has been mostly word of mouth and the occasional shoutout on some local community FB groups. Went from 2 days a week to five days a week In about 8 months and I see about 20-25 visits a week.
I‚Äôm fully mobile

To the best of my knowledge Ive never gotten any business from social media origin. 10.5 months running and I just entered patient #160   Most is word of mouth followed by HH agency referrals followed by me pursing a group of homes w developmental disabled adults.

post_text:
Happy Friday UNCAGED CLINICIAN family !!

Just want to share my win this week.  I am PT / run coach and owner of RunRocket Physical Therapy and Wellness and a mom of 2 awesome active kids. I manage all of that daily while my husband working hard! Last week I talked to David Bayliff and told him I am little slow but it‚Äôs okay I continue working on relationships and keep in touch with all my clients because I believe it‚Äôs KEY üîë to be successful. Guess What? I got 2 more referrals from past clients both 1 is ultra runner and one just active individual. I already saw 1 and sold a 10 pack and he schedule out 7/10 sessions already. ü§Øü§Øü§Øü§Ø I even raised my price and client had no problems!!! He saw a value ! He felt better in 1 sessions ! Did I fix him!! Noooo! I listened to him and his concerns ! I made him feel important and empower him to change his health!!! 

I am seeing a ultra runner today !!! 

What I am trying to say !! Keep taking  small steps and put  yourself out there. Keep showing to local runs / events based on your nitch !! I even bring my son and daughter to community run ! People see I am human and caring for running community !!! 

Have an amazing weekend !! Keep going !! There will be days when you questioned everything but days like this week for me !! I know I am doing EXaCTly what I meant to do !!! 

I am grateful üòá I have an amazing The Pride family and amazing Coaches Josh Payne , David and Kevin DeGroot!!! If you on fence of starting a business talk to them and I promise your life will change forever., mine did !!!! 

#uncagedclinician #PhysicalTherapy #uncaged #runrocketpt #runner

post_text: Hello!  I'm an OT, CHT and I love following these posts and getting more information on the uncaged clinician life.  One hold up I keep having is where can you get reliable information about direct access care for your state, specifically Georgia?  If you plan to be cash based only, but you're still advertising as OT services, do you need to have direct access?  What are the limitations on this or where can you direct me to more information on the regulations?  Thanks!!

comments.text: Hi Ashley, I just sent an email to the Georgia OT assoc with this question. OT‚Äôs in Georgia do have direct access. If you are cash based you only need to have the training to back up your competency in what you are treating. If accepting insurance it depends on what each insurance company requirements are.
Hey Ashley, I am an OT with my own practice.  If you do want to see Medicare clients, just be sure you are familiar with the rules/regulations we need to follow for that population.

If you are cash based you only need to have the training to back up your competency in what you are treating. If accepting insurance it depends on what each insurance company requirements are.

post_text:
So... you play the marketing game to a select few local MDs, discuss things with the MA/front desk, have a good face to face with the doc, hear "yeah, this is great, we'll refer some your way," then you NEVER HEAR ANYTHING.

I know it's all about building relationships, but what specifically is the next step? Try to hit the front desk again? Show up unexpectedly and drop off more pens? Let it go and bug another clinic?

comments.text: I don‚Äôt have great luck with marketing to physicians. For me, joining networking groups and building relationships is where I‚Äôve found success!

Bear with me‚Ä¶. I‚Äôm I‚Äôm totally serious: are you taking good donuts?

The return on investment of donuts is pretty incredible. 

Look, they‚Äôve got pens. And-post its.

They want / appreciate good quality donuts (Not Dunkin, never Dunkin).

Personal experience?  A dozen donuts gets you a referral.

But when you are there, are you spending most of your time talking about the business? Or are you shooting the shit with them (sorry: I didn‚Äôt have another phrase): talking about their kids? Last nights ballgame? Going huntin‚Äô? Everyday conversation
To get to know them? 

They don‚Äôt care about that last course you went to or if you do this new thing with backs. It‚Äôs about building relationships. And getting to know THEM (doc, nurse, front desk‚Ä¶do not ignore AT All the front desk.) . Front desk is the key.

full_thread_text:

COMMENT 2: Bear with me‚Ä¶. I‚Äôm I‚Äôm totally serious: are you taking good donuts?

The return on investment of donuts is pretty incredible. 

Look, they‚Äôve got pens. And-post its.

They want / appreciate good quality donuts (Not Dunkin, never Dunkin).

Personal experience?  A dozen donuts gets you a referral.

But when you are there, are you spending most of your time talking about the business? Or are you shooting the shit with them (sorry: I didn‚Äôt have another phrase): talking about their kids? Last nights ballgame? Going huntin‚Äô? Everyday conversation
To get to know them? 

They don‚Äôt care about that last course you went to or if you do this new thing with backs. It‚Äôs about building relationships. And getting to know THEM (doc, nurse, front desk‚Ä¶do not ignore AT All the front desk.) . Front desk is the key.

post_text: I am currently in the process of starting a mobile PT practice in NJ, primarily Medicare Part B, however, I have been getting a few cash clients as well. I am curious about the direct access in NJ, because as I read the law, as long as the patient is making progress and there are no red flags, I just need to inform the primary MD that I am seeing the patient after 30 days? Can anyone in NJ explain this to me and how you handle this. Do I just send a plan of care with goals after 30 days? Does the MD need to sign a POC like they would for Medicare or I literally just need to make them aware that I am treating the patient and they are making progress?

comments.text:
Same set up, and yes this is how I‚Äôve understood it here in NJ. 

If no progress or very limited I usually suggest referral to the patient and send a POC over to the office. 

If pt doing fine I still inform the MD with a full progress note expecting a signed POC (which also confirms they reviewed the doc) but I don‚Äôt automatically expect the patient to have an MD visit to continue PT.  My EMR generates them quickly and after 30 days Im usually doing some kind of re-eval anyway. 

Covers my ass, generates good multidisciplinary networking and establishes good communication. 

From there it‚Äôll vary by MD. Some just sign and return some want to see their patients.

Hello all!
I'm finally ready to start knocking on some doors to get referrals. Anyone here care to share their experience on how to even go about setting an appointment to talk to these MDs? Also, what's a good opener?
I'm usually shy, but I know that's not acceptable when trying to get your private practice off the groundüòÖ
I'm a concierge mobile vestibular physical therapist, so my target referral sources would be neurologists, ENTs & Audiologists. 
TIA!

comments.text:
I‚Äôm just getting started with this too. I have a friend who is an MD who I asked about this. He said what works best is to call ahead and ask 
1) who would be the best person to talk to for referrals in the office
2) ask what time is normally down time for them
3) make it quick and efficient. ‚Ä¶he said meeting you face to face is nice, but he‚Äôs very busy so 5 min or less is preferred.

Hey there! I also started mobile vestibular practice too!!! I have since transitioned to renting a space but would love to chat! ‚ò∫Ô∏è
In all honesty I haven‚Äôt had too much success with going to doctors, even ENT and neurologists. I‚Äôve done door knocking, phone calls, scheduled lunch and learns, scheduled myself as a patient (I have my own issues too! Lol) and well‚Ä¶ I get most of my clients with direct marketing. I‚Äôm so excited for you! Would love to share what‚Äôs worked (and what hasn‚Äôt for me haha)
