post_text: Has anyone ever started a concierge/mobile cash PT business with someone else but had separate LLC‚Äôs? My friend and I were hoping to have a business name together (shared website, marketing, etc) but keep our money and taxes separate? Any advice or recommendations on how to go about this or if this is possible?

comments.text:
#Compliance - Missing in the equation are legal obligations of a practice related to the website itself, as well as specific notices that practice will be obligated to post.....  

Get legal advice of a health law attorney in your state... that can address all your questions, including website legal obligations.

I would keep your businesses separate. 

A website that features both of you could be ok as a marketing collaborative (a website that features multiple businesses) 

But honestly. I would decide what will happen (who will own it) if anything happens to the partnership later.

full_thread_text:

Any advice or recommendations on how to go about this or if this is possible?

COMMENT 1: #Compliance - Missing in the equation are legal obligations of a practice related to the website itself, as well as specific notices that practice will be obligated to post.....  

Get legal advice of a health law attorney in your state... that can address all your questions, including website legal obligations.

COMMENT 2: I would keep your businesses separate. 

A website that features both of you could be ok as a marketing collaborative (a website that features multiple businesses) 

But honestly. I would decide what will happen (who will own it) if anything happens to the partnership later.

post_text:
Merry Christmas everyone!

I have a lot of physician offices that refer me patients. I got them all some nice little typical Christmas gift baskets.

For a few offices I wanted to get them a Theragun for the office staff to use while working. Is that ethically okay? I just wanted to be sure.

comments.text: If they are Medicare providers it is generally acceptable to give a perishable gift that can be shared with all of the staff. Anything more than that is unethical. At our facility our employer limits gifts to nothing more than $25 value.
#Compliance Under your compliance program - address legal aspects of gifting w/referral sources, and application of federal health care laws.

COMMENT 1: If they are Medicare providers it is generally acceptable to give a perishable gift that can be shared with all of the staff. Anything more than that is unethical. At our facility our employer limits gifts to nothing more than $25 value.

COMMENT 2: #Compliance Under your compliance program - address legal aspects of gifting w/referral sources, and application of federal health care laws.

post_text: Anybody else out there struggling to get new patients? I came out with a bang, but now I haven't had a new patient in months. I had a few evals, but they didn't want to return for follow-ups (I think mainly due to schedule, not anything I did or didn't do, unless they don't want to tell me that). I have done paid ads on facebook, where I get a few messages but never turns into anything. I have done a few workshops and have some coming up in January, but my goal was 15 visits a week, and currently I am at 4, with nothing promising on the horizon.

comments.text: This time of year is notoriously slow. Our business is often feast or famine. If you are seeing Medicare patients, should be an uptick in referrals after the first of the year. Marketing is everything though. Best wishes!
I'm in the same space. It's extremely anxiety inducing. I'm just going to be focused on marketing and making appointments with physicians and their referral schedulers ..

full_thread_text:
POST: Anybody else out there struggling to get new patients? I came out with a bang, but now I haven't had a new patient in months. I had a few evals, but they didn't want to return for follow-ups (I think mainly due to schedule, not anything I did or didn't do, unless they don't want to tell me that). I have done paid ads on facebook, where I get a few messages but never turns into anything. I have done a few workshops and have some coming up in January, but my goal was 15 visits a week, and currently I am at 4, with nothing promising on the horizon.

COMMENT 1: This time of year is notoriously slow. Our business is often feast or famine. If you are seeing Medicare patients, should be an uptick in referrals after the first of the year. Marketing is everything though. Best wishes!

COMMENT 2: I'm in the same space. It's extremely anxiety inducing. I'm just going to be focused on marketing and making appointments with physicians and their referral schedulers ..

Hey everyone!
Recently started my own cash based PT clinic inside my CrossFit gym in October. Looking to treat overhead athletes- CrossFit, softball, baseball, etc. 
I was just a 5/6am athlete, but have been trying to go to other class times so different athletes can learn who I am. 
Once softball/baseball tournaments start back up I‚Äôd like to set up a table there. 
Any advice for ways to get new patients?

comments.text: I used to do free consults in my gym once per month.  15 min and occasionally invited a doc to join me. In NYC that‚Äôs golden. He got a few new patients that needed a formal office  visit. For the basic strains and tendinitis issues he gave them a script to see me. Overall we elevated the prestige of the club and gym members got a sweet deal.  In return our patients got a small discount if they joined the club after they were DC from PT
C O N V E R S A T I O N S

post_text:
Ok this isn‚Äôt necessarily uncaged related but I need help! I wanted to start my own business but I‚Äôm just not in a place to do that right now. 

I currently work for a large hospital system. I feel like they have treated me fairly for the past 10 years but I really want to grow and learn how to run a clinic. However, I think our managers do wayyy too much. 

I recently was offered a position at a new local clinic that is physician owned. They have offered me the salary I wanted plus commission off any new business I bring into the clinic. They are wanting me to run and help grow the clinic which is a great ‚Äúmanager‚Äù role. My friend works as a PTA and loves the owners and has really loved working there so far. I‚Äôm really torn on what to do. I am hesitant to work for a physician owned clinic and I really don‚Äôt know anyone who has in the past.

I‚Äôm not crazy about their current referral base since it is currently from the pain clinic but has the potential to expand to orthopedics. 

Thoughts?

comments.text: What a wonderful opportunity for you to get an idea of what a different business runs like! And to get to know those physicians in case you DO start a business in the future (if you‚Äôre like me in Texas you still need MD referral with our limited access). Sounds like you have the opportunity to learn and grow, build a new population base for this group, and in turn you would be learning to market as well. And you‚Äôre making the money you want. Just check to see what their non-compete is in case you do start your own thing in the future and have worked to give them a lot of business that you won‚Äôt be able to use for yourself. I want to say most people that end up staying with physician owned clinics really love it. They can be poorly run too, but in that case you‚Äôre really learning what NOT to do and then moving on to other things. If you have a good recc from someone I‚Äôd say go for it!

Having done both one problem with a  single referral source us that you don‚Äôt see as much variety in approach and getting other physicians patients to come to another physicians clinic  is never easy

I recently was offered a position at a new local clinic that is physician owned. They have offered me the salary I wanted plus commission off any new business I bring into the clinic. They are wanting me to run and help grow the clinic which is a great ‚Äúmanager‚Äù role. My friend works as a PTA and loves the owners and has really loved working there so far. I‚Äôm really torn on what to do. I am hesitant to work for a physician owned clinic and I really don‚Äôt know anyone who has in the past.

I‚Äôm not crazy about their current referral base since it is currently from the pain clinic but has the potential to expand to orthopedics. 

Thoughts?

COMMENT 1: What a wonderful opportunity for you to get an idea of what a different business runs like! And to get to know those physicians in case you DO start a business in the future (if you‚Äôre like me in Texas you still need MD referral with our limited access). Sounds like you have the opportunity to learn and grow, build a new population base for this group, and in turn you would be learning to market as well. And you‚Äôre making the money you want. Just check to see what their non-compete is in case you do start your own thing in the future and have worked to give them a lot of business that you won‚Äôt be able to use for yourself. I want to say most people that end up staying with physician owned clinics really love it. They can be poorly run too, but in that case you‚Äôre really learning what NOT to do and then moving on to other things. If you have a good recc from someone I‚Äôd say go for it!

COMMENT 2: Having done both one problem with a  single referral source us that you don‚Äôt see as much variety in approach and getting other physicians patients to come to another physicians clinic  is never easy

post_text: When you were finally were ready to launch (this has been a long time in the making), what was the first thing you did to announce your presence in your community to start bringing in patients (mobile outpatient)?

comments.text: I shared on my social medias and then lots of friends shared my posts to their personal pages and to the facebook mom groups across town. Before I left the hospital I emailed the physicians I worked with to tell them I was starting my own practice. I gave them a forwarding email address which contained my company name but did not advertise my company in so many words. I set up meetings with them after I left as a rep of my own company. About 20-30 of my clients came with me, I kept their contact information for when I was ready to launch.
I ran naked down main street holding a sign with our practice name and phone number.

post_text:
Hi guys,

How do you guys contact gyms, yoga studios, or any facilities that you want to build a relationship with? 

What type of marketing do you do? 

I am starting a cash based mobile PT practice but unsure how to get started on marketing. I am in the process of completing my website right now.

I would appreciate any insight!

comments.text: I just started my cash based mobile PT business about month ago. I stopped by some local gyms/studios that had a similar mission. When speaking to the owner, I told them how I could benefit them by keeping their members healthy or help them recover quickly from an injury. Now they are putting my info cards in all of their new member bags. I'm also providing inservices to their trainers.

Give more than you take. That‚Äôs super important when starting relationships. I highly discourage going in to meetings/emails just touting what you do and how you can help their clients. I suggest trying their services out, taking some of their classes, collaborate on a workshop/event, build a relationship‚Äîthis takes time.

I‚Äôm just having someone do IG/FB with some FB boosts and 3 emails a month to my email list.  IG followers have doubled, biz page fb interaction has gone up but no new clients.  Getting a little tired of spending so much money.  But maybe I just need to be more patient or switch tactics.  What have u guys found to work best?

comments.text: Social media marketing is the hard way to get new patients.  Focus on you past patient list.  Next to 0 money and will get you way more new patients than cold lead marketing on social media

Lead gen is, as Ray said, most profitable through past patients. Do your have a digital app that connects you quickly with all of your discharged patients? Even sending a Thinking of You note can re engage them and /or get referrals to their friends and family.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hey guys‚Ä¶.just curious about those of you having someone doing your social media marketing.  Wondering when you typically saw an ROI.  I‚Äôm just having someone do IG/FB with some FB boosts and 3 emails a month to my email list.  IG followers have doubled, biz page fb interaction has gone up but no new clients.  Getting a little tired of spending so much money.  But maybe I just need to be more patient or switch tactics.  What have u guys found to work best?

COMMENT 1: Social media marketing is the hard way to get new patients.  Focus on you past patient list.  Next to 0 money and will get you way more new patients than cold lead marketing on social media

COMMENT 2: Lead gen is, as Ray said, most profitable through past patients. Do your have a digital app that connects you quickly with all of your discharged patients? Even sending a Thinking of You note can re engage them and /or get referrals to their friends and family.

post_text: Sorry for the semi-long post.  I have been a member of this group for a while, but just recently left my corporate health care job to join a small private practice (2 other clinicians with 2 locations).  In the system we had more patients than we could handle, now I'm struggling to find any.  I have 2 kids and as the bread winner in the family am feeling uncertain about my decision financially.  What tips do you all have for free marketing, reaching target audience, etc?  Limited budget for spending on these kinds of things.  I would appreciate and and all help you seasoned uncagers have to offer!

comments.text: Hi Erin!! I think it helps to ‚Äúniche‚Äù down and market right to the people of how you can treat differently than in the hospital system! I‚Äôm happy to chat with you since I see you are now in Brookfield by me ü§ó congrats on the move!

Interview the referral sources in your own podcast and show. Show them how you can help them. Give give give. Serve serve serve. And then ask ask ask after. Or if you don't want to do that. Run FB ads. We are so busy that I turned it off. 

I started with interviewing them in our podcast and now do hybrid. 

Good luck!!!

full_thread_text:

What tips do you all have for free marketing, reaching target audience, etc?  Limited budget for spending on these kinds of things.  I would appreciate and and all help you seasoned uncagers have to offer!

COMMENT 1: Hi Erin!! I think it helps to ‚Äúniche‚Äù down and market right to the people of how you can treat differently than in the hospital system! I‚Äôm happy to chat with you since I see you are now in Brookfield by me ü§ó congrats on the move!

COMMENT 2: Interview the referral sources in your own podcast and show. Show them how you can help them. Give give give. Serve serve serve. And then ask ask ask after. Or if you don't want to do that. Run FB ads. We are so busy that I turned it off. 

I started with interviewing them in our podcast and now do hybrid. 

Good luck!!!

post_text:
Those who are solo therapists, how do you handle vacations? Are your patients ok taking a week off when you are on vacation? Have you felt people quit or got unmotivated when you paused services?
I am from Brazil, and between  going home and a specialization I am taking, I take about 4 weeks off a year. 
I am technically ready to uncage. I have full 17 sessions a week and a 3 week waiting list, and I currently stopped taking new patients for the rest of the year because I can‚Äôt even fit the people I have‚Ä¶ but I am held back by fear‚Ä¶. Mostly silly I am the one supporting a family of 6‚Ä¶.
What if I go on vacation and my caseload quit on me? (Hasn‚Äôt happened and I‚Äôve taken tons of time this year‚Ä¶ but I did not really care or apologize because it was not my main income‚Ä¶ people were still here when I come back‚Ä¶ but I worry that when I need them to stay they may go?)
What if something happens and as a LLC I don‚Äôt have disability insurance?
What if once I go full time all the patients disappear?
What if another covid like event happens and I have no patients??? 

It is so scary‚Ä¶ right now I plan on holding until end of April because I go to Brazil for spring break, and have 1 1-week class in February‚Ä¶. So I figured i could use my work PTO and sabe some money for emergencies in between‚Ä¶. But I AM technically ready‚Ä¶ so sometimes I feel like I should just do it because there will always be a reason to wait a bit more‚Ä¶

comments.text:
Network with a few PTs around that you can refer to when you‚Äôre out.  
Most of my clients prefer to wait for me, but appreciate the options ‚Äî especially for acute flare ups.

One of the biggest things I've noticed since becoming uncaged is my patients are so supportive of me taking time off and doing things for myself.... No guilt trips or rude comments like I'd always get from coworkers and patients in the corporate setting. I have just tried to do more trips starting midweek so that I can squeeze patients in before and after I go, and flights are usually cheaper that way too!

I am technically ready to uncage. I have full 17 sessions a week and a 3 week waiting list, and I currently stopped taking new patients for the rest of the year because I can‚Äôt even fit the people I have‚Ä¶ but I am held back by fear‚Ä¶. Mostly silly I am the one supporting a family of 6‚Ä¶.
What if I go on vacation and my caseload quit on me? (Hasn‚Äôt happened and I‚Äôve taken tons of time this year‚Ä¶ but I did not really care or apologize because it was not my main income‚Ä¶ people were still here when I come back‚Ä¶ but I worry that when I need them to stay they may go?)
What if something happens and as a LLC I don‚Äôt have disability insurance?
What if once I go full time all the patients disappear?
What if another covid like event happens and I have no patients??? 

It is so scary‚Ä¶ right now I plan on holding until end of April because I go to Brazil for spring break, and have 1 1-week class in February‚Ä¶. So I figured i could use my work PTO and sabe some money for emergencies in between‚Ä¶. But I AM technically ready‚Ä¶ so sometimes I feel like I should just do it because there will always be a reason to wait a bit more‚Ä¶

COMMENT 1: Network with a few PTs around that you can refer to when you‚Äôre out.  
Most of my clients prefer to wait for me, but appreciate the options ‚Äî especially for acute flare ups.

COMMENT 2: One of the biggest things I've noticed since becoming uncaged is my patients are so supportive of me taking time off and doing things for myself.... No guilt trips or rude comments like I'd always get from coworkers and patients in the corporate setting. I have just tried to do more trips starting midweek so that I can squeeze patients in before and after I go, and flights are usually cheaper that way too!

WHY IS SEO IMPORTANT FOR YOUR BUSINESS?

I have to be honest, I used to be one of those people that never really trusted SEO or thought it was a scam, merely due to the fact that I didn't know what it actually was. But after going down the SEO rabbit hole, learning all the ins and outs, and now offering it as a service at Nogn, I've realized just how crucial it is for businesses.

But here are a few top reasons:
* Increased traffic from ORGANIC searches
* Best tool for local businesses to get seen - utilize Google My Business
* Builds Brand Authority - creates trust and credibility for your business
* Cost Effective Solution - relatively cheap compared to other marketing tactics
* Strong Long Term Strategy - more effective than PPC ads

You can read through the full blog on why SEO is important here: https://www.nognstudio.com/blog/why-seo-is-important-for-businesses 

Hope this helps clarify the reasoning for SEO campaigns, feel free to hit me up with any questions you have!

post_text: I have no experience with digital ads.  Wondering if I should start with Google ads or FB ads?  Can I do this myself?  Do you recommend a specific person or agency to help with this?  Any help is appreciated! Thank you!

comments.text:
Think about where you‚Äôre driving traffic to‚Ä¶ 

Because if you pay for traffic and have a colander to pour them in instead of a funnel you‚Äôre wasting money. 

I‚Äôve been targeted for so many PT clinic ads from places across the country it kills me ‚Äî because I‚Äôm not their ideal client, I‚Äôm not even in the same state.

Do you have Google My Business set up? 

Next ‚Äî is your website optimized for SEO for your location? (Like if I type ‚Äúphysical therapy in Houston, TX‚Äù you want to appear) 

Then once a person gets to your website is it super clear who you help and how they can book? 

Every time people ask how to get more patients in this group people say word of mouth and Google. 

I‚Äôm not an ads expert, but I wouldn‚Äôt pour money into it until you have the organic pieces in place first. üôÇ 

But if you have a digital product/service and a solid funnel set up, then I say get an ads person to create a plan üòâ

Join this group and sign-up with their BOOKED program. The course will teach you how to start running and maintaining your clinic's FB ads. You wont regret it!

https://www.facebook.com/ClinicalMarketer

When my patients come see me they will feel heard and be treated with kindness, empathy, and respect of their own individual belief systems.

post_text: Hi everyone! Just looking for a shoulder to lean on at the moment. I‚Äôve worked extremely hard to get where I‚Äôm at today. I‚Äôve finally gotten the word out enough and a patient recommended I sit on a panel for a national organization to talk about my specialities treating pediatric spine conditions. I‚Äôm so pumped but my SO is being a buzzkill and says I‚Äôm wasting my time because I‚Äôm not getting paid for it but in my mind I‚Äôm on stage with leading experts with so many opportunities for networking and essentially presenting my cases that I feel would generate a large amount of patients/consultations. They are also doing free marketing in my mind saving me a ton of time! Anyone else struggle with family or partners who don‚Äôt understand the whole concept of free screenings, community service, talks, etc to generate patients? üò†

comments.text: In any business there are times you have to hustle and not get paid for it. I think that is what sets apart entrepreneurs from worker bees, entrepreneurs risk their time, money and energy for an opportunity. Non entrepreneurs will only work for $. If it doesn't hurt your relationship, you do you! Don't look for validation even from your SO.

This is a great opportunity and you are clearly excited about it! That's all you need to focus on. Not every minute of every thing you do in your profession has an immediate monetary return. Do your thing, be confident and enjoy the experience!

post_text:
I‚Äôm in the process of opening a stretching and functional movement company. Ultimately I‚Äôd like to get an actual brick and mortar space, but the rent numbers are scaring me, so I‚Äôm sticking with mobile at first. I‚Äôll be competing with a brand new StretchZone that just opened about 3 weeks ago in literally THE EXACT spot that I was eyeing to have as my space. So, my question is, are targeted Facebook ads effective? I‚Äôve had ads for StretchZone pop up in my Facebook feed yesterday and today, so obviously they think so. But if I had to pump money somewhere, would I be better off with Facebook or doing a large direct mailing campaign?

Also, if anyone is so inclined, I‚Äôd love honest feedback on my website. Thanks! (www.stretch-ability.com)

comments.text: To be honest. We have more leads in our FB than waiting for MD referrals. So go with FB ads. Good luck! Love the name!!

Good job adding this Abby Regan .As someone who has added a whole suite of wellness and recovery services to my new brick & mortar, you did the right thing if you plan to go brick & mortar soon. Do not open a regular brick & mortar with just PT. You can just rent a gym space for just PT. If you want a traditional retail space you need to pursue your stretch initiative plus more in addition to PT. Good luck!

If you want a traditional retail space you need to pursue your stretch initiative plus more in addition to PT. Good luck!

post_text:
HELP. I have a tricky situation to navigate. There is a new functional medicine/wellness center that really wants to partner with us to be able to offer cash PT. We like them a lot as people and like their mission, but idk if they really know how a business works. They want to charge a monthly rent that is a little above market value for the space (linens, EMR, front desk, basic equipment, and some other minor things are included in that) but then take 20%%%%%% of our profit. 

I've never been in a sublease situation before, but I don't know what business takes that much of a cut if they aren't providing that much extra service or referrals to the leasee. They also have no idea how many referrals they could give and I assume I will need to do most of the hustle for marketing. 

Feel free to comment or ask questions!

comments.text: No percentage usually. Rent only

I will be a little more blunt, as Kelley Ryan said...NO!  rent higher than market plus 20% rake on profit?? that's a nicely disguised kick back...and you would be partially caged in my opinion.  

 Your niche' is womens health and that specialty is so in demand.  If you are good at what you do, and I'm sure you are, you will be more than fine.  rent out a room in an office and spend your time on marketing ob/gyn's,  primary care MD's, physiatrists, new mom's groups etc.  word of mouth will spread like wildfire.  you will crush it.

post_text:
What should I expect to pay for rent? 
I'm in a 300 sq. ft. space inside a CrossFit-style (not CF branded) gym. I'm good friends with the guy that owns the building and the gym, and he has let me build out the space and get my cash business started rent free thus far. He approached me tonight about starting to pay rent, but left the amount up to me. Obviously as a business owner, I want to tell him $1/month (ha!), but he's a good friend and is also a great referral source, as he's pretty popular in our small town, so I want to come up with a fair price. 
Pros:
Free utilities, internet
Gym has almost zero attendance until a bout 5pm everyday
Access to lots of general gym/workout equipment 

Cons:
Location on a side street, no frontage on a main road
Limited signage
Front door is always locked and gym members have a swipe card 
Gym area has only limited climate control (I do have AC/heat in my clinic area)
The owner does not make a profit off the gym, and prefers to keep membership low. It's basically his large friend group, so there isn't a substantial built-in referral base. 

For those who rent space in a gym, or sublease space in any other facility, what would a 300sq ft room cost? For reference, this is a relatively low income town and low cost of living area.

comments.text:
Whatever you decide do research and find an average. Present him the research/average and round up to a nice number. He deserves that respect.

Example: average for your square foot is $429/month. I'd round up to $475 or $500 per month. Don't round up too much but whatever you think is enough for him to feel appreciated

You could start out offering him a percentage like 25 percent of each visit not to exceed a certain total amount per month.That may work while still building and that way your not stressed about always coming up with that set amount each month.

post_text:
For all you uncaged folks who work out of gyms‚Ä¶ 

What‚Äôs your arrangement look like? 

At a small impasse with one of the gym owners I work with. He wants me to be there for set hours (takes up my entire day one day a week- I can‚Äôt fit patients before or after my gym arrangement on that day) Essentially- wants a PT on retainer. He wants me there even if I have no patients scheduled for the relationship building aspect. Initially- totally fine, I had nowhere else to be, happy to give my time. Now as things in my mobile business get busier, I‚Äôm finding myself reducing available hours to paying patients to essentially go burn time. Sounds like he‚Äôs not too interested in continuing the relationship with me if I‚Äôm showing up only when there‚Äôs work to be done. 

He doesn‚Äôt pay me, and I don‚Äôt give him kickback or pay rent. 

Been there a few months consistently so I feel that at this point, his gym members know I‚Äôm there for them if they need me. I‚Äôm great about responding to texts and calls. 

I don‚Äôt want to disappoint anyone or burn bridges/ throw away an opportunity, but from a business standpoint the current setup doesn‚Äôt make good fiscal sense, and it sounds like he‚Äôs pretty inflexible with the idea of change. 

Any advice or input appreciated. As PTs would y‚Äôall just continue on and keep set hours on days you don‚Äôt actively have patients to see? Is that nuts, or is that sort of thing just the necessary sacrifices of early business ownership?

comments.text:
I don‚Äôt have my own PT clinic or practice but just speaking out of business experience: if you‚Äôre not paying rent or have any obligation to the gym, why does the owner insist you have regular hours? What‚Äôs the benefit to the owner? Does the owner want clients to drop in and see you for advise, without an evaluation? Clients are expected to make an appointment for which you get paid. 
if the gym isn‚Äôt paying you, you‚Äôre not available for ‚ÄúFReE‚Äùadvise. 
Or was the arrangement that you‚Äôre available to all gym clients unless you have a paying client?
I would recommend moving on. There are other people out there to network with. Not all may be a good fit. This certainly sounds like one of them

post_text:
*"From the core of who I am"*

*"God placed this mission in my heart."*

*"I do what I do because I see the potential in other people."*

*"To provide hope, because the world is filled with brokenness."*

*"To be a pillar of hope."*

*"To build something that serves the community and to move beyond myself."*

As Kevin DeGroot, Josh Payne, Kalyca Jin Zarich, and I have held board meetings with our mastermind students over the past two weeks, these are some of the amazing comments that these incredible people have stated when asked:

*Why do you do what you do?*

*Why is that important?*

We also ask them to rate how they are doing in the areas of the 5 F's:

*Faith *

*Family *

*Fitness *

*Finance *

*Fulfillment*

And what is interesting is that no one's level of fulfillment has been tied to their finance rating.

Perhaps because your business or your job should exist for you; not you existing for your job.

Maybe it is because, virtually, we have never had a student or prospective student tell us that they wanted to create their own practice in order to make more money.

Yes, making more money does happen to be a reason.  But it is never the first thing a person says.  It is usually at least 4th or 5th on their reason list.

In fact, one student even commented that:

*"Unless you are happy at your core, you will never be happy in your business."*

The 5 F's represent your core.

*So, I ask:*

*What is your Why? *

We would love to know.

Furthermore,* does your current vehicle *(i.e. your practice or your job)* have the ability to take you to where you want to be?*

If it needs to change, comment *"**vehicle**" *below üëá Perhaps we can help.

post_text:
Hey friends!!
Can someone give me advice on the best way to go about creating a website that looks professional and is relatively simple to create? Total newbie here with doing this type of thing. We have our logo and domain is secured :) Thank you in advance!!!

comments.text:
To get off the ground, you really just need a one page website that covers the basics. Then after you‚Äôre earning $$ and know your target audience and message more you can expand and add pages. 

You can keep the blog hidden until you want to actually commit to writing consistently. 

I usually recommend Squarespace or Wix for beginners and then you‚Äôll be able to modify things yourself instead of paying a designer. 

You‚Äôll rewrite your website a few times, so don‚Äôt put a ton of pressure on yourself for the first version. Just make sure the feel and message are on point for your target audience.

post_text: I like to send a handwritten thank you card to each MD that sends me referrals, every time they send me a new patient. Would you name the patient in the note? or just a generic "Thank you for the referral". Is anyone else doing this?

comments.text:
As a physician, I would like a "Thanks for referring (patient name). She is progressing well and I plan to see her for another x weeks. She has a followup set up to see you after that. Please don't hesitate to call us you have any questions about her therapy."

As all healthcare providers, physicians are busy. I dont want to spend the time opening a card that just says thanks for the referral. What does help is someone saying you passed the ball, I've got it and I'm taking care of the patient. It also helps that it's noted the patient has a followup already and it's not asking the physician to look things up or set more things up. Hope that helps. If it's ok with HIPPA (I would think it is) it helps to include the name because there are certain patients that stick out to you and having that reassurance in a quick read is gold.

If possible, I‚Äôll personally drop off the eval and offer an in-person thank you to any new MD referral sources, which removes any HIPPA issues. 
Also, I set up a weekly call in time w several of my main referral MDs, so I can give him/her a quick live update about their Pt‚Äôs. They appreciate getting live feedback, so they can ask questions etc. This is especially true for those MDs who offer concierge cash based services; as they want to really be on top of their pts and want their pts to know their getting full personal service and care. This way, they tell the pt ‚ÄúI spoke to your PT, he said you‚Äôre doing better etc‚Äù. Also, it helps me recapture lost/lazy pts, as the MD will call them to remind them to restart PT

full_thread_text:

As all healthcare providers, physicians are busy. I dont want to spend the time opening a card that just says thanks for the referral. What does help is someone saying you passed the ball, I've got it and I'm taking care of the patient. COMMENT 2: If possible, I‚Äôll personally drop off the eval and offer an in-person thank you to any new MD referral sources, which removes any HIPPA issues. 
Also, I set up a weekly call in time w several of my main referral MDs, so I can give him/her a quick live update about their Pt‚Äôs. Alright y‚Äôall. I am ready to at least take the first few steps. I currently work home health but I‚Äôm not getting the hours I need/was told I would get. I need to start out small and local because I‚Äôm also due with my third kid in 2 months, but ideally this would help support my maternity leave as well. I‚Äôm thinking through a couple options
1. Concierge Orthopedics. They do a good amount of the office work, I schedule my clients, develop my POC etc. it appears I can even set my own rates. They help with the business license, mentoring, marketing, social media. 
2. Doing my own LLC (anybody have any recommendations for a website to obtain this, thoroughly, quickly, for good price), and getting liability ins (also taking recs) and using the NextDoor App and neighborhood moms Facebook groups to advertise PT and or wellness. One niche would be a bit more wellness but helping moms get back into fitness post partum and/or maintaining during pregnancy safely etc (I have done CrossFit for 10 years and at one point was a coach but have let that lapse) with some baseline knowledge of womens health and willing to learn more. The other niche is stroke and (I‚Äôm a certified stroke rehab therapist) with a passion for chronic stroke impairments that have now been ‚Äúwritten off‚Äù as they can‚Äôt get better. They very well may have a ceiling but if we can look at some orthopedic limitations that have developed because of bad habits from prior weakness we can improve some quality of life, muscular efficiency, tolerance, pain, a bunch of stuff. 

At first glance concierge ortho is appealing because you have help with some of that stuff, especially for someone who has always worked for a company, so the grass roots marketing for myself feels daunting, but also with an upcoming kiddo on the way, having them help with some of that stuff sounds convenient for this season of life. 

Thoughts?

comments.text:
Yeah, unless you're in one of the states that requires a PLLC, just go to your Secretary of State website and file there. You don't need any other resources.

I use CM&F for insurance.

With the life phase you're in, honestly I'd go the easy route first and then transition after. There's no wrong way, and I love your niches, and you could totally go all in right now and make it work! (Strongly recommend hopping in on the next Bootcamp Josh Payne does, if you jump on the LLC train.) But it would certainly be *easier* to do the "Concierge Ortho" option.
I cannot help you make a decision but depending on the state filing an LLC might be as easy as going to your state's Secretary of State website (it's much cheaper that way)

post_text:
Was asked to do a training on injury prevention for personal trainers who work at my local gym.  How do I price this?

This is a small gym and the owners (who are trainers) already refer to me.  This would add referrals as their new trainers would get to know me, so it‚Äôs a great thing for me to do for outreach, but I also don‚Äôt want to undervalue my time.  It‚Äôll be an hour presentation and about 2 hours prep.

comments.text:
I think it‚Äôs important to understand that the largest payoff one could have from a workshop is clients signing up. If you get good at this, you can convert up to 40-60% of attendees into evaluations. The point is definitely not to make money on the front end, but to invest your time to serve the community with a much larger financial return on the backend. IMHO I think it‚Äôs very poor advice above to charge a high dollar amount for a workshop that is designed to: a) serve the community and b) convert clients to paid clients (which is where you can truly help someone and change their life). Remember: No one‚Äôs life truly gets changed from attending one workshop. When they decide to take action and take care of their problem for good is where the magic happens. 

Free or a nominal fee per person. And if you charge a nominal fee per person ($15-$50 per person), I even recommend giving 100% to the gym or the location that let you do the workshop.

Givers gain.
There has to be some type of price so they understand your worth. And then if they want to barter some thing else, I would go for what they offer in the negotiationÔøº

post_text: If you let your license lapse or cancel it, can you still call yourself a Doctor of PT because of your degree, and then get like a personal training license and technically practice under that with no stupid rules or restrictions?  Thinking out loud üò¨...

comments.text: I have OFTEN wondered this‚Ä¶.

My understanding is that you are always held to the highest standard of your education (always makes me think of a person with a black belt in martial arts getting jumped in a nonprofessional fight on the streets, then the courts considering her hands as deadly weapons when she harmed the attackersü§£) . So even if you are not a licensed PT and are a certified personal trainer, your actions can be held to PT standards. 

More thinking out loud‚Ä¶I am also an athletic trainer and have wondered several aspects of this conundrum over the years.  One factor is which of many ‚Äústupid rules & restrictions‚Äù is one trying to avoid. The other would be the state practice act..think my state does not allow the use of ‚Äúphysical therapy‚Äù or ‚Äúphysical therapist‚Äù if not licensed, so one would have to be careful on verbiage with advertising, etc‚Ä¶but saying ‚ÄúDoctor of,‚Äù ‚Äúdegree in Physical Therapy‚Äù would be fine as long as misrepresentation of licensure is not alluded to. Another factor is in the last several years, I have discovered that a lot of the ‚Äústupid rules & restrictions‚Äù are actual folklore/myths perpetuated in our profession and by graduate programs who have not updated their curriculums, as well as being confused with requirements by insurance carriers, including Medicare.

full_thread_text:
POST: If you let your license lapse or cancel it, can you still call yourself a Doctor of PT because of your degree, and then get like a personal training license and technically practice under that with no stupid rules or restrictions?  Thinking out loud üò¨...

COMMENT 1: I have OFTEN wondered this‚Ä¶.

COMMENT 2: My understanding is that you are always held to the highest standard of your education (always makes me think of a person with a black belt in martial arts getting jumped in a nonprofessional fight on the streets, then the courts considering her hands as deadly weapons when she harmed the attackersü§£) . So even if you are not a licensed PT and are a certified personal trainer, your actions can be held to PT standards. 

More thinking out loud‚Ä¶I am also an athletic trainer and have wondered several aspects of this conundrum over the years.  One factor is which of many ‚Äústupid rules & restrictions‚Äù is one trying to avoid. The other would be the state practice act..think my state does not allow the use of ‚Äúphysical therapy‚Äù or ‚Äúphysical therapist‚Äù if not licensed, so one would have to be careful on verbiage with advertising, etc‚Ä¶but saying ‚ÄúDoctor of,‚Äù ‚Äúdegree in Physical Therapy‚Äù would be fine as long as misrepresentation of licensure is not alluded to. Another factor is in the last several years, I have discovered that a lot of the ‚Äústupid rules & restrictions‚Äù are actual folklore/myths perpetuated in our profession and by graduate programs who have not updated their curriculums, as well as being confused with requirements by insurance carriers, including Medicare.

post_text: I received a referral for a patient who is deaf. A live interpreter is $60/hr with a 2 hour minimum.  What does everyone use if not a live interpreter? I think I will only need it for the initial visit as the patient is able to lip read well and I know a bit of ASL.

comments.text: I‚Äôm deaf and lip read.  Did the patient request an interpreter?  I only ask because people often assume I need an ASL interpreter when all I really need is to be able to read your lips.  If you wear masks make sure you have clear masks.  If you need the FDA type 2 masks I can give you links where to purchase for your clinic. There‚Äôs many ways to get an interpreter if that‚Äôs what they request. If you use live dictation stay away from dragon.  Otter app is not HIPPA compliant unless on a work only device.  Live transcribe or Google meets has amazing transcriptions. Zoom is terrible

post_text:
Hi again,
Anyone have a template of email that they use to ask for Google Review?
Specific context: I am independent contractor in a clinic that does a lot or perinatal physiotherapy. I treat ortho and pelvic health of all genders. My colleague specializes in perinatal and does labour and delivery prep and post partum recovery. When we discharge a client, the admin says something like "would you consider leaving us a review?". and if they client says no problem, they get an email with reminder/link.
Almost all her clients leave her reviews but barely any leave for me. I am not sure if its because of the wording of the email. Or the fact that her patients don't (come for and therefore dont do rehab that is to ) heal from pain and dysfunction. , so they just mention that it was great experience etc. Whereas with me, they come with a problem and they get better and maybe they had expectations to be quicker or something so by the time they disharge, they arent as satisfied? not sure if its my imposter syndrome. So basically, any thoughts?
or templates?
Id like to build up my name there but if the reviews only mention my colleague. I also want people of all genders to know they are welcome but if you only see pregnancy reviews, can throw people off...
if you read until now, Thanks so much!

comments.text:
Have your clinic ask them after they've seen you for a few sessions and you've built rapport and starting to see progress.  No need to wait to DC, and oftentimes by that point they've already "moved on" and it's hard/ uncomfortable to hound them to write it. 

When I email my pts asking them about leaving a review I start with something like "it's been such a pleasure working with you and I'm so glad  you reported you can now lift your toddler painfree and run 2 miles without leaking, what great improvements! Id love to be able to help  other moms (insert population here) like you get the help they need. Would you be willing to leave a review so they know help is out there?" If they agree, I give them a guideline like:  "please include
why you sought PT, what issues were you dealing with and what functional limitations did you have, what has changed/ improved since you started?" 

Don't secondguess your skills! You know you can help them and you see them improving on the daily- own it!!

Why don‚Äôt you ask them personally? Start with clients you feel really comfortable with and work from there. I‚Äôm an independent contractor for a mobile practice so there is no admin to do this for us!

post_text:
Thought I'd share a win. 
Client that I've been seeing for a few months. Started off as Mc client. Went to self pay bc not medically necessary according to those standards. Had a stroke 6 months ago. 
Is now playing tennis 6 days a week. 
Clay courts  and opened up to full court recently with his trainer who didn't think he'd be able to ever do that again. 
Footwork is improving weekly. 
Working on timing of ue and le movements for the game. 
He's a very good athlete with underlying compensations as all of us have and it made me smile to know we're reaching goals that he and I have and had. 
A challenging case but that's why we do this right????

comments.text: Congratulations!
Love this!! Thank you for sharing!

post_text: I‚Äôm having some trouble increasing my private client caseload. Im only looking for 1-2 more clients right now as I‚Äôm still working full time to get my ECS so I still need to have time for that. I‚Äôve had a few people interested but they havnt responded to my follow up email/text (after we initially spoke). Any ideas on trying to reach out again without being annoying or seeming desperate? Or other avenues to find new clients? Any help is appreciated!

comments.text:
It‚Äôs (our own) perception that (we) are being annoying or desperate.

There are many reasons why people don‚Äôt return messages.  A simple ‚ÄúFred, good day! I trust all is well.  
During our earlier conversation you indicated that your back was keeping you from _______.  
I‚Äôve been thinking about your situation and some ideas came to mind. 
I wanted to follow back with you. Is the back pain still an issue for you?

Offer them something free of value.  "It import to me/us that everyone recover even those who are struggling and not currently our patient.  He is a link to download our _____." Do data collection on them and then follow up.  "How were the exercises, did it help, are you back to ____". You want to build their trust before you try to close.  Give them a quick win.

There are many reasons why people don‚Äôt return messages.  A simple ‚ÄúFred, good day! I trust all is well.  
During our earlier conversation you indicated that your back was keeping you from _______.  
I‚Äôve been thinking about your situation and some ideas came to mind. 
I wanted to follow back with you. Is the back pain still an issue for you?

COMMENT 2: Offer them something free of value.  "It import to me/us that everyone recover even those who are struggling and not currently our patient.  He is a link to download our _____." Do data collection on them and then follow up.  "How were the exercises, did it help, are you back to ____". You want to build their trust before you try to close.  Give them a quick win.

post_text:
Hi all! I‚Äôm focused right now on trying to increase my word of mouth referrals, and my husband suggested that I run a promotion offering a referral credit to existing patients who refer a friend or family member (like a $10 credit to their next visit, or something like that). I‚Äôm wondering:
(A) Has anyone done this and did you find it successful?
(B) Are there any legal or HIPAA issues with this? The referred patient would just have to mention the friend who referred them when setting up their appointment or in their intake paperwork. 

Thanks for the input!

comments.text:
If you accept insurance, I have been told that this constitutes enticement which can be illegal if the patient has a government insurance. However, if you are a cash pay clinic, I don‚Äôt see why you couldn‚Äôt do this. 

That said, I do offer a referral bonus to employees.
I hand out t shirts galore. I see them around town. They cost me $9 each

full_thread_text:
POST: Hi all! I‚Äôm focused right now on trying to increase my word of mouth referrals, and my husband suggested that I run a promotion offering a referral credit to existing patients who refer a friend or family member (like a $10 credit to their next visit, or something like that). I‚Äôm wondering:
(A) Has anyone done this and did you find it successful?
(B) Are there any legal or HIPAA issues with this? The referred patient would just have to mention the friend who referred them when setting up their appointment or in their intake paperwork. 

Thanks for the input!

COMMENT 1: If you accept insurance, I have been told that this constitutes enticement which can be illegal if the patient has a government insurance. However, if you are a cash pay clinic, I don‚Äôt see why you couldn‚Äôt do this. 

That said, I do offer a referral bonus to employees.

COMMENT 2: I hand out t shirts galore. I see them around town. They cost me $9 each

In addition, I partnered with a local OP clinic I‚Äôve been going to personally for a year and they‚Äôll be sending me patients that have transportation issues or want it at their home.

post_text:
Rental space dilemma: 

After one person commented that being in the CrossFit gym could quickly stifle my growth I decided to see what else was out there. So I stumbled onto a 1000 sq ft commercial office space with pretty easy access to the freeway. This space would offer me two 11.5 ft x 7.5 f (90 sq ft) treatment rooms, access to a shared kitchenette room, and a main room with private entrance to it that is 20 ft x 40 ft (800 square ft). The price for this listing would be $1000 which includes all utilities, WiFi which they said they would have a WiFi hub added to my end of the building, and no CAM fees. The place is also only 15-20 minutes from the house plus a good fairly central location in Utah County. Oh it would also be a 1 min drive to another one of RxFit‚Äôs CrossFit gym which is the gym I‚Äôm a member of. 

I would be sharing the building with a Real estate company whom is the owner of the building. He seemed really interested in getting me into the space and talked about having a couple other offers, most likely a sales tactic, but said he didn‚Äôt want them and thought I would be a good fit for the place. Once again probably a sales tactic, but he definitely seemed interested like they would modify whatever I needed to help make the space more suitable. 

So weighing in this space against the CrossFit gym space I feel like I would be an absolute idiot to not seriously consider it as an option. 

Thoughts?

comments.text: Prior to becoming a PT, an old Crossfit gym of mine had a PT and massage therapist rent a space inside. All I could ever think of was how it would be difficult to communicate with clients (or to relax when getting a massage) with music always cranked up and blasting really loud during your business hours and having no control over that.

What is your 3 or 5 year plan? We can fill 2,000 sq ft really easily with 2 clinicians. I have owned and relocated over 10-clinics and my first was 800 sq ft, but 2K sq ft is about the best size for us. 
...

post_text:
Vendor/Rehab tent at CrossFit events:

My gym wants me to setup a Pre-hab/Rehab tent at all their upcoming local competitions that I can be available for. This is huge because they are the largest CrossFit community in Utah County with 6 gyms total. This would mean a lot ton of visibility and a big way I think for me to build some credibility within the local CrossFit community. 

I need some help with figuring out what services to provide, maybe prizes to contribute to the competitors, marketing materials to have available, ways to pull in leads, the works. I‚Äôve never done anything like this and this feels really like a golden opportunity that I really don‚Äôt want to screw up. 

I will take any and all guidance on how to fully capitalize on this opportunity. I feel like if things go well with one or two events they will likely be really open to me setting up workshops as well, haven‚Äôt broached that subject. 

I have a ton of CrossFit experience so I know the movements extremely well, I understand the common injuries, but I don‚Äôt know the ins and outs of stepping into this role. It‚Äôs new and different and I‚Äôm just a little afraid to mess up a good thing so I really want to do it right. 

Thank you in advance. You can email any suggestions to briancollinsdpt@revitalize3d.com or DM as well. Posting in the comments section is cool too.

comments.text:
Definitely grab emails, do mini sessions for 10 minutes every 15 minutes to give you a chance to connect. If you‚Äôre able, have someone with you to help keep you organized and see if they want to book a full session with you and get them set up with an appointment. For prizes you could offer a free or half off session. 

If you do want to charge for something, check with your gym if you have to pay a fee to them. I‚Äôve worked some competitions where if I charged, I would have to pay the organizers a fee or percentage whereas if I did free services, no charge for me. I‚Äôve also done taping at events with moderate success. Good luck, sounds like an awesome opportunity!
Sent you a message!

post_text: ÔøºÔøºÔøºÔøºso I have a weird scenario‚Ä¶Ôøºwell, ÔøºÔøºI think it‚Äôs weird. I‚Äôm asking for guidance as I‚Äôm not sure what to do here. I was contacted by a local PT who, Ôøºlike me, is also a cash based practice, also offers mobile, also works at a cross fit gym. In fact we offer many of the same services except I‚Äôm well known by many local runners and she seems to do a lot of pelvic floor/post partum. She reached out to me (through a friend) to work/collaborate/hire (see screen shot). Currently I commit 15 hours at my own company where I sublease out of a CrossFit gym. It keeps me relatively busy. But the rest of my work week is 24 hours at a outpatient clinic. Is this weird? Am I overthinking it? WOuld it be awkward to do the same work for another cash-based OON PT when I have my own company? ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è thanks for any advice

comments.text:
You may want to remove her name from the screen shot. Just for privacy. 
As for the topic, it doesn‚Äôt cost anything to have a conversation. It may be a good opportunity.

I work for a cash practice on one side of town and run my own LLC out of my home and with mobile visits on the other. My boss has absolutely no problem with it and if anything has encouraged and help me! It‚Äôs been great to have someone to continue to learn from and bounce ideas off of for challenging clients. I was just very up front about continuing to see my own clients on my own time, and I‚Äôve been given the respect and space to split my weeks between the two. I love my situation, as I left a large outpatient clinic prior to joining my current clinic. My life is significantly less stressful, I work fewer hours, I‚Äôm making just as much as I was before, and I‚Äôm seeing patients that actually want to get better. It‚Äôs a win/win to me.

post_text:
Hi, any strategies for getting POCs signed by physicians? One physician's medical assistant said she'll place it on the physician's desk to be signed again. It's my 3rd request in 3 weeks. If I do not get it back within 30 days, I assume I would have to pause the patient's POC? Does it help to visit the office and personally make the request or are there better strategies you'd recommend?

Thanks!

comments.text:
Unfortunately it is what it is my friend. What we have been doing are these.

1. Ask patient to call MD office
2. Drop of the actual print out in a nice paper and marketing materials.
3. Ask patient to go back to their MD for follow up visit and bring your POC.
4. Fax everyday and document.
5. Hire a VA team to do this for you.
6. Keep going.

Tell the patient, have them advocate to the physician for you. 

Physicians listen to their patients (customers) and want to keep them satisfied.

Edit: Relevant story that I just had this month. Pt referred to PT (order sent to affiliated PT clinic to PCP office). Pt reached out to me for PT. Eval completed, faxed in for endorsement with nice note. MA calls me saying physician is not willing to sign the POC because I‚Äôm not a provider she is familiar with and ‚Äúordered PT from a different company‚Äù. 

I told the patient, she called while I was with her and made a fuss. POC was faxed and returned within the hour.

post_text: Those of you who service assisted living facilities: do they typically ask for proof of insurance? I have been seeing someone for 4 years in a facility and the new administrators have been extremely hostile toward me and are now asking for proof of insurance. I've never had a facility ask before. If it's normal, I'm ok with it but they've been so hostile I wanted to double check.

comments.text:
This is an opportunity to build trust and credibility! 

Ask if you can meet with them, then ask how you can best support their needs and their residents and make it an easy ‚Äúyes‚Äù for them. 

How can you prove to them you‚Äôre ‚Äúsafe‚Äù to have in the building? 

The new administrator may have had some bad experiences somewhere else. If I hadn‚Äôt been in this group and understood more about mobile practices, I would probably a little skeptical about a one-person PT ‚Äúclinic‚Äù compared to a larger organization that feels like it would have more checks/balances/accountability. 

How do they know you won‚Äôt just skip town and become untraceable? Who is supervising you to make sure you‚Äôre legit? 
How do they know you‚Äôll refer to a HH agency when appropriate instead of keeping them on your own caseload? 
(There are just thoughts they may have ‚Äî I don‚Äôt need the answers.üòÜü´∂) 

Good luck! 
Maybe you can win more referrals by being proactive!
Yes

How can you prove to them you‚Äôre ‚Äúsafe‚Äù to have in the building? 

The new administrator may have had some bad experiences somewhere else. If I hadn‚Äôt been in this group and understood more about mobile practices, I would probably a little skeptical about a one-person PT ‚Äúclinic‚Äù compared to a larger organization that feels like it would have more checks/balances/accountability. 

How do they know you won‚Äôt just skip town and become untraceable? Who is supervising you to make sure you‚Äôre legit? 
How do they know you‚Äôll refer to a HH agency when appropriate instead of keeping them on your own caseload? 
(There are just thoughts they may have ‚Äî I don‚Äôt need the answers.üòÜü´∂) 

Good luck! 
Maybe you can win more referrals by being proactive!

COMMENT 2: Yes

post_text:
I've seen a lot of concern about us losing the title "professional". The absolute lowest bar of acting like a professional is being a member of your professional organization. 

APTA is all over this fight and other fights like it every day, year after year. They protect and maintain our profession from constant attacks on our scope and our payment. I hope you'll join the 100,000 members of APTA who choose to support these constant battles that threaten our profession.

comments.text: I'm going to step away from this and let it bubble a little bit, but I'll be back with more responses. I would love to hear more from others who have had positive experiences in APTA. I see your thumbs up, but we need more vocal advocacy like this for our essential organization. Most people don't understand what a professional organization does, and I'm happy to try to pull back the curtain. A lot fo the work sounds boring, but it is literally the difference between PT existing and being swallowed up bit-by-bit by "body workers" and others. We would cease to exist shockingly fast without APTA.

All the pitchforks and torches came out to represent here, and I can't possibly find the time to respond to all of them. If you see that a bunch of people were clamoring for continued representaion as "professionals", and others could care less and have other priorities.... and then you multiply that by hundreds of issues with differing opinions across 300,000 licensed PTs, you start to see the complexity of APTA. I hope more of the PT profession can start to see APTA not as an optional organization, but one that fills hundreds of essential roles that no other organization can fill. Once we, as a profession, recognize that fact, we can all work together to make our profession and it's impact on people even better.

post_text: Asking for suggestions. I have an LLC and want to start marketing a mobile outpatient clinic with just me, a PT. I currently see mostly geriatric patients and post op joint replacements but also have my LSVT Big certification and really enjoy working with my current population. I have an opportunity to have a booth at a local wellness event and need some suggestions/recommendations on how to make my booth stick out. Besides business cards should I have give aways also? I was thinking of offering quick fall screenings and stuff. The event is 1/3/26 so coming up soon but was just offered the opportunity to have a booth at the event!

comments.text:
I do a lot of corporate events like this and the most popular giveaways Ive ever done were hyperice products (the giveaway depended on the size of the event). I‚Äôm also a sports med clinic so it fit the clinic brand. 

I also usually hire a massage therapist to give out free 5-10 minute chair massages. The person has to fill out a lead magnet before they are allowed to the massage this way I have their contact info to reach out to after the event.

post_text: What advice would you give to a therapist who wants to be uncaged?

comments.text: Answer three questions: WHY and WHY and WHAT.... Why do you want to be UNCAGED for yourself? What is in it for you and your family (or future family).  WHY does YOUR practice have to exist in the community?  WHAT is it that you do for people. Then..... BELIEVE in yourself. Understand what your PASSION is. Display ACTIVE PATIENCE.  Maintain your GRIT.  Finally, truly, save yourself time, money (in the long run), and a world of frustration by having a guide/mentor/coach who has done it to lead you.

Hire a business coach.  They help rocket your business forward faster and with less guesswork.  They have several proven processes because they've been there and have already helped others.
You're going to make your own mistakes no matter what, but you can avoid the ones they've already made. They know how to coach past them. 
David Bayliff , who runs this page has an incredible program. Free knowledge is great, but it only takes you so far.
You need to invest in your knowledge by hiring a coach. 
I am in my 3rd practice. A formal coaching group was the best investment I ever made.

‚û°Ô∏è Why confidence is the #1 skill for success in business (and life)
‚û°Ô∏è The connection between sports and leadership
‚û°Ô∏è How to reset when your confidence takes a hit

post_text: Looking to get myself and my clinic out into the community and set up a table at a local town fair. What are some things that you guys do that bring people in at these events? I obviously don‚Äôt want to do a whole ortho assessment bc it‚Äôs a waste of mine and their time. Not exactly sure how I can sell myself to a random person at one of these event.

comments.text:
Don‚Äôt think about selling yourself. Think about events like blind dates. If you sell yourself hard it can be off putting. 

Be nice. Talk to people about where they‚Äôre at what their problems are. Make it about them. 

Offer how you can help them but don‚Äôt be pushy. Get contact info, get them to follow your insta etc‚Ä¶

I‚Äôve done cupping and scraping before at health fairs which has brought in new patients‚Ä¶ most of them didn‚Äôt know I did these kinds of things‚Ä¶ I always go in with a goal of how many new patients I want to get out of the event to make sure I‚Äôm very intentional with it!

post_text: Any chance the admins of this group could start blocking spammy posts?  People are replying multiple times on the same posts to get us into their long term investments groups. comments.text: Thanks you guys!  I appreciate your diligence. I didn‚Äôt realize I could flag it, so I‚Äôll start doing that if I see em!

post_text: I'm considering starting my own practice. Torn for many reasons. Unfortunately, small town and I would need to be in network with some insurances. Does anyone know if there is anything wrong with getting in network with insurances and then not billing them, if I end up not going out on my own?

comments.text:
I started in a town 5 yrs ago , population of 5 thousand, now close to 7 thousand. I have been able to create an amazing network and created enough impact to be able to hire my first full-time employee! I linked up with a group of passionate massage therapist first then slowly added to our group.

We strictly cash-based, no insurance. My advice: hire a coach. You can do it!!!
If you are in network with an insurance company you can‚Äôt charge people with that insurance for anything insurance covers.

post_text: I have a patient that requested medical records for disability. We provided these records and she wants to have a meeting to discuss some ‚Äúinaccuracies‚Äù she sees in the record. I have explained that we can not/will not change the documentation. Am I required to meet with her? Or can I just ask her to email me a list of things she disagrees with and attach them to her medical record so that her concerns are documented?

comments.text: I believe a pt. Can request amendments for what they believe to be inaccuracies and you do have a certain time frame in which you need to respond. I would honestly call your malpractice and see what the procedure should be.
I recently reviewed some of my medical records and found inaccuracies.  They are entitled to request a change if they are inaccurate.

full_thread_text:
POST: I have a patient that requested medical records for disability. We provided these records and she wants to have a meeting to discuss some ‚Äúinaccuracies‚Äù she sees in the record. I have explained that we can not/will not change the documentation. Am I required to meet with her? Or can I just ask her to email me a list of things she disagrees with and attach them to her medical record so that her concerns are documented?

COMMENT 1: I believe a pt. Can request amendments for what they believe to be inaccuracies and you do have a certain time frame in which you need to respond. I would honestly call your malpractice and see what the procedure should be.

COMMENT 2: I recently reviewed some of my medical records and found inaccuracies.  They are entitled to request a change if they are inaccurate.

post_text: Is Pickleball a good way to meet people and potential patients? I‚Äôm a beginner in the sport

comments.text: If your niche plays pickleball, yes. If they don't, no.

I definitely wouldn‚Äôt use it solely to meet potential patients. Relationships that happen organically tend to lead to better connections in terms of patients. I‚Äôm a competitive powerlifter and I work out in a specialized gym for that, have for about 3 years now. I‚Äôve never been shy about what I do for a living but I‚Äôve never handed out a business card. So now my coach knows me and trusts me, and sends me his athletes when they need care. I never forced anything, and never intended to. It happened organically.

full_thread_text:

post_text: If I‚Äôm coaching instead of treating‚Ä¶. Do I need a license in the state my client is in?

comments.text: I have talked to several different lawyers on this. From what they have all explained, if you are health coaching (meaning something specific is being worked on or they have a diagnosis that is trying to be helped) you have to be licensed in their state. If you are doing wellness coaching (no diagnosis, just working on general health and nothing specific) then you do not need to be licensed

Nope. Curious what you are doing from the coaching/wellnesss side of things. I feel like I always have a fear of the ‚Äúwhat if‚Äù so I tend to be pretty cautious even though I know there is so much more I‚Äôm capable of providing beyond ‚Äúskilled therapy‚Äù

post_text: What are your top 2 interview questions when hiring a virtual assistant to make sure they are a good fit for your practice?

comments.text: Did you see the list in the drive?

Organization is key. I have them tell me specifics about how they stay organized. I will often give them a task as a test (paid for) and we'll use that to assess them.  It is usually a task that takes a good amount of organization. If they are also going to be customer facing and communicating with customers on a regular basis then I also test their their communication skills. Often I will give them a scenario and ask them to respond to a patient. It will be fake, but it lets me test what their email/phone skills are like and how they communicate and how they come off.  It also allows me to test how they do with problem solving given limited instructions.  These tasks are also timed tasks so it lets me assess their ability to meet deadlines.

full_thread_text:
POST: What are your top 2 interview questions when hiring a virtual assistant to make sure they are a good fit for your practice?

COMMENT 1: Did you see the list in the drive?

COMMENT 2: Organization is key. I have them tell me specifics about how they stay organized. I will often give them a task as a test (paid for) and we'll use that to assess them.  It is usually a task that takes a good amount of organization. If they are also going to be customer facing and communicating with customers on a regular basis then I also test their their communication skills. Often I will give them a scenario and ask them to respond to a patient. It will be fake, but it lets me test what their email/phone skills are like and how they communicate and how they come off.  It also allows me to test how they do with problem solving given limited instructions.  These tasks are also timed tasks so it lets me assess their ability to meet deadlines.

Hi all! I‚Äôve been a fly on the wall in this group for a week or two and the info is all so helpful!!

I‚Äôve been in outpatient PT for 11 years, and PRN for the last 5. I‚Äôve had the tug to open my own mobile, cash based practice for about a year now üôà and finally am brave enough to move forward ü•≥

My LLC paperwork is filed and I have EMR set up but the NPI confuses me. It looks like I have an NPI1. Should I change the address of this from my current employer to myself? I will likely continue to work prn for them for a little while. Just not sure how to move forward there.

I would also LOVE to work with the Parkinson‚Äôs population as I am BIG certified and have a great referral source, but you all have made me aware that I will probably have to accept Medicare for that and I don‚Äôt know if I‚Äôm ready for that yet üòÖüòÖüòÖ

Anyways‚Ä¶THANK YOU for all the great content you all put in this group. It‚Äôs helped me so much already!!

comments.text:
Anthony Maritato has a YouTube channel that covers lots of things, including the NPI question! 

He also has a Facebook group, Medicare Billing for (Mostly) Cash Based PT, OT, SLP Providers Group . I take Medicare because I also work with Parkinson's, and that group has been a wealth of information and help.

post_text: How did I miss this this week??? Who went? What was the outcome?? Why wasn‚Äôt this all over the place?? Not only did I not see it all over I didn‚Äôt see it all ALL ANYWHERE. Link below üëáüèº

comments.text: I went.  Got multiple emails about it ahead of time....starting in Jan/Feb timeframe I believe.  About 1/4 of the PTs there were private practice owners.  You're split up by states and you schedule meetings ahead of time with your senators and local districts.  I also went 5 years ago.  It's impossible for a lot of PTs to go because you absolutely cannot put 20+ PTs in a meeting room with a congressman...they physically wouldn't all fit.  BUT that isn't to say that when your representatives are back home and away from DC that you meet up with them and advocate for what you want to see change.  That really is the best way and I've done that many times here.
Same! Saw the After photos.

You're split up by states and you schedule meetings ahead of time with your senators and local districts.  I also went 5 years ago.  It's impossible for a lot of PTs to go because you absolutely cannot put 20+ PTs in a meeting room with a congressman...they physically wouldn't all fit.  BUT that isn't to say that when your representatives are back home and away from DC that you meet up with them and advocate for what you want to see change.  That really is the best way and I've done that many times here.

COMMENT 2: Same! Saw the After photos.

Other than the obvious! and telling ‚Äúcaged‚Äù clinicians to become ‚Äúuncaged‚Äù how can we help our fellow caged clinicians, who need a W2 job for whatever reasons?

How can we help those still in SNFs or contract rehab Co. advocate for a new healthcare bill to prevent 100% productivity, groups and concurrents to be forced upon them, to the point at which we have ‚ÄúTherapist & Me: Senior Nap Time üò¥ groups‚Äù being paid for by Medicare! Or therapist working off the clock in droves‚Ä¶

Any verbiage I think of will also hurt us, who can ETHICALLY run well oiled, outcome producing, high level, outpatient groups and concurrents‚Ä¶

There has to be come creative way to word this bill I am envisioning to put the CARE back in SNF healthcare without hurting my fellow ‚Äúuncaged‚Äù clinicians private practices. 

If this is not the place for this thread please message me and I will start a group chat

comments.text: I do have an advocacy group but many in there are in the other side of the business and would not understand this question

What about a policy that states 

‚Äú
If ‚Ä¶clinician works within the same facility that has the at least 1 of the following 3 professionals also working or contracted there:
1. Doctors
2. Nurses
3. CNAs
Or 
If‚Ä¶the clinician has any Med A patients on their caseload that day

Then‚Ä¶the CTC, SNF, or ALF shall never do the following unethical things:
1. Demand that the clinicians productivity will be above 75% billable time that day
2. Dictate which clients are placed in a group
3. Threaten the clinician with an action plan or job termination for not grouping per scheduled list or not going above 75%

This will ensure that the following will occur:
1. quality and individualized patient care 
2. non-billable discussions with the IDT
3. medically necessary groups
4. working ON the clock

post_text: Anyone have any good advice/tips for making posts to local community Facebook pages? I'm looking to take my Mobile Med B side hustle to full time, trying to get more community outreach. I've gotten a good amount of likes on my posts, but it's not converting at the rate I'd like to getting more patients. Thanks!

comments.text:
Local groups are great for building "famousity"! So be present in the groups. A lot.

Respond to people's posts, even if it has nothing to do with you.

Recommend services that you don't offer, but trust and feel confident recommending.

Connect with the other regular posters who share part of your vision; become their friend.

Pay attention to the most frequently asked questions that are relevant to you -- the questions can become content for you (digital or workshops or both), and the people asking can become people you offer free resources and information to, until they're ready to have you solve a problem they have.

If there's a "small business posting" day, use it.

If there are networking events advertised, try them.

I posted a video of me introducing myself and my new business in a local FB group when I was just starting and it actually worked well! I think I got at least like 8-10 people contact me and 3-4 new patients schedule, which felt like a win to me!

full_thread_text:

I've gotten a good amount of likes on my posts, but it's not converting at the rate I'd like to getting more patients. Thanks!

COMMENT 1: Local groups are great for building "famousity"! So be present in the groups. A lot.

Respond to people's posts, even if it has nothing to do with you.

Recommend services that you don't offer, but trust and feel confident recommending.

Connect with the other regular posters who share part of your vision; become their friend.

Pay attention to the most frequently asked questions that are relevant to you -- the questions can become content for you (digital or workshops or both), and the people asking can become people you offer free resources and information to, until they're ready to have you solve a problem they have.

If there's a "small business posting" day, use it.

If there are networking events advertised, try them.
